I like LoS 1 enough that I spent many hours achieving 110% completion for it. Please keep that in mind when I say this is a step down from the first game in basically every possible way.

-Assumes you've played the handheld side game, refuses to explain itself.
-Combat is repetitive and limited, thanks to overly frequent enemy respawns, the inability to run past most fights, and overly aggressive enemies with too many ranged and unblockable attacks forcing you to give up on any sort of long fancy combo and resort to basic attack hit and run tactics.
-It feels like there are less bosses, and most aren't very good. Toy Maker is the obvious exception, that fight absolutely ruled.
-In a bizarre reversal, bosses are by far the easiest part of game, mainly because you don't have to deal with hordes of scrubs like you normally do and can actually make full use of the combat system.
-Stealth isn't just unfun, the STEALTH FEELS WRONG. You're f***ing Dracula, Satan himself hid in a hole for 1000 years cowering at the mere thought of facing you, why are you hiding from Resident Evil enemies?
-Not only is the Agreus stealth section the worst in the game, it's immediately followed by a boss fight where you kill him, making it completely pointless.
-The city feels like Arkham Asylum, a bizarre tonal mismatch, except of course when it feels like every generic modern day city you've ever explored in a thousands other games.
-The claws are useless, the sword isn't much better, their reach is just too short.
-No overall map in a game trying to be an open world Metroidvania. Local minimap is limited to the current room you're in.
-I've never before noticed the loading areas as much as I did playing this game. It felt constant.

I came into it knowing this game was flawed (mainly the stealth), but I was not prepared the sheer volume of negative changes that were made. A disappointing end to the Lords of Shadow series, and as of 2023, the entirety of Castlevania.

144448898.review:
Lords of Shadow 2 is what I'd call an over-correction. Everything that Lords of Shadow did poorly, this game improved and everything that Lords of Shadow did well was removed. Gone is the polish and the cinematic storytelling replace with a pretty fun Castlevania game straight out of the PS2 era.

The combat is arguably stronger than the first game now that you have a free-control camera and Dracula's improved air control. Everything has been rebalanced and tweaked to feel more like a beat 'em up rather than hardcore combat mastery. My life bar on hard mode here, lasted as long as easy mode on the first game and the magic meters were equally generous. 

Where things get trickier is that QTEs were replaced with magic required kills such as armor that can only be broken with chaos magic or killing blows that can only be performed with light magic. These feel far more natural and faster paced than the first game... but introduce a frustrating reliance on magic and identifying which special move the designers expected you to trigger.

Nearly all of the bosses have unlimited spawning minions because its the only way to charge your mana, which is required to actually finish the boss. The bosses were absolutely cooler and more varied in this game, but I really never felt the satisfaction I did in the first game. The QTEs were dumb, but I almost preferred them when I ran out of magic.

By end-game even normal enemies had armor that required chaos magic to kill and maintaining that meter was Tedious.

But the tedium was just beginning.  

This game tried to mimic a 3D metroidvania where you could explore a couple wide-open maps looking for upgrades and unlockable art. But the fast travel was absolutely atrocious... and ultimately lead me to give up on exploring. 

The problem is that there is two forms of fast travel and they are spread out all over heck and creation. So to get from A to B I need to:
 - Walk 15 rooms to a "Map Room" which only lets me get to Areas D, E and F.
 - From Area D I need to navigate these 9 rooms of deathtraps and wall climbing puzzles to reach wolf medallion that brings me to area C (Since you cant choose the destination of these fast travel points)
 - From Area C I need to walk 12 rooms back to the shop in B. 

  Keep in mind, there is 2-3 cutscenes for EACH time you travel. YAY! 

But at the end of the day I really loved the first half of the game and I enjoyed the experience as a whole. I liked the direction they took the lore, I liked the feeling of growth as you unlocked powers, and I liked the combat when I wasn't forced to beg for magic or health.  If this was the first lords of shadow game I played, I'd have been first in line for the sequel.

I'd call this a legit decent Castlevania game, but an absolutely dreadful Lords of Shadow game. Whether you'd enjoy the game probably depends on which of the two experiences you're looking for.

Titlu: O Încleștare Epica între Lumină și Întuneric în Universul Întunecat al Castlevania

★★★★☆ Recomand

Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 oferă o continuare a povestii intrigante și întunecate începută în primul joc, aducând o nouă perspectivă asupra aventurilor lui Gabriel Belmont. Cu o combinație captivantă de acțiune, explorare și elemente de RPG, acest joc pune în scenă o luptă epica între forțele luminii și întunericului.

Un aspect notabil al jocului este povestea sa complexă și matură. În rolul lui Dracula (Gabriel Belmont), veți explora o lume modernă în care forțele întunericului sunt trezite din nou. Încleștarea dintre lupta sa internă și amenințările externe adaugă adâncime narativă și dezvoltare caracterelor.

Gameplay-ul îmbină elementele de acțiune cu explorarea și puzzle-urile. Luptele împotriva zombilor, demonilor și inamicilor formidabili sunt satisfăcătoare și vă permit să utilizați un arsenal variat de arme și puteri. Transformarea în forme de demon și controlul asupra elementelor adaugă un plus de varietate în lupte.

Designul lumii este o combinație de locații gotice și medii contemporane, oferind o perspectivă unică asupra seriei Castlevania. Explorarea orașului modern și a castelelor întunecate adaugă adâncime și varietate în experiență.

Un avantaj semnificativ este faptul că acest joc aduce îmbunătățiri vizuale și tehnice față de predecesorul său, îmbunătățind aspectele grafice și ratele de cadre.

Un dezavantaj poate fi că povestea complexă și abordarea temelor mature pot fi mai puțin accesibile pentru unii jucători și pot necesita o cunoaștere prealabilă a poveștii din jocul anterior.

În concluzie, Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 aduce o continuare captivantă și încleștarea epica între lumină și întuneric în universul întunecat al Castlevania. Cu povestea sa matură, gameplay-ul echilibrat și stilul său distinct, acest joc este o alegere excelentă pentru fanii aventurii gotice și acțiunii supranaturale. Indiferent dacă ați jucat primul joc sau sunteți în căutarea unei experiențe întunecate și profunde, Lords of Shadow 2 vă va captiva cu siguranță și vă va oferi o luptă epică între forțele întunericului și luminii.

[h1] TL;DR [/h1]
[b]A mixed Gothic adventure with exceptional Gothic themes, atmosphere and visuals with fluctuating levels of quality and okay combat. Almost 23 hours for my first playthrough and no regrets.[/b]
 
 
[i](Spoiler free story wise, does describe aspects of the game)[/i] 
My experience of this game as you've already read is mixed. If I had to rate this game out of 10 it would be something like 7/10 but that doesn't really express how I feel about the game so this review is gonna be dissected into pros and cons.

[b]Good things that stuck:[/b]
Strong start right into the action. I had played the beginning of the game way back when I was younger and it felt so great and nostalgic to play it again. The intro is so lovely and I would say one of the best parts of the game.
The world building and atmosphere in this game is one of its biggest strengths. It is such a key element that it single-handedly makes the game still relevant to this day. At the same time while the map is very huge and everything connects to each other almost making it an open world it is insanely detailed and full of stuff to find and see.
A lot of collectables and side content, from trials and bonus areas to collectables, items and upgrades it makes you want to take every step carefully and fully explore the entire game.
This also helps immersing you into the game and enjoy its beautiful visuals and locations. The graphics are especially impressive and good looking for its time and can still be enjoyable even today.
If you're into Gothic themes, this is a perfect game for you. The solid variety of enemies and enemy designs, paired with great characters, immerses you in a dark and mysterious world that feels truly Gothic in every aspect.
While playing, I made an effort to miss as little stuff as possible resulting in my first playthrough being almost 23 hours, and I still didn't manage to fully complete everything in the game. Maybe one day I'll go back and try to 100% the game.
It was relatively fun the whole way through particularly every boss felt exciting and the gameplay overall was satisfying and fun. Mostly because of the main mechanics surrounding the combat and your selection of weapons and powers.
But here's where it starts to feel icky, maybe more if you're sensitive to stuff like this and it really bothers you. I myself tolerated a good amount but never really irritated me.

[b]Not so good things that stuck:[/b]
The combat is very easy and overall pretty simple. I wouldn't say basic because the gameplay has its depths but definitely god of war level of difficulty.
The parry system specifically being the most important mechanic to keep the combat together is very awkward and effortless. The input if I remember correctly is the same input as rolling/dodging but you have be neutral on the joystick. Also the quick get up mechanic after getting hit threw me off and I didn't get used to it through the whole game.
The dialogue in general was mostly okay and not very noteworthy. Some parts were a bit average, some parts kinda bad and some handful of parts were absolutely brilliant. It was really boring and underwhelming towards the end.
Notably the game's climax, the final boss felt unfinished. They wanted to do something special for the ending but it kinda felt underwhelming and drawn-out.

Overall the game felt Inspired and pretty special and I had a lovely time playing it even though it wasn't perfect.

141221597.review:
[b]TL; DR[/b] [i]Castlevania: Lords of Shadow[/i], but Dad Game. At its best this game is good, but for the most part of its 20ish-hour runtime it is simply fine. It is easily my least favourite game in the trilogy. 

[b]Note[/b] this review is very negative, but I did enjoy myself enough to recommend the game to other people. 

[h1] Story [/h1]
Many years have passed since [i]Mirror of Fate[/i], and Dracula has now woken up in the future, the year is in the late 2050s, and his old friend offers a deal. Stop Satan’s return and be free from immortality. 
This is the main conflict within the game, Satan versus Dracula, but there is also the struggle between Dracula and Gabriel Belmont. Both of these are fine on their own but prefer one of these over the other, however, the way the two of them are handled together cheapens both of them.

You will be spending hours in the City on one objective only for the game to abruptly force you into Dracula’s Castle to deal with something else, typically rewarding you with an item you need to progress. This, the constant interruption of cutscenes, and certain gameplay elements removes any sense of urgency, and ruins the pace of the game.   
I certainly like a number of things that happen, I think a lot of the cutscenes have nice perspectives, there are some cool callbacks to previous games, and I did find myself caring about what happened, despite the corny dialogue. But that does not mean that I think the story was told properly, overall, I am rather disappointed.

[h1] Presentation [/h1] 
Out of all the [i]Lords of Shadow[/i] games this is the one with the best visuals, the textures, the light, the shadow, it all works quiet well together, and this gets accentuated in a lot of cutscenes. At its best it feels like it could have been taken from a movie, if you omit certain things. 
One of the things I enjoyed the most was a very short, but beautiful section involving a puppet theatre where most aspect of the game seems to come together and give you a glimpse of how good the game could have been.  

On the other hand, we have the designs, some of it is on the generic side. Take the demons as an example, some of their designs are not distinct enough from each other, and at a glance it can seem that the only thing that separates them is their scale, which is not factual, but it feels true which is the problem.  
There are also the futuristic designs, I do not mind them since the game is supposed to take place in the future, and since there were some precedent set by [i]Lords of Shadow 1[/i], but I am also not very fond of them. The only designs I really like belong to bosses. 

However, there are also issues with some of the sounds in this game, mostly they are fine, some might be stock sound effects (I believe I have heard them in other games), and then there are a few that are grating to the ears. The worst of the worst is the Vampires’ sonic attack, save me please, because it is doing more damage to me than to Dracula. 

Luckily the music is good, maybe not as good as previous games, but still, and it is the same returning composer. I would argue that the orchestral music mostly evokes a sense of nostalgia, and longing which is appropriate. But there are also some tracks with a more modern feel, I did not like them too much, but they are certainly a good fit for the City areas. 

On the voice acting, we have some returning talent, such as the two from the post-credit scene in [i]Lords of Shadow 1[/i], and a few others. Personally, I think that the voice acting on the whole is a step back, it felt as though they were less emotive, and some felt like they were just reading from the script. But then there are also scenes that make me think it is as good as the previous instalment at its best, so I guess you can blame the allegedly troubled development. 
On another note, dear god, these bosses are never quiet. The bosses shout taunt after taunt after taunt, to such an extent that whether not it is well written or acted does not matter, and they only have two or three lines! It gets really annoying, surely the fights make up for it?

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]
[i]Lords of Shadow 2[/i] is structured more like a metroidvania than the first instalment, areas are gated behind abilities or story events, but it is still very linear.  If you see an area, you cannot access yet, chances are that it is a mandatory area or that it is a dead-end with a collectible. 
The game does allow backtracking at basically anytime, but it is not without issues as the plot usually teleports you between the City and the Castle during cutscenes. Sometimes these triggers at your leisure, but in others it is just by entering a room you have to pass through. I only mention this since it is related to another issue. You can only move between the City and the Castle at specific locations, and you can only fast travel to and from specific rooms, these can be far away from one another which adds a layer of tedium to exploration. Another issue is how small each area, and they are all surrounded by loading screens, meaning you will have to pass through quite a while of loading whenever you want to move between areas.  

Did you know that this game has forced stealth sections? Did you know that this game has forced rat sections? Both of these are bad, and they are the first thing you will be doing after the prologue, have fun.
Another decision that is perplexing is the implementation of QTEs, these can be disabled, but why does it take two different buttons to spin a cylinder when most bosses are finished off by the press of a single one? Why not give the players the fun QTEs to finish of enemies but leave the one where you turn a crank? 

[h2]Combat[/h2]
If you are familiar with either of the previous [i]Lords of Shadow[/i] games, you will know what to expect. You have three weapons, two types of basic attacks, you can block or dodge attacks, you have sub-weapons, and you have magic. 
While the three weapons share broadly the same combos, they feel vastly different on account of the effects they have, their speed, and their reach. However, a problem arises with the [i]mastery[/i] system. 
It works like this, you use combos and that increases their proficiency, when you are proficient with enough combos you increase the [i]mastery[/i] which can be done twice for each weapon. As an idea this works fine and is a nice reward for using a weapon a lot, but in praxis it feels a bit tedious. Some people will not be bothered by it, but I am, as I found myself constantly checking my progress to see what combo I needed to use to gain that tiny bit of extra damage. The system would have been better if the [i]mastery[/i] always progressed when you used a weapon but with diminishing returns for proficient combos, but that is not what we have. 

As for how combat actually plays, well it is fine, enemies are typically just tough enough so that they do not take too long to kill, and also do a fair amount of damage on higher difficulties. It is just that the roster feels a bit samey with several foes intruding on each other’s niches, and there being too many ranged enemies. Nevertheless, it is fun, quite satisfying to finish off enemies, or to turn them into gore with magic. 
However… the tedium arrives with all the armour and shields, it feels like I can hardly pass a room without encountering them. Sure, you do not need magic to deal with them, but it is the preferred method, and when there are this many of them it becomes more an annoyance than a consideration for combat.

140817379.review:
I'm writing this in case there is still anybody downloading and playing this for the first time. 

First of all, the scenery is gorgeous; and even in 2023, impressive to look at. There's a floating temple in the City of the Damned map that's so beautiful, it's frame-able. This is offset by how much backtracking one has to do--there's not an easy way to get around the map. Places are meant to be revisited, and the modern/medieval ferrying they do in the game give the player some option to change scenery when one gets boring or frustrating, and there is a map room that allows fast travel (to other map rooms). But you still wind up hoofing it quite a lot (unless I'm just doing it wrong). This is rather tedious and not fun, especially for the inclusion of the following:

Add to that the respawns that ambush the player all the time that, in many instances, cannot be bypassed, locking you in with them gladiator arena-style. If you try to leave the fight with the jump-climb gimmick that is used extensively to explore, the enemies theatrically shoot you down and force you to fight with them. That's a big "f- you" from the game and really irritating when you're just trying to get around.

Add to that the tedium of the fights themselves. Look--some people like the combo-input, button-mashing style of gameplay, so I can't bash that as a fault, although that isn't my thing. But the huge weapon swipes and long hit stops and lighting effects and explosions and dramatic sounds that accompany all the attacks are completely nullified by the fact that everything takes over a hundred hits to kill. It's really quite emasculating. I don't know why games keep doing it, except that people are just sensory-adapted and need bigger, louder explosions more often to be entertained. There are some combat mechanics that I thought were good ideas and sensible to implement--like enemies guarding, requiring a guard breaker move--but the wind-up for the guard breaker (or any technical move/combo) is so big that enemies usually punish you for attempting them, especially when there are three of them, which there usually are. I just found the fighting to all feel very spammy and annoying. Not too difficult--just annoying. Tedious. It's like chewing on a piece of fat. I wanted to play the game like it seemed it was meant to me, but I never felt like I had the chance, or like there was ever a reason to stray from the safety of light attack/dodge moves available since the beginning of the game.

Some of the music was/is incredibly beautiful, and some of it is just clever and really adds character to the scene (the rat music was great!). The problem is that there aren't a lot of tracks, and they're playing constantly, which de-values their effect and, after a while, makes them grow old. That's sad, because they really are beautiful songs, some of them. This could be easily remedied by only playing music when something is going on--not while wasting time backtracking through a tedious map with few shortcuts and constantly being held captive by tedious fights.

I was worried about the film actor voice overs being distracting, but found they fit in very nicely--except for El Chupacabra. They did a good job with the art and animation of this annoying, comedic relief character; but the voice acting, with all due respect to the actor, is embarrassing to listen to, bad to the point of distraction. Someone in the other room heard me playing the game and commented on how bad it was. A hundred other actors would eagerly have smashed that role, and they shouldn't have settled for how bad the acting was, not with their budget. The game has been out for a while now, and they will probably never replace the voice, like they wisely did in the English voice overs of, say, Blasphemous. 

O, and let me give a special shout out to the Agreus maze mission. Insta-death stealth missions are the worst, especially in a game that isn't built out around stealth--they're why I couldn't finish playing The Order. Done right, this mission takes, like, 5 minutes--but it is so infuriating trying to get it right, I almost bailed completely on the game at this mission. That, and the inappropriate use of apostrophe--it should be, "Agreus's," not, "Agreus'." English is hard, I know, but come on. "Agreus" isn't plural, and it shouldn't end in an apostrophe. I'd overlook that if I didn't have to see it over and over and over when I had to restart the mission. But there it is, the wrong usage of s-apostrophe, welcoming me back to one of the most infuriating game experiences in gaming history (I mean that, and this is coming from a FromSoft veteran). 

This game was almost great, and a lot of really excellent artists and devs were on the project; but its flaws, its shortcomings, its nuisances, stacked on top of and combining with each other made waste of its virtues. I wanted to love this game, but it's just too tedious to actually play.

Played originally on PC, then on Steam Deck + CryoUtilities
Finished in: around 20 hours

THE GOOD:
+ the graphics are nice, although I think the first LoS looked a lot better, and Mirror of Fate had much more style
+ all the crucial voice actors reprise their roles, including Patrick Stewart
+ it's the only Castlevania game where YOU play as Dracula (not counting stuff like Kid Dracula, etc.)
+ the inside and outside of Dracula's castle are absolutely stunning! (I love the City of the Damned for example!)
+ the cityscapes of Castlevania City can be very gothic and beautiful, with huge, beautiful statues, towering architecture, and little details everywhere, but most of the time their layout makes absolutely no sense
+ the opening of this game is very very strong, both visually and thematically, and the parts in the past, inside the castle are great
+ basically, the environments are very nice and epic
+ the boss and enemy designs are great as always
+ there's much more to do here, than in the first one, which was basically a very linear game
+ the fighting is responsive and if you come from the first two games, or any other game of this type (old God of War games, Devil May Cry's, etc.), you'll feel right at home
+ the relics, powers, and movesets are really cool, and feel familiar, yet a bit refreshed
+ there's just one chupacabra this time, and instead of being an annoying little **it, he's actually pretty helpful with his little shop (although, makes absolutely no sense... think about it: who's buying anything except Dracula himself?)
+ the enemies are varied and interesting
+ I really liked the Toy Maker part
+ some of the scenes are quite memorable...

THE BAD:
- ... but EVERYTHING in this game is sooooo over-the-top, like literally every shot is like a Michael Bay collaboration with Uwe Boll... they're trying to go for epic, and instead achieve cringy
- even Alucard's design is over-the-top and looks almost nothing like the one from Mirror of Fate - he's got a triple six-pack here for crying out loud xD
- the fighting mechanics are very similar to the ones in the first LoS, but this time the enemies won't stop spamming unblockable attacks, and attack you like crazy all the time in general, this makes Dracula fly around like a tennis ball being bounced from enemy, to enemy, making him look like an utter fool, not The Prince of Darkness... there's very little window to attack, and I found that the basic moves are better at hitting anything than the special combos you unlock, because, well... you will always be interrupted whenever you try to use a combo... I know that in both LoS and MoF it was also very easy to get hit, but come on! This makes the core mechanic very tedious when you can die to the weakest mobs
- on the other hand, while the bosses are nicely designed, they are soooo much easier than the regular enemies, to the point of being child's play-level of insulting
- the story is all over the place with conflicting moods, which break your investment in anything what's happening
- a lot of the modern-day locations are just boring, not because they're badly designed, but because they're... well... modern...
- many mechanics sound interesting in theory, but end up being extremely underwhelming, like the mist, bat and rat powers
- the game felt a lot more like Batman Arkham than Castlevania, I **it you not!
- the Void Sword and Chaos Claws are here to replace the Light and Dark Magic from the first LoS and MoF, but end up very uncomfortable to use. They just have too short of a range
- the story of MoF is explained after the prologue, but - aside from Alucard himself - there's little connecting the two games; in fact, it seems like MoF is being ignored altogether, by basically changing the way Alucard feels about Dracula by 180 degrees
- the ending is very, very underwhelming and out of character, is Dracula good all of a sudden?
- the final fight is also very underwhelming
- somehow they managed to make Satan look even more laughable, than in the first LoS 🤣
- there is a DLC, but to me, it feels overpriced, and I'm not gonna shell out money on it, to find out some tacked on stuff about Alucard. I think while the DLC for LoS is mandatory, and playing MoF is really advised, here, I don't even want to buy it

THE UGLY:
~ the whole Agreus segment and those weird sneaking segments in general, are just aggravating and nonsensical

Overall, if you liked the Lords of Shadow timeline, and this one is in a deep, deep sale, then give it a spin. It has some nice moments to it (mostly those taking place in the past), but overall I would advise to play Mirror of Fate instead. Only for hardcore Castlevania fans.

Welcome to my overly long ramble about the latest game in a series I love that is very super dead at the moment, and I hope it stays that way because I do not want Konami to touch this franchise until they are redeemed. I am familiar with this game despite my short playtime on steam.

To get the first one out of the way, the story is very mediocore and a very unsatisfying end to the Lords of Shadow series, but it has a few fun parts to it by the very end.
Having mentioned that, the game has great cutscene and in game camera direction, the enviroments are impressive and the art direction overall is great.
The sound design is very satisfying, hits are loud and gritty, any sound effect that comes from an object is well done and the music does its job, although nothing truly remarkable in my opinion.

As for the gameplay, many people will make the comparison to old God of War when talking about this game and the entire trilogy of these games. The comparison on a surface level would be accurate. Very cinematic experience full of over the top set pieces, huge epic enviroments, soft character action like combat against mobs of enemies and memorable bossfights (mostly I guess). When it comes to the combat however this one has a few unique quirks.

This game, just like the previous two, revolve around you using one button for single target oriented attacks called direct attacks, and mostly circular aoe moves called area attacks. There is absolutely no combo system between the two, as each button has its own series of attacks executed during repeated presses, and if you press the other then  you switch to its basic combo instead. What the game does is give you combinations between holding the attack button down to get a different attack, combining it with the guard button for something bigger and 3 unique weapons to switch between, each having slight range and speed differences, the latter not too much. The game however has an interesting twist to it that can give you incentive for creativity, which is that you can cancel any of your attacks into a guard, meaning you can get a bit creative with transitions between your different weapon attacks if you want to be a bit more stylish. However the game doesn't have anything else beyond that to make it into a more interesting experience for fans of character action games like DMC or Bayonetta, and instead focuses on a very simple combat loop that results from the weapon effects, which to specify: The Void Sword has a life steal effect while the Chaos Claws break enemy guard and are effective against shields. Enemy variety revolves around these concepts, and generally speaking the encounters are not too repetitive, but there is barely any truly interesting enemies or mini bosses worth remembering.

One true downside to the combat however, is the fact that there seems to be barely any (and I'm being generous with that since I think there is actually none) invincibility frames on your dodges or movement tools, making it so that when the enemny does an attack you either turtle it out by timing your guard button to get a slowdown that lets you retaliate, like a flashy parry, or you have to run away very far from them so you don't get clipped by their hitboxes. This mostly affects you if you are trying to play the game more aggressively through frantic movement, but it becomes an actual issue with certain bizarre enemy placements in small areas. Having limited dodging options makes the combat a little more dull for me personally, but I believe that it would make things better for everyone due to certain small details like unblockable moves from enemies having absurd tracking unless you dodge at the last moment allowing no preemptive movements and on the fly stategies and instead making come encounters feel like slugfests, making it so that you never truly feel powerful through skill. Just be patient and you win eventually.

A more general weakness of the game is its 'real world' sections, combined with its stealth setpieces which aren't anything special or offensive, just passable for me. Though some would tear the game apart just for these, and I cannot blame them myself. The dark city enviroments are not very interesting to look at, and due to the game's lore they combine certain aesthetical parts of medieval fantasy through statues and extravagant towers into the areas, making you question where you even are often times. It meshes badly with the main character himself as well, as you are controlling the legendary Dracula himself who for some reason is unable to climb through a fence. When you are in Dracula's castle however the game truly shines with vast and unique areas that showcase the bizarre and complicated anatomy of the castle. The game has a lot of great touches like soldier diaries that are basically POV memories of people who died trying to take down Dracula, and you get to see how they felt and dealt with the same enemies you do in the game, or the various hazards and platforms you come across, giving you more insight into the castle itself and the dangers of the monsters in it. When it comes to the lore in general the game has a ton of thought put into it and tries its best to make the experience more immersive, and for me it succeeds.

In an nutshell, it is a game that was clearly made with a lot of care, having some truly impressive presentation. Moment to moment gameplay  by platforming and combat that feels satisfying and fun, despite the lack of depth and some rare frustrating elements. The story should not be taken seriously though, unfortunately it is not very compelling despite its potential with the setting. Overall the game got a very bad reputation when it came out, press reviews were not very kind and fans of the Castlevania franchise were mixed on it, but I think the game is actually very good, deserving more praise for what it does well instead of hate for what it misses. Very high highs and very low lows I would say.

Después de una primera parte SOBRESALIENTE, esta segunda parte se queda, por desgracia, en un notable. Merece la pena jugarlo si te gustó el 1, pero ve con las expectativas bajas y con acopio de paciencia. 

Ahora un análisis un poco más en profundidad con posibles SPOILERS:

El problema del juego es casi todo lo que tiene que ver con el "presente". Si bien me dejó flipado en el final del primer juego poder verle en esta época, creo que no lo han resuelto bien. De escenarios y diseños espectaculares a una ciudad gris, sucia y aburrida (aunque intentan mantener partes antiguas del estilo gótico). Encima intentan abrirla un poco más perdiendo el detallismo que permitían los "pasillos" del primero. 

Además meten la mecánica de sigilo, que no me parecería mal (por los poderes que se les atribuyen a los vampiros como convertirse en niebla y controlar alimañas o transformarse en ellas) si no fuese porque a mi parecer está mal resuelta. En lugar de poder usarlo cuando quieras, te obligan a usarlo en determinados momentos, haciendo que estas fases siempre sean iguales. Tendrían que haber dado la libertad de poder usar el sigilo si estabas mal de vida o intentar ir a saco en cualquier zona. O si no haberlo limitado a los poderes que puedes usar para superar las zonas. 

Por otra parte el pasado sigue siendo lo mejor del juego, con esos paisajes y zonas espectaculares, mucho más inspiradas aunque lejos del detallismo del primero por hacer las zonas más grandes. 
Aun así, se han perdido los puzzles del primero, cosa que me parece lamentable si era para poner las fases de sigilo con lo mal resueltas que han quedado. 

Otra cosa que se ha perdido por el camino son los jefes gigantescos. Hay uno, pero está muy por debajo de cualquiera del primero. Con lo cual pierdes una parte de la epicidad del juego. 
Además se han empeñado en no darte recursos antes de casi ningún combate importante, así que los combates finales se vuelven frustrantes como llegues mal de vida. 
Y el combate final, regulero. Teniendo en cuanta que era el final de la saga, te deja encima un sabor agridulce.

La música y el diseño artísticos siguen siendo sobresalientes. Un gustazo ver los menús, las descripciones de las reliquias, objetos y los personajes con sus ilustraciones. 

Y luego el DLC es un caramelito que te deja con la la miel en los labios de no haber tenido más de eso en el juego. O un juego a parte así. También me hubiera gustado que el Mirror of Fate, que aunque el 3D es muy disfrutable, no lo sacasen igual que el 1 y el 2. 

Una lástima, porque como digo el juego tiene partes muy buenas por ser una continuación del 1, y luego partes mediocres que empañan el juego. Aun así el computo total de la trilogía queda muy alto, me ha encantado.

That way you are constantly pushed to play perfectly and not get hit, while making it damn near impossible to do so.

An other example of good stuff done horribly are the pain boxes. They are a way of getting access to more of 3 types of resource. Every box has a type of crystal in it that you need five of in order to unlock more of that type of resource. Some of the boxes are basically given to you just for progressing and some you need to find by exploring. Now here comes the twist. Finding the hidden boxes was actually fun at first and gave a sense of discovery, BUT needing to find 5 boxes for each resource makes the whole mechanic a chore. For example I ended up finding four of each different type in a row. That makes 12 boxes I had to find for before unlocking anything. So once again the game lured you in with a fun mechanic before ruining it with tedium.

129069792.review:
Remember when this came out? It was part of an especially bad story, but a lot was made over the gameplay and the visuals.

It does look good, mostly, and the designs are mostly pretty interesting. There are a lot of ambitious elements and creations, but you can see where they drew them from if you're a fan of Castlevania.

Unfortunately, it doesn't play as well as it looks. It's often stiff and sticky in controls, and it's not very intuitive. In basically any of the 2D Castlevanias, like Symphony of the Night, you have a character whose powers are intuitive to use and tends to have everything they need to handle boss battles. In this, despite controlling basically Dracula, you constantly feel outclassed and overpowered. The problem is mainly because this is from the design philosophy that players should be limited in how they engage with the game and can only resolve situations like boss battles in a very few ways. There are too many QTEs that boss mechanics sometimes depend on, making some of them virtually unbeatable if you can't somehow come up with what the developers want you to, which it does a poor job of conveying.

It's frustrating, it's not that exciting, and as mentioned, the story is terrible. The visuals are solid, but they're not exceptional, and they really weren't at the time either.

If they had gone for another especially well done 2D Castlevania instead of this, they could have really added tremendous quality and production value. In large part, though, Konami's insane corporate leadership and Iga's self-obsession made this whole series happen. You'll notice there was not a Lords of Shadow 3.

It's nice to be reminded of what you were up to last time, and I like that in general in games. It helps you slip back into the game, and that's a nice part. Unfortunately, it doesn't let you easily use multiple savegames, and as mentioned before, it's not that intuitive so it's not easy to slide back into. Unlike other stylish action games like Devil May Cry or Bayonetta, this game takes some considerable time to get back in the swing of, and that's a failing of the production.

It's a mediocre at best experience, unfortunately. I'd recommend even Lament of Innocence as a 3D Castlevania over this one. At least that one isn't heavily reliant on QTEs and a poorly-implemented set of abilities, most of which you'll never use unless you're forced to either by a boss battle or a stage, and even then it always feels forced and never really organic to the design.

Unless you're determined to play every game with the Castlevania title, don't waste your time with this. You'll inevitably hit a point that is so off-putting that you will put it down for good.

128920727.review:
I'm in around 5 hours in this game, and by now I think had enough. This games begins greatly, kicking more or less right from where the first LoS ended, and gives you the false(as I will explain later) impression of a story-driven anti-hero hack n slash action game playing as Dracula/Belmont. What more could you ask for, right? But that only lasts for so long, and after the hour mark the game begins to circle around the same dull set pieced gameplay through a pseudo-open world map. Obviously, I'm not having fun anymore, I'm just going to finish the game for OCD reasons and nothing more. 

First and foremost, I cannot even comprehend the setting and the story (so far at least) the game evolves in. Who could have thought that you get to play as Dracula the prince of Darkness, and instead roaming inside medieval castle corridors full of traps and hidden doors and dark forests,  you would at times be hiding completely powerless, behind truck cargo trying to get past the most disgusting enemies possible (from artistic pov) in one of the worst and boring stealth segments ever appeared in gaming, while trying to infiltrate a high-tech biolab in search of an antidote for an unknown disease. Wow! What's next? Frankenstein hacking bank networks traversing on roofs doing parkour stunts ? Honestly I'm having the impression that I'm playing as a lunatic dressed up and hallucinating of being Dracula. It's obviously a risk that didn't paid off AT ALL. All in all the 'modern day' segments are horrendous, maybe that idea could work out in an animated series, but not in a Castlevania vg title.

But of course, there are also the Castle segments accessible sometimes at random, sometimes at will though the wolf medalion areas, and although they are obviously far more interesting than the modern day ones, they too fall short mainly due to the extreme linearity while at the same time the game tries to convince the player that he gets to explore the "open" map at will. That doesn't happen almost at all, but I do think there's a fast travel option which I haven't yet explored since I would rather get on with it as fast as possible.

Combat is good in par with the 1st one, I would say almost identical, the move set for each weapon may be looking fancy, but in the end I found myself just mashing buttons randomly since there's too much combinations to remember and eventually stick with the whip which is the main weapon after all and has the shortest moves list from all 3 weapons. One thing that annoys me is that they chose to "lock" the use of Sword and Chaos fists only when the two meters is filled with magic and chaos energy accordingly. While being relatively easy to fill these meters, I believe the weapons should be accessible at all times. 

Exploration feels unrewarding if not plain frustration  since traversal can be extremely annoying at times. There are some segments where Gabriel/Dracula transforms into a rat moving inside vents getting access inside otherwise locked rooms. Sometimes there would be electrified cables moving around inside the vents, and I swear I cannot understand the hit boxes these cables have. It's just crazy. You get shocked having passed behind one, or escaping while running next to the sprites jumping off from the cables edge. It's completely random, and you just pray for the whole rat section to end asap. It's just bad and boring. And that stands for any given moment be it in the Castle or not, the game gets you to sweat for just getting another health/magic/chaos crystal, that in the end you may be choose to ignore them and move on. 

I won't be adding anything else since as I said I haven't finished the game yet but being halfway through I believe I have a good grip on what it has to offer. At least the soundtrack is very good, I would surely listen to it more later on.  

PROS

+ If you can forget the setting and the uninteresting vertigo of a plot... still...you're playing as Dracula/Belmont.
+ Music is great, even epic at times.
+ Some nice cutscenes so far.
+ Combat is solid though can be frustrating when facing multiple enemies locking on at enemies randomly. (upgrades give good crowd control movesets though)
+ Voice acting is great. Carlyle and Steward deliver both amazingly well.

CONS 

- Dull, annoying, badly executed stealth segments.
- Modern day setting feels far off from whole Castlevania/Dracula lore.
- Unrewarding and limited exploration. Many invisible walls.
- Tiresome traversal with many back and forths.
- Story could be great but instead seems like a complete mess.

Bottom line. Buy only in a severe price drop and if  - like me - have a knack for Vampires/Dracula etc. Otherwise there are far better action/advs you can get your hands on be it current or past gen.

128419253.review:
Where does one even begin this topic? The visual architecture alone is worth buying the game. A lot of time, dedication, and speed went into making this game come into fruition and it still received bad reviews by 'some' people. Critics will say it's just a copy of G.O.W. or Devil May Cry. To those critics I say let's see you make something better. Of course this version of Castlevania is no longer accepted as cannon, I am greatly disappointed to not see Mercury Steam give it a true ending it deserved. 

*spoiler* All we see after the one true Belmont defeats Satan, he carelessly breaks the mirror of fate (after spending a quarter of the game trying to put it back together again) and walks back into his castle leaving us with a cliffhanging cock-tease that is still felt to this day. Will he finally commit suicide and be with his family in the after life, or does Gabriel still have more work to do on earth? Unfortunately looks like we will never know and that is truly disappointing after all the time put into playing L.O.T.S/M.O.F./L.O.T.S.2. 

Even though this game is dead and no follow ups will be made (that we know of) I do recommend picking up this trilogy if/when it's on sale. My super old GTX-950 can play this perfectly at max setting on 2k resolution and it looks absolutely stunning on a 4K TV. The castle parts of the game are something to appreciate if you're a Castlevania fanboy. It's a shame we didn't get as much as we thought we would back when they first advertised for this. If only a few things were different it would have been an absolute masterpiece.

To those who say it's hard, you're meant to battle, gain EXP, and then level up. Just like every other Castlevania game you spend the entire time battling demons/monsters until you make it to Dracula, so why should it be any different this time?

Are the maps confusing? I must admit at times it can be. Some clean up could have been attempted but I heard the game was rushed so who knows for sure?

Even though it has it's flaws I give it a highly subjective 8/10.

P.S. I like that Satan looks a lot like Peter Steele on steroids. R.I.P.

Después de haber tenido una gran experiencia con el primer juego y esa incertidumbre sobre que pasaría con Gabriel ahora que ya abandonó toda esperanza no podía dejar pasar la segunda parte.
La historia continua con Gabriel, pero muchas cosas han pasado. Nada más acabar con el tutorial empezará a contarse una gran historia en poco tiempo, la cual es la base del juego que parece mas un DLC: "Castlevania Lord of Shadows: Mirror of Fate". Una vez terminada de contarse la historia ya estaremos en contexto para empezar con la partida.
Para resumirlo brevemente el argumento gira en detener a Satanás quien cree que Grabiel, ahora llamado "El Dragon" o "Principe de la oscuridad", ha muerto. Con ayuda poco confiable de su antiguo compañero Zobek intentarán frenar que Satanás sea invocado.
La historia tiene giros impresionantes como en el anterior juego y tiene momentos épicos que hacen muy interesante la trama. Sigue siendo genial en ese aspecto.
Gráficamente luce ligeramente mejor que el anterior y sigue teniendo un apartado artístico increíble.
La música esta bien supongo aunque creo que a veces es algo repetitiva, sin embargo, no es que moleste sinceramente pues es bastante asimilable.
El aspecto jugable si hay que remarcar que no todo es genial. 
Una de las partes mas lentas y aburridas son las de "adoptar la forma de una rata" para alcanzar lugares imposibles para Drácula en su forma original, la verdad no entiendo porque consideraron que esa idea fuera divertida. Felizmente esa mecánica solo esta presente en ocasiones contadas, sin embargo, rompen tremendamente el ritmo de un hack and slash. Los acertijos eran suficientes y podían haberlos mejorado, pero decidieron poner esa basura de convertirse en rata.
Otra de las partes odiosas y lentas es la de evitar ciertos enemigos que en primera instancia el juego te indica que son prácticamente invencibles. Tiene sentido al principio, ya que Drácula esta débil y no tiene suficientes recursos para hacerle frente a esas cosas en los primeros minutos de la aventura. Sin embargo, cuando ya pasaste por casi la mitad del juego adquiriendo mejoras en el camino que recuperarán a Drácula esos enemigos siguen siendo invencibles y esto es porque el juego usa a esos enemigos para justificar otra mecánica que podríamos decir que es "sigilo". La idea es evitarlos frente a frente, distrayendolos, evadiendolos convertidos en "rata" o acercandonos a ellos por la espalda para poseerlos y abrir puertas.
Estas 2 mecánicas realmente pudieron haberse evitado. Usando la forma de niebla para alcanzar lugares en vez de usar la estúpida forma de rata y haciendo posible enfrentar a esos enemigos en vez de hacerlos invencibles para forzar una mecánica que solo retarda la acción en un Hack and Slash.
Dejando de lado eso, el hack and slash sigue siendo bueno y podría decir que se amplio un poco más. Ahora las magias del vacío y el caos se identifican con el uso de una arma que las representa. Estas armas tienen sus propias técnicas sin olvidar que también tenemos los látigos sombras los cuales remplazan a la arma usada por Gabriel en la anterior aventura.
Este juego presenta 2 escenarios por así decirlo, por un lado la parte del Castillo y por otro lado, la Ciudad.
Cada escenario cuenta con sus propios tipos de enemigos.
En la ciudad encontrarás ciudadanos poseídos, demonios de todo tipo (estos son los mas divertidos), fuerzas antidisturbíos y entre otros parecidos. En cambio, en el castillo encontrarás sirvientes de Drácula que atacan al mismo Drácula y Soldados de la Hermandad (el sacerdote es el mas interesante).
Explorar ambos escenarios del juego ya no es sencillo como antes. Ya no hay un libro que te cuenta la historia y donde puedes elegir una pagina para ir directamente al capitulo que quieres ir. Ahora tienes que guiarte tu mismo por la ciudad o por el castillo y las conexiones que haya entre ambos escenarios. Se ha vuelto algo engorroso buscar un lugar específico.
Hay un lugar importante que resaltar que es la tienda del chupacabras, ese personaje molesto de la 1 que te quitabas tus pertenencias y que te obligaba a jugar a las escondidas para que las recuperes.
Ese mismo personaje ahora te venderá objetos como llaves, fragmentos de cristales de magia para aumentar tu capacidad o las llamadas "reliquias". Objetos que podrán recuperar tu salud, darte magia ilimitada por unos segundos, etc.
Honestamente casi no las use, incluso en la dificultad mas alta: Principe de las tinieblas. Salvo situaciones especificas, por lo general no considero que sean algo necesario siempre que domines el juego.
Sin embargo, donde si considero que serán de gran ayuda es en los "desafíos de Kleidos". Estos desafíos vienen a reemplazar a los retos del anterior juego. Solo que ahora mas interesantes que antes y algunos que parecen muy difíciles pero que tienen un truco bastante simple. Realmente me divertí mucho con los desafíos, sobretodo en la máxima dificultad.

En conclusión, Lord of Shadows 2 es un buen Hack and Slash que viene ahora ampliado con 2 armas nuevas que representan a los 2 tipos de magia y con mas posibilidades con el uso de reliquias. Sin embargo, también tiene añadidos innecesarios que pueden frenar la acción por momentos, pero que por suerte son pocas veces. Si vienes por la historia este juego sigue siendo genial, sin embargo, personalmente creo que desaprovecharon una gran oportunidad con el Mirror Fate, el cual fue incluido aquí en un instante aportando con la historia, historia que pudo haber sido plasmada en un juego que debería haber sido la segunda parte.
Si vienes por la acción en este juego ya sea que uses a Drácula o Alucard las posibilidades de como enfrentar a los enemigos son muchas y en eso esta lo divertido. Aunque me temo que deberás ser paciente al menos al principio, pero ten por seguro que mientras mas progreses en el juego todo irá mejorando.
Considerando el final de este juego se puede afirmar que es el final de la saga. No se si algún día se considere en revivirla, pero si lo hacen me gustaría saber hasta donde pueden llegar.
Lo recomiendo comprar en oferta y solo si jugaste la 1. Solo así estarás motivado y podrás soportar el inicio del juego.

Wether or not to recommend this is a hard question to answer.

If you're like me and have played Lords Of Shadow 1 and Mirror Of Fate and just want to finish off the trilogy, then I would say yes. Grab a guide and go for it.

If you're instead just windowshopping for a 3D Brawler or exploration game (and for some reason want to start with a game with the number 2 in the title), I suggest looking elsewhere.

Lords Of Shadow 2 has some fundamental problems in its game design that keeps it from being a great or even good game, some of which were also a problem in earlier Lords Of Shadow games. 
- Enemies are just a tad too tough and even basic enemies don't stagger easily, making your basic attacks feel like you're just slapping the enemy while they're wielding swords, claws and other sharp objects. 
- Each of them also have a number of unblockable attacks, some of which there's not even a limit on how many they can chain after another. 
- It's supposed to be a parry & dodge battle system, but the parry timing is not only very tight, enemy attacks track your position heavily, dodge too early and you will get hit anyway, dodging also leaves you wide open to get hit thanks to no invincibility attached to it. (There's a sommersault move that lets you jump over an enemy that I found nearly useless because of the tracking & non-existant i-frames).
- On the exploration side, LoS2 has a lot of slow climbing sections and "loading-time air locks" that make getting around kind of a pain. The Science District specifically is waaaaay too huge for its own good, too.
- Enemies also have ranged attacks with amazing accuracy to keep you from climbing or running away, making you clear rooms before you can move on even on revisits on areas
- Because of how many cinematic, area-destroying cutscenes & story-based teleports are happening, it can be really hard to make up a mental map of the areas.
- While you can see how many items are collectible in each area based on your current abilities and one of the consumables pointing out an nearby item to you, you cannot look at any different minimaps aside from the current area you're in.

A lot of the negative reviews seem hyper-focused on single mechanics and not the product as a whole. Mostly, just ragging on the stealth sections. They were reasonably integrated at first (what with Dracula being weak, etc.) but there should have been a point where you become strong enough to kill the guards cause there is some dissonance between having to sneak to live and being able to kill FUCKING SATAN himself. Anyway, this single mechanic doesn't really "add" to the experience and you'd probably have a better game without it.

Lords of Shadow 2 is better than 1. Plain and simple. It looks better, there's no fixed camera (thank fuck) it takes place in a freaking castle, and has that labyrinthian, back-tracky, secret-laden platforming that Metroidvanias are known for. The writing, I'd say, is on par with 1 - that is to say, its decent. Gabriel's turn to evil was kind of weakly portrayed in the first game and they retroactively explain his actual Dracula transformation in a DLC (that was unplanned mind you). He was kinda forced to kill people, or literally controlled to kill people and through narration it is said (NOT SHOWN) that darkness is growing within him. You don't really buy the transition. And all throughout 2 he never seems out right evil, just kinda jaded, like he's trying to convince himself he's the Prince of Darkness all the time. The ending was kinda anti-climactic. You just beat Satan and walk away, the end. No closure, no death, no nothing - planning a 3rd game? But the journey is fun enough. The game ultimately feels like a relic from a time before live services, day-1 patch, microtransactions. Just a solid single player experience that isn't loaded with "content".

The combat is also better than the first. Much more fluid and kinetic with seamless weapon transitions. That coupled with the relics gives the player a lot of choice in fighting.

I'd give 1 like a 7/10 and this probably an 8/10. It improves on a lot of what the first did and takes better advantage of a 3-D Metroidvania concept.

Lords of Shadow 2 is considerable different and more varied than the first game.
The possibility to be able to experience a dark fantasy future, with some aspects of "World of Darkness" and "Vampire: The Masquerade" in combination with the more traditional Gothic past is deeply interesting.
The gameplay is more fluid than the gameplay in the first game, but the scenery is less beautiful, inspired and varied but more dense, explorable and bleak.
Boss battles are creative and truly intense, the battles against Gorgons and Carmilla are between my favorite boss encounters of all time, side by side with bosses from Bayonetta, Ys and God of War.
The exploration is relatively more open comparing to the first game of the Lords of Shadow series, more similar to Legacy of Kain games.
Overall is a great experience for players who enjoy action adventures, "Dracula (original)", "Interview with the Vampire", "Legacy of Kain, Castlevania", "God of War", "Vampire: The Masquerade" and are able to keep an open mind.
Some reviews talked negatively about the "rats transformation" and the "rats sections". But they forgot that in the original book, in the Coppola's movie and in the "Nosferatu" (the 1922 adaptation), Dracula transforms himself into rats to be able to hide and escape. Personally I would like to explore more hidden places as rats.
Just like the first Lords of Shadow (a game I truly enjoy), LoS II is longer than most games of the genre.

114454404.review:
Tras tantos años, una nueva rejugada y sigue siendo lo mismo de siempre... Una de las mayores oportunidades perdidas.

Despues de la mas que notable primera parte, tenían fácil mejorar los aspectos mas cuestionables de aquella. Mayor profundidad en el sistema de combate, un diseño de niveles menos irregular, el paso de un Castlevania lineal a un Metroidvania el sistema de cámaras... Y lo consigue en parte.

El sistema de combate es bastante mas profundo y variado, es cierto que hay multitud de secretos por descubrir, un mapa que permite un mayor disfrute al no estar tan encorsetado, la camara sin ser perfecta si permite mas libertad... 

Pero por otro lado toda la parte del presente es patetica. No queremos jugar con el todopoderoso Dracula en alcantarillas y almacenes, no queremos tener que usar un sistema de sigilo patético y anticlimático. Tampoco tiene una navegación por el mapa fluida, con escasos atajos y puntos de teleport. Error masivo en un metroidvania.
Y el final es la cosa mas ridícula del mundo. Debian tener prisa por acabar el juego.

Eso si, a nivel audiovisual sigue siendo una pasada, con un diseño artístico de otro mundo, un doblaje excelso, y en general, la reinvención del canon clásico de la historia de Castlevania que ya inició el primero, es lo mejor que le ha pasado a la saga desde Symphony of the Night.

En definitiva una pena, tenian al alcance de la mano hacer un juego excelente, pero tantas decisiones de diseño tan cuestionables lastran al juego demasiado. Sus virtudes son muy potentes y claras, pero no pueden con el ancla de los citados defectos.

While this game is more Metroidvania like with an open-world platforming, its predecessor follows a more Dark Souls kind of gameplay. The general difficulty is less difficult than the first part, only the optional Kleidos challenges have some few very mean special tasks that need a big portion of luck beside very good reflexes. The strong points:
* a good fighting tutorial (this was missing in the first part)
* impressive buildings, city/castle settings and awesome statues
* normal playthrough is more for casual gamers
* better overall graphics
* there is a shop with one of the best sidekick characters ever

The weak points:
* a lot of important story things are just told in a rough cutscene. It feels like you missed a Lords of Shadows 1.5

105615300.review:
[h1]Sins of the Father[/h1]

Though it fixes many of the problems of its predecessor, [i]Lords of Shadow 2[/i] falls prey to many of the same poor design choices of the first game, and even decides to fail in its own ways. The game opens on a strong note, then drops off immediately after. The game follows this roller coaster structure of fun, followed by the antithesis of fun until you just get sick and get off the ride.

[h1]What Was Fixed[/h1]

The combat is by far, a million times more satisfying. The main weapon is still a whip and it still functions the same, which is good. But rather than just having red and blue magics, now you have a sword that restores your health, and gauntlets that break armor. Fundamentally, all of the weapons have the same combos, which is slightly disappointing. But they all have different advance moves, different feels, and all of them serve different functions which really helps mix up the combat. 

Platforming is also improved. You can control the camera, and for the most part, movement is streamlined and much more responsive than in the first game. I never really came across any platforming issues in the form of bad camera angles or Dracula not grabbing ledges he was supposed to. Overall, the whole game [i]feels[/i] much, much better to play.

[h1]What Went Wrong[/h1]

The game still repeats a lot of the same mistakes:
-Having your ability to recover magic being tied to a combo meter
-Having 2 magic bars
-Having to stand still to collect blood orbs rather than passively picking them up
-Secondary weapons aren't useful
-You need to use the D-pad to cycle secondary weapons/abiliies

Alone, none of these things are tolerable. Together, they just make the game bad to play. For the most part though, the combat is satisfying enough that these things can be ignored. What can't be ignored is that for some inexplicable reason, MercurySteam thought it would be really cool if stealth sections were sprinkled in throughout the game. And I'm not just talking about the rats.

If you look at initial reviews of the game, they all complain about Dracula turning into rats to sneak around enemies. MercurySteam has stated that they would do things differently if they could. But here's the thing: It's not just the rats. There are stealth sections that have nothing to do with rats. You have to sneak around Carmilla. You have to sneak around Argeus. Neither of these sections involve turning into rats. 

The problem with stealth in this game, is that it is in the game [i]at all[/i]. This is what I was referring to about the game following a pattern of fun, followed by not fun. Stealth sections are not "6-7% of the game" as the developers have said. Stealth sections pop in the middle of fights - Seriously, you go from fighting a monster on a train, to sneaking by big dudes with big guns, back to fighting, back to sneaking - It's nauseating. Mercury Steam was so clearly proud of their ability to craft stealth scenarios, that they saw it fit to pepper the game with them. 

Let's say these were actually good, well-designed, well-thought out segments, which they aren't. This isn't a stealth game. Nothing you do will make stealth fun because no one came here for it. This is going to a classical music concert, and then part way through the string section genre jumps into a rap group. Doesn't matter how good the rappers are, it's not what I'm here for. You are undercutting yourself.

Despite not being the main thing that ruined the game for me, exploration was also done poorly. They really tried to open the world up in this one, I suppose to encourage you to explore. Except there really is no motivation to go back anywhere. You will regularly encounter upgrades you can't reach without gaining a new ability, but it's very easy to forget where those upgrades were because all of the environments just kind of blend together. Even if I had wanted to go back to get things I missed, I wouldn't know where to start, and you are only looking for health and magic upgrades, which never feel that necessary - You tend to get enough just following the story and doing some minor exploration. 

[h1]The Story is Nonsense[/h1]

I'll save you the hassle - The Castle isn't real. This isn't technically a spoiler, since it's technically open to interpretation, and ultimately doesn't matter. The game is set 1000 years after its predecessor and roughly 500 years after [i]Mirror of Fate[/i]. If you know that Trevor is Alucard, then you don't need to worry about that particular entry. Technically, it picks right after the epilogue of the first game, but I digress. 

The game opens with Dracula decimating an army sent by the Brotherhood of Light. Alucard emerges from the shadows and fade to black - We're in modern times. Zobek, who's alive somehow, despite being burned alive by Satan, informs Dracula that Satan is coming back, and must be stopped. Dracula must regain his strength, kill Satan's children, and Satan, and then Zobek promises to kill Dracula, ending his long, torturous life. 

The game shifts back and forth between the main plot, as described above, and Dracula traveling 500 years back in time to his castle. The denizens of his castle all are afraid he's going to leave again, and so decide killing him is the best way to get him to stay. As mentioned, none of this is really happening - it's all in his mind. This is meant to be the story of Dracula's inner struggle. How he reconciles with being evil.

Admittedly, this is an interesting concept that could have been performed better if MercurySteam employed actual writers, rather than whoever they had. The main problem is there are 2 narratives: 
-One is about Dracula's fight against himself
-One is about Dracula's fight against Satan

These aren't really interwoven at all in a way that makes sense. Dracula just randomly goes back to his Castle to confront his inner demons while the other story goes on pause. Vice versa, too. I found myself caring more about Dracula's inner struggle, and when the game brings you back to the present day, I didn't really care what was happening.

[h1]Overall[/h1]

I want to like this game. I really do. The combat is fun. The music is great. It looks fantastic. But it just gets in its own way too much. Between the random stealth sections crassly shoved in and bad exploration, it's hard to recommend this as a game. The story is also just 2 stories that don't fit together - when one is going on, the other stops. 

It's just such a shame too, considering how much they fixed from the first game to see them stumble and fall harder than they did before.

By now Lords Of Shadow 2 has both its' staunch supporters and its' haters. There's no getting around the fact it is a divisive game. I suggest you play LOS 1 with the dlc (And even Mirror Of Fate) if you want to go into this penultimate sequel knowing what the heck is going on. This was always intended to be an alternate what-if universe split off from Castlevania's mainline canon. Names and locations are similar "but" this is not based on the nes classics,Rondo Of Blood,later Igavania iterations,or even the netflix animated series. If you are a "CV purist" you need to know this going in.

Beyond that? Personally I had a lot of fun! It certainly gave me the nostalgic "Castlevania experience" and with that came some frustrating platforming,difficult bosses, and environmental puzzles that required absolutely perfect timing and perfect navigation. Even on easy this game will make you a repeat cadaver until you recognize the patterns of your enemies and the layout of LOS 2's various breathtaking yet haunted locales. (Respectively split between the castle and the more modern city segments)

If you are a fan of action platformers and have been there throughout their evolution you will recognize a familiar pattern. Gabriel can level up and unlock a multitude of attacks. He has a variety of weapons. Certain items tucked away in the dark corners can increase his magic or his health. Certain abilities also allow him to more thoroughly explore each area so there is backtracking involved. Combat is fast and fluid yet also has heft and weight to it. Your chaos and void reserves are used to leech life from your foes or more effectively break off their protective armor. LOS 2 is the closest we've come to having a competent 3D Igavania game with modern improvements. 

(It's then a crying shame just a few flawed segments drag down an otherwise pitch perfect marvel of a game.)

Imagine being Dracula. Prince Of Darkness. The Dragon. The Impaler. You are obviously the most chad vampire ever to have existed! "Now" imagine going toe to toe with old pagan forest gods,psychotic police officers in mecha armor,floating life sucking wraiths,wall scaling contortionist ghouls,knights from the Vatican church,a menagerie of screen filling abominations,the grim reaper,and "finally" even Satan himself.

Retain all of what I just told you "then" come to the laughable realization glorified security guards wearing red Warhammer 40k armor can utterly destroy you with their pew-pews. And do you ever get to fight them on equal footing where you can eventually rip them out of their tin cans then snack on them like the human happy-meals they actually are? Nope! The reason being you only encounter these guys in painfully awkward stealth sections that involve running around as a rat briefly then possessing certain people to open doors. This ridiculous oversight makes these lug-heads the most powerful adversaries in the whole friggin campaign.

To Mercury Steam's credit these sections are brief and if your willing to soldier through them the rest of the game is a lovingly crafted masterwork. I didn't encounter any game breaking bugs. LOS 2 ran fluidly and concisely with hardly any lag. The visuals remain stunning to this day and the orchestral soundtrack and spiritual hymns fit the overall mood flawlessly.  (Exactly what you would expect from the same studio that recently brought gamers the highly regarded Metroid Dread on the Nintendo Switch!)

I've read mixed opinions about how this epic tale of family,betrayal,revenge,undying love,and redemption unfolds. Personally I enjoyed it and even liked the somewhat divisive ending. (Aka,another aspect that left certain folks satisfied and other folks disappointed.) Regardless you are getting some quality voice work from Robert Carlyle,Patrick Stewart,and the rest of the cast whom are also very talented.  
 
By now I hope I painted an accurate enough description with words to help with your final decision. I'd say if you enjoyed the previous LOS games as well as games pertaining to this genre in particular then the game is a steal for the price and is often on sale to boot. It is certainly a good choice for a Halloween play-thru when the veil between the living and dead is thinner and all matter of monsters go bump in the night!  

Pros

+Challenging but fair. (If someone like me can beat it then it is certainly not an impossible feat.)

+Combat that is easy to learn but hard to master

+Breathtaking vistas

+Traversing the terrain using vampiric powers is usually enjoyable and rarely tedious

+Not a bad looker of a game even by today's ridiculous standards.

+Good voice acting

+Music meshes perfectly with the atmosphere and mood of the setting

+Mostly forgiving save check points 

+Dlc lets you play as Alucard

Cons

-Stealth segments were not needed and are an annoyance that offers nothing positive to the overall package. 

-Certain puzzles and boss segments require split second timing whilst one tiny misstep can make you fail or restart the whole sequence.

-Castlevania city? Really? Who ran with "that"? Why not just call the place a Romanian sounding name like Wallachia?

Neutral

After having beat this game and Lords of Shadow 1 I believe Lords of Shadow 2 is my preferred of the two. The game expands heavily on the aspects of the first game that worked and ditched a lot of what made it a slog especially on repeat playthroughs (overlong puzzles, slow platforming as the pace has been dramatically increased, etc.).

I think most notable are the changes in writing (our lead has a lot more to say in this game than he did in his first outing as a playable character, and the world itself has more personality), and the changes to combat (your super meters are now also unique movesets with their own weapons tied to them, your subweapons are now rechargeable instead of limited by how many you can carry, there's even more move variety to experiment with, enemies have more varied movesets, more memorable designs and strategies to fight, and it's less focused on massive hordes and more focused on dealing with enemies that are more keen on putting up a fight individually).

While the game is on the shorter side I think this game stands above the previous game just because of the improvements and the ambition to try and make a big, interconnected world with secrets in this one which isn't something that the first game attempted to do, instead opting for a long quest. 

At the time of writing I've yet to play the DLC for this game, nor have I played Mirror of Fate, which only gets minor play in this game. This is a maybe. It's better than LoS 1 but that's not saying much. LoS2 has some good qualities but it is staggering how there are barely any elements of game design LoS2 doesn't squander in some way.

I suppose you can say that it remains a good game to look at and listen to. The graphics are very PS3/360 era but are far from ugly. Levels and monster design are quite distinct and striking, they've managed to nail the Japanese gothic style very well. The music is ok, it fits and isn't overbearing but not very memorable.

The camera is much better in LoS2 in that you actually control it most of the time.

The voice acting is good, particularly Robert Carlyle. Shame it's LoS writing. You see in LoS they seemed to write themselves into a corner as the climax heavily plays on redemption and self forgiveness which then made it all the more mysterious how the final scene came to be. The DLC forgot or ignored the point of the climax and presented a non sequitur regarding Gabriel's growth for itself, Mirror of Fate and the start of LoS2. 

LoS2's writing is muddied, lazy and one of the worst examples of cutscene logic I've yet witnessed. It's still a mystery to me how Gabriel/Dracula is exploring these memories of him, Trevor and Marie while we know that's not how it played out due to Mirror of Fate.

Controls aren't very responsive, sometimes takes multiple attempts to register input. This lack of responsiveness always sucks all the more in games where timed inputs are required for parries. The combat has a miserable attempt at auto facing which can have you attack in the opposite direction you tell it to. 

It has the worst stealth section I think I've ever played in a game. In general they make little sense as your character can easily overpower any foe you're hiding from, especially the section where you Dracula, Prince of Darkness hide from a boss from LoS1 that you beat as a human. But the section in the greenhouse is a masterclass in bad design. The floor makes noise in certain sections so you mist form over it, except the mist form is slower than a crawl and the hunter is homing in on you. Supposedly you distract it with bells however there aren't any in the longest section so GG. And then you just fight the hunter anyway, having gained no extra tool in the meantime making the stealth section pointless...

Fast travel is laughable, there are map rooms that take you to different districts of the city and the castle. However each district has multiple map rooms and you can't move between them, you just get a map room. Which one, lucky dip I guess!

There's a map but in terms of being useful beyond your immediate environment your SOL. You get a couple of rooms around you and no idea of where they link to the next sequence of rooms in order to plan a route. Though I will give credit and say at least the world map tells you how many secrets remain for you to find in the districts.

Speaking of secrets, there are a number of devices around the world that require keys to access new areas and upgrades. These keys are only obtainable in the castle afaik and you can only carry so many of them so you're going to have to find the nearest portal to the castle, go to the shop or kill the enemy that drops them, get your fill then clumsily renavigate the world (because again, fast travel is an obtuse ballache) unlock what you can then go back for more. FUN!

For traversal in platforming there are various hot points you can move/jump from/to. The start of a sequence is highlighted with a mini cluster of bats, once you're in a sequence you can press L2/LT to highlight available points to move to. Some platforming however needs you to jump ahead to the middle of a sequence and you just have to hope your man snags that point.

This is one of those games where the obvious stuff is always highlighted too much "Here you need to do this thing. This glowy thing here. Let's look at the thing together for a minute. Maybe 2." and you can't skip it. If you restart a checkpoint, it'll show you again in case you forgot. Also, collectibles aren't saved so you'll need to grab those again.

Speaking of skipping, it'll always replay cutscenes. Boss intros, using the map room etc. I get it, I got it the first time. You can skip some but why replay them at all? Again I will give credit and say at least LoS2 has the option to skip QTEs.

There are other things but you get the bloody point.
