95870401.review:
Castlevania: LoS2 is a decent story driven hack & slash title.
It also features some exploration and stealth aspects.
The first playthrough took me about 15-16 hours on normal difficulty ("Creature of the Night"), not including the "Revelations" DLC.

Noteworthy in advance is that the game uses 3 different upgrade systems:
- Weapon movelist upgrades. Unlocked through the ingame currency, which is mainly obtained from killing enemies.
- HP and mana gauges. Only upgraded through finding hidden collectables.
- Movement skills. Unlocked over time during story progression.

Con:
- The frequent stealth segments are barebones and mostly irrelevant. Only a single one stood out for me. Similar thing with the platforming, it is mostly just "hold forward and jump". In general, the game throws a lot of random mechanics together that it uses a few times in very basic ways and then disregards them.
- Lots of backtracking through already cleared areas for upgrades and story progression. 
- Searching for upgrade collectables is a chore sometimes.
- Story is kinda whack, as typical for hack and slash games for some reason. Lots of bland stereotypes.
- It takes a very long time to unlock new things. Even the item shop is only unlocked about halfway through the game. This also means you are stuck with only a handful of short combos for the initial ~4 hours.
- Consumables are overpowered.
- Lots of long animations that interrupt the game flow, like when transforming for stealth, picking up a collectable, etc.
- Annoying voice line loops, like bosses saying the same thing 20 times in a row. 
- Similarly annoying are all the different popups reminding you every 20 seconds that you have collected enough things to upgrade something.

Pro:
- Good english voice acting.
- Graphics are still okay by 2021.
- While the story didn't strike me as amazing, it does do a few interesting things.
- Once having unlocked a variety of different skills, the combat is pretty good. Especially the resource management aspect is fun. I imagine NG+ on harder difficulty is a lot more fun than the first playthrough on normal. 
- Interconnected levels, lots of hidden routes and secrets. Makes for decent exploration. Level design is generally good.
- Large enemy variety.
- Decent difficulty curve. 

Some further notes:
- I only ran into a single bug, which was that the game didn't let me exit the item shop once, so I had to reload a checkpoint.
- If it weren't for the upgrade system being tied to the hidden collectables, exploration would be a lot more fun. This is because it then wouldn't feel like you "have" to find everything.

Verdict:
The core gameplay of Castlevania LoS2 is good, but there are a lot of hiccups along the way. Not one of my favorites by any means, but worth a try if you already went through most of the classics.

This is the direct sequel to Lords of Shadow 1, which was one of my favorite Castlevania games. It feels like you are playing a medieval version of God of War. If you liked the GBA/DS SoTN style Metroidvania ones you might not enjoy this one.

Honestly this was nothing like I expected it would be after Lords of Shadow 1. The first LoS felt a lot more like a classic Castlevania game with faeries and werewolves, wargs and spiders. Dracula wasn't the endgame boss though so it wasn't exactly a normal Castlevania. It was more like Legend of Zelda: Skyward Sword in that it was an origin story of sorts. Lords of Shadow 2 was pretty different. It felt much more like Legacy of Kain Blood Omen 2 or Defiance or Soul Reaver than it did Castlevania or Lords of Shadow 1. It plays like Lords of Shadow but the story and atmosphere feel very much like a Legacy of Kain game (I love Legacy of Kain so I don't mind it at all).

You awaken as Dracula after many centuries of a dirt nap in your coffin. If you like me were hoping for an explanation as to what happened between the end of LoS1 and the start of LoS2 you will unfortunately be disappointed as very little in the way of explanations given. They do briefly touch upon it but it's a very brief description of what happened in the centuries between the last game and this one. Barely any info at all is given as to how Dracula became what he now is. The only real explanation we have is from the DLC that was in LoS1 Reverie, and a minute or two here and there as flashbacks in this one. Actually Mirror of Fate HD helps bridge the gap a lot more than LoS2 does but you are kind of left to piece it all together by yourself. Seems he went off the deep end after the end of LoS1 and hid himself away in his castle for eternity. In doing so he slowly lost all of his humanity and hope and out of hatred and spite and misery became Dracula.

It is an open world game that takes place in a huge city built on the foundations of Dracula's ancient castle. The city is split into 3 or 4 big areas that you explore throughout the course of the story and you can free roam and explore them as you wish, there are many secrets that have been scattered around the map. Much like Lords of Shadow 1 you find gems that upgrade your health and magic powers. There are items that restore health, give you temporary unlimited magic, slow down your enemies, there is even a pendant that instantly kills all enemies on screen. There are sacrificial fountains that grant Kleidos gems which unlock hidden challenges accessible from the chupacabra shop.  There are scrolls as well like the previous game that add history and lore to the series and help fill in the gaps between the prologue and when Dracula later awakens. There is a handy item called the Dodo Egg which will help you locate hidden items which was really helpful in finding the hidden items. 

As for weapons and abilities, most of the things you had in LoS1 make a comeback, but you sort of have the "dark" version of them you could say. The vampire killer has been replaced by a whip made of pure blood, and there is the void sword which replaces the "light" power that has ice powers and heals upon hit. On the "fury/dark" power you still have the fists of fury that do massive damage and break enemy shields. While you initially buy the skills and powers for each weapon with points you have to use the skills in order to gain XP for them and level up the weapon. As far as I can tell the additional levels don't unlock any new abilities but the level 3 does look pretty sweet.

The epic boss fights make a return and you also get to explore Dracula's castle and find out more about his past and learn a little more about his son Trevor (who also makes an appearance he has white hair you probably know who it is, he is in the Castlevania anime too). Basically it's a fun open world romp where you get to be Dracula and rain down death and destruction on...pretty much everything.

Good gravy what a mess. 

First the good, the combat is better, in terms of both polish and mechanics (free camera!). God of War combat still isn’t really my preference, but it’s functional now. You even get different weapons! OK, that’s all for the positives.

Gabriel Belmont is Dracula (Gabula from now on) and wants to die, Patrick Stewart tells him he will kill him with the only thing that can if Gabula kills three Bad Guys. Why can you get a game over if Gabula’s immortal? Good question! Anyway while looking for these guys you get pulled from a modern city into a castle in Gabula’s mind (?) at arbitrary points in the game to do some activities so separated from everything else they feel like sidequests.

The city sections are a low point of the game and probably the entire franchise. They’re drab and ugly, the layout would be impossible to navigate without the minimap waypoint. Half of the enemies look like they belong in a different franchise and genre. Most of the stealth sections take place here as well. It’s a meme to complain about the stealth sections at this point, and they do make up a tiny part of the game, but they really are shallow and putrid and it’s not clear why they’re in the game at all. In addition, the city’s scaling is kind of screwed up, Gabula is tiny compared to everything else, if you put him next to mundane objects like lampposts or cars he looks like the prince of manlets.

The castle sections are a bit better, one part even reminded me a bit of Psychonauts in a good way. But with how you get teleported in and how little these sections relate to the city to its hard not to feel like it’s just a bunch of random junk made in a vacuum and then smashed into the game haphazardly. The castle also contains the worst stealth section in the game, in its defense it does introduce stealth mechanics beyond line of sight, unfortunately they’re borked. You can ring bells to distract the guy, but when I rang the bell he just ran immediately to me (nowhere near him, projectile not in line of sight) and instant-failed me. Despite his own-zone attack you fight him immediately after the stealth section with no real change to him or you and he goes down like a chump, which makes you wonder what the point of it even was.

Spoilers follow, because these sections are just too insane to leave out.
Within the first 30 minutes Gabula vomits a stream of blood into the power source of a giant steampunk Christian robot, killing it instantly.
A big titty mind vampire in Gabula’s mind-castle seduces Gabula into drinking her hypno-blood, and then once you get past her stealth section and counteract her hypno-blood with Gabula’s mind-wife’s blood, she encases herself in an electrical sphere and tries to bowl you over.
A man drops a magic rock in the middle of a boss fight and then grows 5 times his size, you stop him by smashing the rocks surrounding the arena for 30 seconds and hes so slow I don’t think he got an attack off on me. The next phase of the boss fight is a QTE.
The same man kills himself minutes later for you, minutes after meeting you, for nebulous gain on Gabula’s behalf and without considering any alternatives.
You spend like half the game and multiple castle visits trying to get an antidote for a mutant plague for a mutant for nebulous reasons. Once you get the antidote Patrick Stewart opens a portal for you to teleport you back to the start, why didn’t he let you teleport there from the start, grab the antidote and go back into the portal? Would take too long and they’d notice the portal, stupid! Anyway then you find out the mutant is Bad Guy 1 and she tries to kill you by blowing up the building you’re in. Why did she merely pretend to be an idiot and pointlessly spend several hours chained to some rock? Good question! I dunno maybe she liked it.
You spend a long time trying to kill Bad Guy 1, much less time trying to kill Bad Guy 2, and then Bad Guy 3 and the endgame take like an hour put together. The game’s clearly not done.

If this review feels patchwork and disjointed, that’s just what playing the game is like. I spent most of LoS1 annoyed and most of MoF bored. I spent most of LoS2 just befuddled. This might be the worst LoS game as far as grading media with a beginning middle and end goes, but I think I enjoyed it the most out all of them. LoS2 is so bizarre and nonsensical I got a lot of value out of staring at the freakshow unfolding before my eyes. I definitely wouldn’t recommend buying or playing it unless you’re insane though.

84046489.review:
In 2010, the rather enjoyable Castlevania: Lords of Shadows ended with a major plot twist revealing that Gabriel Belmont was alive during modern times and was now called Dracula, taking on the famous vampire’s persona and visage.  This left fans to wonder how the sequel would continue the story, either as Dracula or fighting against the protagonist from the original game.  Four years later, Castlevania: Lords of Shadows 2 answered the question, but it’s a question that probably was more interesting to think about than how Konami approached it. 

Castlevania: Lords of Shadows 2 chooses to continue with the same protagonist of Gabriel Belmont, now called Dracula, and picks up the story after a second game, Castlevania: Lords of Shadow – Mirror of Fate, though it quickly glosses over those stories, even when they play a pivotal point in the development of a few characters.

With the player now in charge of one of the most fearsome vampires, one who the franchise has used multiple times since the beginning, it would be a chance to deliver an interesting look at both the character and mythos at the core of the Castlevania franchise.  Instead, Castlevania: Lords of Shadows 2 feels like it tries to stay true to the formula the series has embraced with the main character fighting some great evil with numerous minions.

The biggest problem with Castlevania: Lords of Shadows 2 and one we will return to multiple times is that this isn’t a generic Castlevania game, in which you usually fight against the forces of Dracula.  Instead in Castlevania: Lords of the Shadows 2, you’re playing as Dracula, and yet the game fails to make that feel like anything other than an inconvenience to the story that the game wants to tell.

In Castlevania: Lords of Shadows 2, Dracula is fighting against a greater evil in the form of Satan and now must battle his forces of evil.  While Zobek from the original game returns as a guide for Dracula, this feels strange considering how Zobek was used in Castlevania: Lords of Shadows’ plot.   Besides, much of Dracula’s personal forces turn evil adding new fights, and ultimately Zobek has Dracula hunt down various forces of Satan.  All three of these stories happen simultaneously in Castlevania: Lords of Shadows 2 and if they sound confusing, that’s because they are. 

Castlevania: Lords of the Shadows 2 also suffers from an excess of cutscenes that are either unnecessary, or longer than they should be, and this makes the player less engaged with the story, and experience because sitting through a 2-minute cutscene to see a hint on how to beat the next room doesn’t feel that much different than sitting around to hear two characters the player isn’t interested in talking among themselves.

Castlevania: Lords of Shadows 2 isn’t a game that has a clear narrative to tell, but rather talks about bits and pieces from numerous storylines and acts as if it's a story that needs to be told, and should be told.  Instead, it’s mostly just a jumbled mess of scenes that happen.  

A similar thing happens with the level design of Castlevania: Lords of the Shadows 2.  The game constantly moves Dracula around to different locations, as well as teleporting him to spots and leading him to the next objective.  But in general, the map feels strange and misshaped.  The buildings and levels that Dracula finds himself in don’t feel particularly interesting.  

Even the few times you revisit an area you notice how similar it is to every other area and city street you’ll come upon.  There’s not a memorable map or interesting location in Castlevania: Lords of the Shadows 2 and that really hurts the experience of exploring these locations.

Castlevania: Lords of Shadows 2 also tries to add a bit of open-world exploration but contains a completely linear story and progression so the major benefit of the open-world format is lost, and it just becomes a way to explore for unnecessary benefits as the game itself is rather easy.  Having to backtrack to just find the upgrades with new abilities doesn’t help this process either.

I mentioned that the biggest problem with Castlevania: Lords of Shadows 2 is Dracula, and it’s in the gameplay that I find it to be the most egregious.  The player never feels like Dracula, Dracula is a blood-sucking vampire who is known for his absolute brutality and violence.  He’s been the antagonist or final boss in so many Castlevania’s that one might wonder what it would be like to control him and possibly terrorize the Belmonts, or the civilians he might find.  Castlevania: Lords of the Shadows 2 starts with Dracula attacking a woman in a cutscene to draw her blood into him to regain his strength.  This is the first and last civilian the player even sees in Castlevania: Lords of Shadows 2.  

Instead Castlevania: Lords of the Shadows 2 focuses only on combat with the forces of Satan, and while Dracula can suck the blood of his enemies, they’re the same type of villains any game could have.  Even the “sucking blood” type of gameplay could be done in numerous ways, such as the Glory Kills in the newest Doom releases.   

This is Dracula, and yet, everything the player is told to do is “fight the bigger evil.”  If the character was switched out for any human Belmont, the gameplay could operate the same, even the summoning of a health regenerating blade, and stronger attacking gauntlets don’t feel like part of Dracula’s normal weaponry.

Then there are the stealth gameplay sections, that really feel out of place when talking about Dracula, repetitive enemies who seem to be able to take huge chunks of the player’s life force away, and Quick Time Events which are always a mistake, but feel like a major one with when the game kills your character and then repeats the same segment over again.  Players can disable QTEs in the options menu, but having better cutscenes that didn’t require QTEs would flow better in both formats. 

Not everything in Castlevania: Lords of the Shadows 2 is bad.  The enemy designs and the bosses look particularly good.  In fact, every boss is both very interesting and unique, it makes the issues with the level design stand out more with so many locations feeling so uninspired.  Quite a few bosses are exceptional fights, and that’s when Castlevania: Lords of the Shadows 2 earns a lot of the credit.

But ultimately the boss fights are the only thing I really enjoyed with Castlevania: Lords of the Shadows 2.  Otherwise, the entire experience was uninteresting and boring, and when you’re playing as Dracula in a Castlevania game, that sounds wrong.  

A few changes and I might have enjoyed the core of Castlevania: Lords of the Shadows 2.  Better level design, a few gameplay additions which feel more like playing a major vampire such as attacking innocents, or using them to restore your health, or just interesting levels to explore could have helped.  

As it is, Castlevania: Lords of the Shadows 2 is quite uninteresting, and feels like a game that I can’t recommend, nor is it one that makes me feel bad about this fact.  It’s also the last entry into the Castlevania franchise and now that I’ve completed it, I don’t feel like I should mourn Konami moving away from video games.  I instead mourn that Konami couldn’t continue producing interesting video games that I wanted to play. 

I ultimately give Castlevania: Lords of the Shadows 2 an arbitrary 

4/10 

It might be higher if this was a random game but coming after so many games in a famous franchise, not being able to find an interesting game here feels particularly insulting. 

If you enjoyed this review and want to see more from me, including more in-depth reviews of select games, check out my youtube channel at youtube.com/c/KinglinkReviews

I hadn't reviewed this game when I played it back in 2014 because I thought it wasn't worth it, but now that I have nearly completed my long retrospective of all original Castlevania titles I just need to tell the world how much of a mess this game is.

This game sucks. Big time. It sucks as an action game because its pacing is all over the place, it has terrible stealth sections and an easily exploitable power-up system that quickly makes you overpowered. It sucks as an adventure game because the exploration is nonexistent, the plot is bad and the characters are shoehorned so badly that you're gonna think you're watching some kind of parody. Finally, it doesn't just suck at being a Castlevania but it takes a massive dump over it, putting the final nail on the coffin of another series that Konami did all it was in their power to completely destroy. I swear that these guys must seriously hate every single one of their historical franchises with passion, because they ruined all of them. No survivors.

The first Lords of Shadow was still a disappointment in being a Castlevania, but at least it managed to be decent as an action game and kept a minimum of respect towards the original source material (DLC excluded, that was awful). This sequel showed no mercy in completely destroying the original lore, turning Dracula into some kind of powerless wretch who is constantly manipulated by Satan and the one who's supposed to be his most faitfhul servant - Zobek, aka Death - thus being unable to do nearly anything on his own. Characters from the original series, from Simon Belmont to Alucard, are randomly thrown in without a real logic and their backstories completely messed up, just for the sake of saying "see? This is Castlevania, the good guys are there". It's insulting, and the ending makes no sense either since it was a blatant attempt to leave room for sequels and make more cashgrab. TL;DR - This is not a recommend not because there's nothing good here, but because I think the amount of people that are going to be willing to put up with the weirdness and awkwardness to get to it is going to be a pretty small crowd. 

At Length - Probably the best thing going for Lords of Shadow 2 is just how delightfully weird it gets. It goes full force into the premise hinted at during the ending of the original LoS, putting the player in the shoes of Dracula in the modern day (or really, near future) fighting against Satan trying to take over the world. It's an amazing concept, and I honestly wish this was in the mainstream Castlevania continuity so that this could have been the "Year 2000 Event" that was spoken about in the DS games. 

By putting you in the shoes of the series long antagonist, Dracula, LoS is able to explore some interesting territory that no other Castlevania game has before or since (especially since Konami committed sudoku and jumped into only making Pachinko machines shortly after this was published). Like the fact that Castlevania itself is a living magical entity that draws you into itself so it can resurrect and drive Dracula into malevolence by dwelling on his pain. Or that, from Dracula's perspective, the Belmont line is a constant nuisance that gets in the way of his real enemy (Satan, again). 

Neat ideas. Also neat is that this game takes a stronger approach toward Metroidvania design in having interconnected worlds rather than just levels like the original LoS did. As you progress and get new abilities you unlock more pathways around these worlds and it's satisfying to open them up. Especially since both of them (the castle and the modern gothic city built on the castle's ruins) are gorgeous to look at. 

Oh, and like in the first LoS, the voice-acting is top-notch as they have some fantastic actors  putting in solid work here.

So what's the problem? 

Mostly it's that the combat, while still fundamentally good, gets pretty repetitive pretty quickly. Lots of enemies have built in defenses that can only be circumvented using the same tactic or move over and over, and these enemies respawn whenever you come back to an area after enough loading zones away so you'll be repeating lots of fights again and again as you traipse back and forth across the two worlds. 

At the same time, only a few of the boss fights in this game are any good, most of them early on in the adventure. The latter half of the game mostly doesn't have many good fights, which, since that's the focus of the LoS games, is a really big problem. On top of this, there's an incredibly underdeveloped and very punishing but not actually hard stealth system that makes sense at the start of the game when you're weak but none whatsoever by the end when you're stronger. It just gets annoying and tedious when you run into these segments later on, and it's not a good mix-up from the brawls.

Worse, the story gets dumber and more predictable as you progress, and end on sequel bait that we know will never get fulfilled at this point. It also feels really rushed in the latter half too, with a few major contrivances that pop up just to get everything to its conclusion that leave the impression that the devs ran out of time so had to tie a few threads together to finish the game by deadline. 

LoS 2 isn't afraid to get really weird and really dark at times. And in those moments it does, I can appreciate the boldness it takes in doing so. But it's also disjointed and tedious and I don't think the moments of delightful bizarreness it has will be enough for more than a few hardcore Castlevania fans to want to purchase it outright. 

If a really pretty, really gonzo Castlevania game sounds good to you, get this when it's on a steep sale one day. But if that's not you, you're pretty safe in just finding a playthrough online to watch somewhere.

[h1][i]"I was their most devoted warrior. A Champion of Light. But I fell. Fell into darkness, and now... I am feared as The Prince of Darkness. Ironic, don't you think?"[/i][/h1]
[i]Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2[/i] is a third-person action-adventure game and the final entry in the [i]Lords of Shadow[/i] series. You control Gabriel Belmont, who is now known as Dracula, and your main weapon is the Shadow Whip, which is very similar to the Combat Cross from past games. To fully understand Gabriel’s story and how he turned into Dracula, I highly recommend playing the first game before this one, and that you will be seeing familiar characters.

[h3]Pros[/h3]
✔️ Very good story with interesting side characters and well-made cutscenes.
✔️ Gabriel, the main protagonist, is interesting and likable.
✔️ Improved combat with more weapons and abilities to choose from.
✔️ Free-moving camera.
✔️ Challenging enemies and excellent boss fights.
✔️ The graphics look absolutely stunning.
✔️ Character models and facial expressions are improved and look great.
✔️ The game is well optimized.
✔️ Great soundtrack. 

[h3]Cons[/h3]
❌ Tedious stealth sections.
❌ Some pointless puzzles.
❌ Kill animations take too long and get repetitive.
❌ Some areas feel linear and claustrophobic.

[h1]Story[/h1]
Like in the first game, you control Gabriel - now known as Dracula, the Prince of Darkness -  and you wake up from a deep sleep, centuries later in your cathedral, which is located in present day Metropolis. You found out that Satan is returning to Earth and it is up to you, with the help of your former enemy Zobek (voiced by Sir Patrick Stewart), to stop and destroy him once and for all. 

It starts off with an excellent tutorial sequence and a very well-made intro that explains the events of the previous two games. The cutscenes are well directed and just fun to watch (with few awkward scenes here and there), and I enjoyed the banter between Gabriel and other characters. 

In the previous game, all the characters are interesting, mysterious and intriguing, and you will meet familiar ones from past games. Gabriel is more fleshed out and is very likable, as the story focuses more on him and his family. Overall, the story is far better in the previous games, with well-made cutscenes and very good plot twists that I didn’t see coming, and it kept me invested until the end. 

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
[u]Combat[/u]
Being Dracula now, your main weapon is the [b]Shadow Whip[/b], and it is pretty much the same as the Combat Cross so I felt right at home. The combat is more fast-paced and feels a lot smoother, you can now dash and leap during fights with more ease and greater accuracy, and you can drain the blood of your enemies to heal. Kill animations are back and they are varied from one enemy to another, but some take too long to finish and can get repetitive after a while. 

Instead of the medallions from the first game, two new weapons are added to your arsenal; the Void Sword that replenishes your health when attacking enemies and can freeze them for a short period of time, and Chaos Claws that inflict more damage and can break certain armors and shields. Both weapons have their own combos and abilities that you can unlock using points that you earn from killing enemies.
 
[u]Stealth[/u]
Probably the worst feature in the game. You will be doing some tedious stealth missions throughout the story, and hiding from certain security guards. Those stealth sections feel so out of place, since you, the almighty "Prince of Darkness", aren't able to kill those security guards even in the late game, but they can easily kill you with one or two hits.

[u]Enemies & Bosses[/u]
The enemies are diverse and challenging, even on normal difficulty, and you can sometimes see them fight each other in some parts of the world. Bosses aren't as frequent as in the first game, but they are epic and feel more cinematic, a huge step up from the previous games.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2129747647

[u]Puzzles[/u]
The puzzles are easy and less frequent, since the main focus is on combat and exploration. However, most of them, especially the stealth puzzles, feel unnecessary and a chore to go through; It is baffling to see Dracula defeating monsters twice his size, but struggling with locked doors or not able to go to the next floor of a building without doing certain puzzles.

[u]Difficulty[/u]
I played on the [b]Lords of Shadow[/b] (Hard) difficulty; the enemies and bosses are tougher and deal more damage but remain fair and balanced, as you will be using your abilities, weapons and combos that you learn to slay them and progress through the game.

[u]Other Changes[/u]
🌟 [b]Free-moving camera[/b] is used instead of the fixed camera like in the previous games, and it is a great change, since it enhances the exploration and combat.
🌟 [b]Platforming[/b] is better and faster-paced, as Gabriel moves much faster now.
🌟 [b]QTEs[/b] are back, but you can disable them in the game's settings and continue playing the game without them.
🌟 [b]Soldier’s scrolls[/b] are back but are called diaries and memorials instead. They only offer more lore of the world and the Belmonts instead of hints to solve certain puzzles.
🌟 The game constantly gives you hints (sometimes not even related to the gameplay, such as how to view artwork), so I recommend turning it off in the menu immediately.
🌟 There’s [b]New Game+[/b], and you can still keep playing the game even after defeating the final boss to improve and fully upgrade your abilities, if you want.

[h1]Graphics and Level Design[/h1]
The game looks beautiful; the character models and their facial expressions look more alive and detailed. The lighting is great, and some of the areas nailed it with the game's gothic atmosphere. However, the world is less vibrant and some areas feel narrow and claustrophobic, as you are almost always surrounded by buildings and walls. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2146572129

Contrary to the previous game, this one has no chapters or levels anymore; it is just one big non-linear open world with no loading screens during gameplay. There are a lot of secrets and upgrades to your abilities for you to find in this world, so keep your eyes peeled. 

[h1]Technical[/h1]

GTX 1070
Intel Core I7-7700HQ 2.80 Ghz
16 GB RAM
Windows 10 Home 64-bit[/quote]
The game worked well and ran beautifully. No issues to report.

[h1]Soundtrack[/h1]
The game has an orchestral and more cinematic style of music, compared to the previous ones; from a dark tone that represents the tragic Dracula’s origin story, to epic music during boss fights that make those battles more memorable and cinematic. The composer, Oscar Araujo, did a fantastic job with the game’s soundtrack, while sticking with the style and tone of the previous two games.

I enjoyed playing [i]Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2[/i] and had a lot of fun slaying enemies, but the new stealth sections, pointless puzzles and some dull locations held the game back for me. Regardless, I still recommend this game and it is still worth playing for its engaging story, fun combat and excellent soundtrack.

Oddly enough I hated the first Lords of Shadow and it took me two attempts at playing through the game to complete it after hating the original so much on Playstation 3 that I never played it again, and finally giving it another go on PC and finishing it because it has vampires in it and I'm a sucker for vampires. In any case, I expected to play Lords of Shadow 2 for an hour or two at most, quit, then write a review expounding upon how I hate it as much or more than the original. Much to my surprise, I could hardly put Lords of Shadow 2 down and regularly found myself staying up way later than I intended. A few things are the same as before, but others differ greatly.

You play as the same character as in the original game, though obviously he has some significant differences, considering the original game's ending. Although yes, my love of vampires made me interested in him this time around, I will say that the writing of the game fell flat on its face in one big aspect of the game. The protagonist seems to have a moderate bit of effort put into giving him a redemption arc. However, as a massive fan of redemption arcs in games, movies, and television, this one absolutely did not work for me. This is a very, very minor spoiler. Right after you start to play in modern times, you are given what appear to be a husband, a wife, and a female child to drink their blood until they're dead and you're rejuvenated. The husband hits you with a stick trying to protect his family, and you're about to die if you don't feed. I can fully understand the decision to kill the husband. However...your protagonist doesn't drink his blood. He just cuts the man's throat, lets him fall to the floor, and ignores his blood as it pours from his neck. Your character should be practically incapable of resisting drinking from him in this starved and desperate state. The woman and child are terrified, and your character proceeds to drink the woman dry, then he laughs in a sinister manner as he looks to attack the child. Cut to black and you do not see the child dying. Later, you see the family's corpses laid together in the small room.

Since we're playing as Dracula, that's fine to do something super evil...so long as they either don't try to redeem him - which doesn't work because they try to redeem him - or it's fine if they redeem him and the audience is given a scene where he laments the horrors he's committed and wishes to change. Needlessly killing more people than he needed to in that family and showing no remorse for it at any point throughout the entire game just does not work. He only shows any sympathy toward his family. Even the worst people in the world might be kind to their family members. In any case, they should've not bothered with a redemption arc, or drastically changed things concerning killing that family near the beginning if they wanted this to work right.

That flub aside, the game itself differs most from the original in that it is a Metroidvania. The first Lords of Shadow was a series of maps that acted as "levels" or "stages" more in line with the older Castlevania games than the newer stuff like Symphony of the Night. Although some folks may have liked the nostalgia aspect of it, and you could certainly select an old "mission" to go back through it again, I didn't enjoy that arrangement at all. Lords of Shadow 2 has intricate, interconnected city and castle areas with oodles of upgrades strewn about which you use your abilities to gain access to. I quite liked how this functioned and thanks to teleportation spots between areas, getting around was made a bit easier. Unfortunately, I found it difficult to remember which area connected to a different area, resulting in getting quite lost if I didn't have the map direct me to the nearest teleporter, resulting in me starting out in the same part of different areas each time almost exclusively.

Oh, and on the topic of upgrades you find throughout the game, there are a TON of them! If you keep your eyes peeled, you'll likely get enough upgrades that the game isn't very tough. By the end, I was stomping most enemies. I did go back and collect all of the ones I missed, though. One of my favorite features in Lords of Shadow 2 are Dodo Eggs, which you can buy in a shop and hatch, sending a Dodo to mark on your map where an upgrade is for a few minutes, along with an arrow on your map directing you in the direction to go to get it. Without it, I never would have found quite a few upgrades. There is a large amount of backtracking if you want to get all of the upgrades, but like I said, based my experience of the game from start to finish, completing the game at the normal difficulty isn't bad at all with a moderate amount of the upgrades. You get multiple full-heal items which you can pay to restock or find more of in broken objects, so the game is extremely fair when it comes to combat.

The story in general, other than the redemption arc, isn't anything amazing, but it works well enough. I think the lore you collect around the city in which this alternate history world is described where vampires are *known* by mankind to have existed and people do not doubt it, was really cool. I enjoyed reading through the various scrolls strewn about the place and the made the game world a much more interesting place to be in.

If you liked the original game and like Metroidvanias, I would think there's a good chance you would enjoy Lords of Shadow 2. If you're like me and hated the original game, you might *still* enjoy Lords of Shadow 2. I found it quite addicting exploring the castle and the city, and it's just interesting enough to keep me motivated from the gameplay and the lore.

[h1] Mediocre adventure game with perhaps a bit too much lore [/h1]

Castlevania, a game series that goes as far back as the flashing 1980s! Its lore is rich, the history deep. It's a mouthfull so to speak- even for those that has followed the game since its origins. I've finished [i] Lord of shadows [/i] 1 & its middleman [i] Mirror of fate [/i] which I feel is essential to have played to understand and to give a more proper description of the game as it's the very bone & flesh of Lord of shadows 2. 

[h1] So what do you actually do in Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2? [/h1]

You're in the shoes of Dracula himself as he appears in a weakened state. With alot of cinematics and questions- your mission is to regain your lost powers & abilities. The beginning of the game is quite comfy as the tutorials makes very well sure that you're ready to stand on your own before being released to mainstage.  

It has this nice touch to the game as you progress very... progessively? As you mindlessly rumble your way through waves of creatures you'll receive currency which is used to once again discover your lost combat arts. By the time youve learned your basic combat mechanics you'll receive new ones to learn so theres a consistent learning curve without necessary forgetting old mechanics or feeling that you're overencumbered with abilities.

As with any other games with (perhaps) too many combat abilities we usually end up spamming basic attacks or that one overpowerd ability (I sure am guilty). However, Lords of shadow 2 Though about this and added a Mastery rank to your weapon(s). To level up your mastery you'll have to practise every ability. This is a great feature to motivate you to have variety in your strategy.

[h1] Pros & Cons [/h1]

[list]
    [*] As we mentioned earlier; Its a lore rich game! If you havent played earlier Castlevania games esp. (Lords of Shadow 1) &
(Mirror of Fate) You will not understand much if anything at all which really takes alot from the game. Its like watching Marvel Endgame without watching the previous movies.

    [*] I really loved going through parts of the game which had resemblance from earlier games. Seeing how things had changed and the results of previous actions had given such results ect.

    [*] The game offers a new game+ with the new difficulty. This can be a huge pluss as it offers replay value- giving you more hours from your dollars. With the amount of secrets in the game its a great oppertunity to see if you caught them all and ofcourse challenge yourself.
[/list]

[h1] Conclusion. Should you buy Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2? [/h1]

Rush through the game ~10hours. Explore the game ~15 hours. completionist +20 hours. 

From personal experience I found 1 playthrough enough. It doesnt temp me to achieve completionist nor ng+. Because of this it doesn't hit "1 dollar an hour " which is another factor if you should invest or not. Havent followed the series much niether.

Thank you for reading my review of Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2.

69024365.review:
Castlevania LoS2 had a chance to be better than the first, but seems to have followed in the tradition of sequels being worst than the original.

The dual-plotlines that occur breaks the pacing of the game. Enemy variety boils down to humanoid with armor, humanoid with stick, humanoid with gun, humanoid that flies, or a combination of those. The combat has mediocre highs and very low lows.

Fresh off the heels of playing through LoS1, this game feels like a complete downgrade outside of the aesthetic. The world and models look amazing for their time and still hold up very well. (I've been playing on the Lord of Shadows difficulty, and played through LoS1 on Knight difficulty as the hardest was locked off.)

Dracula's Castle was probably the better part of the world in both looks and gameplay. 

The upgrade system from LoS got watered down immensely from a simple 'unlock combo, get a small upgrade' to a 'unlock combo, upgrade combo, master combo, transfer your mastery of combo into your weapon, your weapon is now the way it should be. Now rinse and repeat for your other two weapons.'

Combat got downgraded as well. While it and feels more fluid at first, the mask comes undone once you start fighting multiple enemies or multiple big enemies, and sometimes even bosses. Getting knocked down doesn't give you iframes like in LoS1, you're also susceptible to being hit while being knocked. This can lead to chained attacks killing you as you're locked into a spiral of being knocked around. Even your 'recovery' animation isn't safe as you can also be hit during that.

Parrying was well rewarded in the first LoS as you'd get some i-frames and knockback nearby enemies making is safe for you to follow up with your attacks. In LoS2 parrying can lead you into getting hit more often than not when in a situation where you're surrounded as none of these mechanics have followed over into the sequel. Enemies are more aggressive, as such when you being attacking an enemy, you'll have another monster attack you, you could parry that monster and the one you were attacking first will have recovered and made a swing at you, forcing you to dodge out of your supposed 'window of opportunity', or just take the hit.

There's so much wasted potential here, and the influence, or the lack thereof from Kojima can be seen and felt in LoS2's direction and design.

I cannot in good faith recommend this game to anyone outside of finishing this game just for the story on the lower settings as the higher settings will set you up for nothing but hair pulling frustrations in later segments. LoS2 also has slower load times when you fail, so yay for more waiting.

4/10, would not playthrough for a challenge.

Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2, is the sequel to the fantasy story that is Castlevania: Lords of Shadow, and continues that by turning into a horror story. The story takes place on Earth somewhere in the future. The universe is fictional with ties to folklore, mythology, and works of literature. The story is a continuation of the events that transpired in Transylvania, surrounding that stories' protagonist; Gabriel Belmont, but thousand years later.
After that ancient history, Gabriel's tale took an abominable turn. He lost his humanity after his victory over the vampire, and now reigns over them as the monster Dracula. Gabriel now exists as a vampire; immortal, and neither alive or dead. He retains his youth by drinking the blood of the living, and is now a supernatural creature, and behaves in an equally uncanny way.
While Earth's society developed towards a more modern age, Gabriel has remained detached from it. Gabriel's seclusion from society is soon discovered, as the vampire's master; Satan, is being summoned to Earth. Satan's homecoming is to be accompanied by an Armageddon.
Strengthened by his heritage, Gabriel must prevent the fallen angel's return, after a millennium.

The protagonist is displayed from a distance. It is possible to rotate this viewing-angle in all directions, while the protagonist remains at the centre. A map shows the general direction he has to follow, and visual hints point out the way forward.
The worlds show an environment, which is composed out of rooms and pathways, and in between more open areas. Some of these locations have multiple entrances and exits, and together they form a thematically connected world. These areas may be revisited, and artworks and background stories may be discovered by searching. The world is also interactable, and has destructible objects.
The protagonist runs, jumps, and climbs with superhuman agility through most environments, and between events, there are animated videos.
On occasion, groups of adversaries must be overcome through combat or stealth. Combat consists out of blocking, dodging, or attacking with a sword, whip, or claw. This requires timing. Each attack has defensive and offensive benefits, and there are consumables that may also help the protagonist survive these encounters. Larger, and more dangerous adversaries arise when the story unfolds. The protagonist's combat techniques increase during play, and may be customized.

At certain locations the protagonist may travel to his ancient castle. Which has a distinctive environment. There is a contrast between the modern environment, and the old castle. Floors, ceilings, and walls are often fashionable decorated and designed. The world use detailed textures and models, distinctive art-design, imposing architecture, and towering statues. This intertwining between old and new is enhanced by classical and modern music.

Looks like Michaelangelo, expects you to play like Da Vinci. 
Such a massive castle and beautifully rendered, would love to see it built in minecraft(yeah right!) and it starts getting destroyed early on in game and I just felt really bad, like as if it was my property. 
But Dracul doesn't care and should I?

Dracul has some major issues that only he can deal with and action this devious and confounding are reasons why there are turned based combat games, this is not. 
Frenetic fighting keeps the pace of the story at its threshold and enemies are powerful and come in unholy numbers. Defeat is the result of immature knowledge of the moveset, or maybe a bad camera angle, when Dracul gets ritually stun-locked and stomped.  It is so damn cool to go all out button mashing to start the attack and then finish off as you seem fit, feeling out what the next move in the combo should be to exploit the enemy's weakness, its never too easy and many encounters require the use of the new weapons in which there are a total of three. Even the harpies are a nuisance near the climax and we meet their kind early on.....It is tough and demanding of one's concentration and full of blood and gore. 

Yet there is the story and exploration that rages you on forward like a man possessed.
I cannot realize the amount of hate this game gets as it is seemingly what the fans cried for, a SoTN type adventure in 3D and it is here minus the massive amounts of equippable gear and enemies, it turns out to be much like  Devil May Cry 4, but here instead of [spoiler]going in reverse[/spoiler] it is more like cleaning up puke, no just kidding, areas are large and branch out  into multiple directions so that finding the extras and secrets are that much more demanding. 
Did I mention this all takes place in the past and the present? 

Dracula does not provide all the angst and voracity alone, a supporting cast plays their role in tune to the setting, but I noticed a hint of shallowness within him and that is keeping in mind his evil nature and impervious to anything attitude, it just  feels like he is still hungover from his centuries long slumber, a weakness?...maybe

Gone are the clever puzzles of the first game, I think they are relegated to the DLC with Alucard. Exploration and opening shortcuts is the name of this game, excellent level design and as a whole it is gratifying to have a working, controllable camera.

The symphonic/electronica music is superb and dynamic instead of continuous and that  part of the sound design is absolutely horrific, titanic and beyond reproach. The sound effects are awe inspiring, come together so covalently with the sound of the shadow whip and some  monster sounds are truly unreal in the state of being actually annoying to the ears. The acting is not as good or as present as in the first game but all the players return and make it a tour de force anyways. The lore is back and so is the writing, plus memorials to collect and read pertaining to the history of the city ironically glorified in propaganda-Does Dracul care? hell no, everything is deliberately designed to divert our well honed instincts and love for the series. Are you afraid to play as the bad guy?

53948528.review:
Ok, the first thing I want to say is, that I never played Castlevania before. I have no experience at all with the series and only bought the game for it's modern day setting. 

That said, Lords of Shadow 2 is awesome. It has a nice fighting mechanic, good looking enviorenments, great boss battles and the plot was fine to follow, even if you don't have any Castlevania knowledge. 

Now, as the game description says, Lords of Shadow 2 is a hack and slash game, where you take control of Dracula and after finishing a really well done tutorial mission, you awake in modern day Castlevania City. Stripped off your powers, you explore the city in a midst of a demon invasion to return to your former glory and to find a way to end Dracula's eternal life.

The game itself plays like most hack and slay games do. You have three weapons, your default whip, a Void sword which refills Dracula's health and firey Chaos gloves, which deal more damage and are the only way to break through shields and armor. All of them offer normal and crowd control attacks with the usually combos you expect from such a game, like throwing your enemy into the air, holding the attack botton for extra damage and to break your enemies blocking manouvers or to use spells, like creating a protective shield around you.

Unlike in Devil May Cry or Bayonetta though, the Sword and Gloves aren't always available, but require magic to wield. This can be aquired by either absorbing them from special statues or by performing combos. And here is the main difference to DMC or Bayonetta. Unlike in those games, the combo system isn't only there to look fancy or to gain a high score, but also allows you to refill your magic. With each hit you land, you fill up Dracula's focus, which, when fully filled, allows him to create blood spheres with each following hit. These spheres can then be absorbed to fill either your Void (The sowrd) or Chaos (The gloves) magic and a single hit from the enemy will break that focus.

Which is a good bridge to talk about the enemies themselves. The game has quite a good variety of them and range from easily killable knights, over demons of various sizes, skelletons, steam punk like riot police units and magic using priests. All of them with varying abilities to deflect your damage, block your attacks with shields or to simply dodge you. Now, with this game taking place in modern times, you won't only fight close quarter battles, although those are the majority, but also engage in ranged combat, like with the mentioned police force. 

Like with the melee enmies, you will encounter a good amount of different weapons here, including 60's styled assault rifles, shotguns and grenade launcher, while later in the game you will also face enemies throwing magical projectiles at you or wielding powerful single shot weapons in combination with rocket launchers and morters. These can be pretty annoying, because dodging bullets can be tricky, especially if multiple enemies are firering at you, and are an easy way for you to lose your focus.

An other annoying thing is, that the enemies shake your attacks off like they are nothing. They barely get staggered and can attack you back, even if you are in the middle of your own combo. This often makes it hard to see, if you are about to get hit. And while I like that the enemy's attacks are barely telegraphed, it makes the combat rather challenging and I got my butt handed to me pretty often, even by the default enemies. And although this sounds like a criticism now, it isn't and I actually liked the way how Lords of Shadow 2 handles it's combat.

Aside from your weapons, Dracula also has some other abilities, like turning into a rat or fiering ice, respectively explosive projectiles, as well as some charms to increase your combat performance. I just mention them, because they can be a bit finicky to control. I played with a gamepad, so all of those abilties were assigned to the D-pad and after selecting them, you also have to press he RT/R2 button to activate them. While this is mostly a case of getting used to it, it often happened in the middle of combat, that I forgot to change my ability before pressing the Use button, which sometimes resulted in wasted magic. Nothing big, but it can be annyoing.

Now, let's talk about Castlevania City a bit. I often read that the modern day parts of the game are grey in grey and optically quite boring, which is all true. But this didn't bother me and while I personally don't like the gothic architecture the developers went with, it still is an interesting place. If you have played any of the Batman Arkham games, be it City, Origins oder Knight, you know what to expect here. Much like Gotham, Castlevania City is a place, which looks like it got stuck in time at some point, with cobblestone sidewalks, interiours and cars that look more like they came from the 60's or 70's, narrow alleys and huge buildings, which are more resembling castle towers than modern skyscrapers.

It's dark, it's depressing, it makes me wonder why anyone would voluntarily live there, but it definitvely has a certain charme to it, which made me admire the city. I'm also a huge fan of supernatural stuff appearing in a modern day scenario and seeing some demons walking along some wrecked cars, while an advertising screen can be seen in the background, always puts a smile on my face.

Aside from the city, you also get to explore Dracula's castel and while you need to go there to progress the plot, you can freely switch between both places at certain points in the map. Which is partially required, because there are certain locks in the city, which can only be opened by keys aquirable in the castle. And unlike Castlevania City, the castle itself is more diversive, with the usual stone hallways, underground caves with lava or a snow area. It's also where most of the boss fights take place and all in all, it just has more going for it than the city.

For the final part of my review, I want to mention the stealth sections. Now, most of them are fine and it's not that hard to see, what the game wants you to do. But good grieve, the last two ones are very, very annoying, because you have no margin for error and in both cases, you take a pretty good hit on your health when getting spotted.

So, to end this: Castlevania Lords of Shadows 2 is a pretty good game and if you are a fan of games like Devil may Cry or Bayonetta, I would say give it a shot. It has nice combat, nice locations and the one or other special puzzle to offer a change of pace. You only need to aware of, that the combat can be challenging, that the stealth parts can be annoying and that the city levels aren't that unique in their appearance.

Rating: ★★★☆☆

(Pretty good DMC-like slasher)

============

Review:

Castlevania Lords of Shadow 2 is a 3rd-person action game that is very similar to Devil May Cry series.

Graphically it looks pretty good for a few years old game, at least when the high-resolution textures are on. It also runs smoothly even on older hardware. The music and sound effects are up to modern standards, they're good enough but nothing mind-blowing.

Story-wise its fine too, I really like the evil vs evil setting of the game. 

You play as Dracula, which is referred as the Prince of Darkness in the game. He's a very vengeful vampire that hates god and mankind - that itself creates a different kind of atmosphere for the game, as you're not some knight in shiny armor that saves the world.

Though, even as a bad-guy, you're supposed to kill Satan at the end of the game.. haha.

============

The game starts off bad, like really bad. It feels like a design flaw to me. You put a new player into a hellish jumping sequence right from the start, and it might be so frustrating that some new players will quit the game right there.

This negative feeling is further amplified by the fact that you'll be forced to do a stealth scene soon after that. Yes, it's short and will be over fairly soon, but the stealth stuff just isn't for everybody.

However, the game gets progressively better and better, if you can endure the crappy start.

There will be more annoying jumping, but you'll get used to it. It's not that much of a problem later, I just think it's brutal
that they put one of the most difficult jumping scenes right at the beginning of the game, when new players don't know how to jump properly.

============

Overall, I think the game is good. It's fun to play through once, and if you feel like it, you can go for the New Game Plus and collect achievements.

But honestly, I didn't want to play the game more after I finished the story. I really didn't want to plow through the same areas and try to find every secret.

So, is it worth buying? 

I think so. It's a good game, but it's nothing mind-blowing - so you probably should wait for a sale and get it cheap.

============

Summary:

The Good 👍
+ Still pretty good looking (with HD textures enabled)
+ Well optimized
+ Interesting story
+ You play as Dracula!

The Bad 👎
- Very poorly designed beginning
- Stealth parts feel rather forced

50110883.review:
Sometimes changing a games genre or style can completely reinvigorate a series, adding that little bit extra that makes a good series great. Super Mario’s bros is a good example of changing from a side scrolling series to 3D open world that ticks all the boxes and works really well. Other times ideas that look great on paper fail to wow in reality. Castlevania 2: Lords of Shadow is one of those games. You have a great story and lore to start from, excellent move list, good pacing, plenty of secrets and collectibles in a nod to the past games, along with good sound effects, big boss battles great voice acting and very decent platforming design. It should be a recipe for success, but it just doesn’t seem to come together as well as it should.

Castlevania 2 continues directly from Castlevania: The Mirror of Fate. You can play the game without playing the previous 2 games, but you would be doing yourself a massive disservice by doing so. If you haven’t played them and are thinking of playing this, stop and at least play the first Lord of Shadows game. After all these years, we finally get to play as Dracula. In a substantial plot twist from the previous games (I’ll get to that later) Gabriel has embraced his inner darkness (or is at least constantly at war with it) and in a climactic battle vs the brotherhood of light destroys their army to the last man, as well as his castle. 500 years later you awaken, weak and under assault by Satan’s minions who are trying to resurrect their lord since you are presumed dead. Having being the one who was ultimately responsible for all your grief in the previous two games it’s up to you to regain your powers and prepare to put him down for good this time if you can’t stop the resurrection. As gods chosen warrior.

Gameplay is the same as the previous game, with a lot of new twists. It is still a game of slowly unlocking abilities and powers, which in turn open up different areas in the world and your castle to explore. There are tons of collectables to find and some to purchase, with the crystals giving you holy/light and dark powers for every batch if five you collect. Light infused attacks still heal, while dark empowered attacks deal bonus damage, with your blood whip building a gauge to refill the power meters in combat. Combat is much the same with you using your unlocked abilities to kill enemies, with different attacks being required for different enemies. New to the series is the ability to fire your light and dark magic to freeze or set enemies on fire, opening up more combat opportunities. Attacks also generate mastery, which is used to empower your primary attack methods (whip, sword or gauntlets). There isn’t anything stopping you from using the same attacks, but you are now at least rewarded for using different attacks. Also new to the series are the dreaded stealth sections. Being a disempowered monster Dracula is required to transform into a pack of rats to bypass certain sections that are guarded by enemies that instantly kill you. They make sense story wise, but weren’t really fun to play, fortunately they are very infrequent and are only in certain parts of each map. I would have loved to be able to return to these areas post game and destroy these enemies, but that is denied to the player. It’s a missed opportunity to reward the player for continuing to play the post-game content. Some of these sections are also placed right before boss fights, [spoiler]and while the Camilla section isn’t so bad, I think the maze [/spoiler] happens to be one of the most infuriating sections of any game I have played.

The other major change is instead of set stages the game is a giant open world map, split into the present city, and your castle, which is incorporeal and based off your desire. The stage design really shines in the castle, it totally invokes flashbacks to the previous games. Quite a few familiar faces reappear, with a few known bosses returning. [spoiler] Being based on Gabriel’s desire it’s good to see him being able to interact with a young Trevor and his deceased wife to solve puzzles. [/spoiler] On the other side, the city you traverse looks ok, but misses the varied detail that the castle provides. There are plenty of varied environments, however the castle areas win out in my opinion. Both areas have hidden areas that require upgrades received effectively at the end of the game, so true to its nature there is a lot of back tracking in hunting down collectables. Smashing objects rewards you in either dropped items, experience point or artwork (which is cool to look through). I miss the front stage selection as it advised what secrets were left to collect in what area (and the item you get to help with this isn’t very good). You would bow need to play with a guide or have a photographic memory to find all the secrets. I highly recommend using a controller to play, while it is an option to play without one, it has been designed to play with one.

The voice acting is very good, with Dracula being the stand out. Patrick Stewart is back as Death, and I miss his opening speech to every stage. What small parts he does talk in don’t see to have that wow factor that they did in the first game. The enemy sound effects are good, though most of them are some form if grunt or screech (most if the enemies are possessed or animals). The background music was good, though nothing really stands out unless you are fighting the bosses, where it ramps up. The game looks great in 4K, and didn’t stress my computer that much.

The boss battles were pretty epic, with the first battle being a one of those fight where you have to work your way up the giant boss to kill it, before the second phase of the fight starts. The weakest boss fight would be the toy maker, who is a straight up brawl (and doesn’t actually pose much of threat). On easier difficulties the boss battles are very easy and forgiving, but require a degree if skill and memorization of their attack patterns. A fair few of them have a gimmick to you have to work out before you can beat them.

Now for my gripes- at least early on a lot if the story really glosses over the events of Mirror of Fate. I thought this was a major disservice to the trilogy, as Mirror of Fate had changed the events and understanding of characters significantly. Camilla’s portrayal is nothing like her previous incarnation. The plot overall is still serviceable, and it’s good to see Gabriel fighting the darkness in his blood (even if he forced to kill those who are corrupted by it). Another gripe is the item collection- in previous games you at least knew what stage it was in, but with the open world format this has been removed (even an icon when switching between area’s would have been handy). There’s nothing that allows you to mark secrets to revisit or anything that advises you what you have already collected, so there is a lot of un-necessary backtracking. Starting a new game + removes all your mastery and unlocks (you get the experience back to buy new skills), which is annoying as you have to farm enemies for the mastery levels again.

A lot if the DLC are costume changes for Dracula, which are nice but don’t really offer anything for the price that you get charged for them. One item allows you to switch excess items for others, which is highly recommended. 

The last DLC is for Alucard and sets up the events of the main game, but should only be played after finishing the main game otherwise it will ruin the twist at the end. The review can be found here https://steamcommunity.com/id/Carrionjr/recommended/273153?snr=1_5_9__402

If you are chasing 100% achievements then there is a lot to do. With collecting hidden items and farming enemies for mastery levels there is a fair amount to do and takes a fair amount of time depending on your skill level and how much you collected the first time around.

For more reviews please visit https://store.steampowered.com/curator/31327216/

This game fell somewhere between "equal to the first game" and "much better than the first game" for me, but that's comparing 
two games that I each liked a lot. I give it two thumbs up. I wish there'd be another one, but it seems like that won't happen. Two great feature-length games and one just okay handheld title -- not too shabby.

Things I loved: 
* Story and lore both continue to be engrossing
* Voice acting, memorable performances all-around
* Visuals (despite the purportedly boring city setting)
* Not too easy, not too difficult (for ME, big asterisk on that one since admittedly I am decidedly average skill-wise compared to most hardcore gamers)
* Amazing opening chapter
* Lots of secrets to find
* Art direction (for the extras and the lore entries, and overall) is to die for
* Takes inspiration from real life without being too heavy-handed and preaching to you, which is super rare these days and something I greatly appreciate

Things I liked:
* Combat is fun and easy to pick up on
* Lots of abilities to unlock
* Just long enough length-wise
* Reserved but well-done take on "open world" structure
* Mostly ran perfectly, except for a couple times when I crashed apropos of nothing

Things I didn't like: 
* No lock-on during combat,; even if you don't really NEED it, it'd be nice to have
* A few moments where the camera hinders you in combat; one sequence near the end nearly got me killed because I just couldn't see the enemies off-screen
* The reason behind some things that happen in the moment-to-moment plot could be a little clearer, or alternatively a little less convenient. Question: "Why did that happen?" Answer: "I dunno, roll with it."
* Ran out of consumables that I very much needed near the end, but whether that's a good thing or bad is up to you ultimately
* A pointless death in the story that seemed like it could have been avoided somehow, but hey, what do I know
* I didn't use all the consumables, and furthermore, skills, that were available to me. Maybe that's a fault of my own and thus you can ignore me here, but there were some elements of the combat that went unused for a majority of the game.

Interesting observations:
* The stealth sections aren't as bad as I'd been led to believe. What I'd heard made it sound like it overwhelmed the entire game, kinda like how I'd also heard the city setting also brought the game down, but neither of those things were true for me. There's actually only ONE stealth section that really got my goat, and even though it was blissfully short, it still pissed me off because of how hard it was. So overall, not that bad, if you ask me. One or a couple frustrating sequences does not a bad game make.
* When some people called this game an 'open-world' game, I expected something a little different. But I like what this game offers in terms of world structure, even if the world structure doesn't always make sense (ex: you can't jump over this barrier that anyone could easily get over). It's an open-world in a very structured way. It's an interesting variation on exploration in games, I'll give it that. In a way, it fits right in with the Metroidvania genre; I would love to see more games made in this format, not every game needs to be a LOTR-sized adventure.
* The Transmutation Rune (available in the DLC) is something I'd like to see more of in games. It gives you the freedom to trade in consumables you don't need for ones that you do. Extremely useful!

Tras terminar el juego principal en la máxima dificultad posible en la primera pasada, me siento obligado a escribir esta reseña para hacerle justicia a esta obra. Y digo justicia porque creo que la crítica y el público han sido muy injustos con este título, hasta el punto de que ahora mismo creo que se tuvo que tratar de alguna especie de campaña de desprestigio (no es la primera vez que a Mercury Steam le ocurre, ya pasó con Blade), y es que recuerdo que se habló de que el juego estaba roto, que era un desastre e incluso de que Enric Álvarez se había convertido en una especie de megalómano cuyas ideas habían arruinado el juego. Auténticas barbaridades a tenor de lo que luego te encuentras mientras juegas. Y lo que te encuentras mientras juegas es un título muy notable en todos los aspectos.

El primer Lords of Shadow fue encumbrado por la crítica, con razón, pero ¿entonces qué ha pasado con esta segunda parte? Ambos juegos cambian radicalmente su ambientación y su tono, por exigencias de guión, uno es colorido y variado en paisajes, el otro es oscuro y centrado en un único lugar (dos si tenemos en cuenta que podremos recorrerlo en dos épocas distintas). El primero es un título lineal y con cámara fija, el segundo tiene un desarrollo metroidvania, con backtracking y con cámara libre. El combate de la primera parte es muy notable y divertido, el del segundo es igual pero añadiendo más profundidad con los distintos tipos de armas, tanto la espada, que servirá para recuperar vida y las garras, imprescindibles para romper armaduras. La música es igual de excelsa, pero la de este título es más oscura, acorde al tono general. Y la historia es entretenida y con muchos claroscuros en las emociones de Drácula, con su lucha interna entre su maldad y sus sentimientos hacia su familia, con momentos igual de épicos que la primera parte. Ya podréis intuir que los cambios no son precisamente a peor, sino en general, a mejor. Por eso no se entiende por qué el primero fue tan ensalzado, y este tan vapuleado.

Los tan polémicos añadidos en forma de fases de sigilo son aceptables y lo único que le añaden al juego son más mecánicas. Te pueden gustar más o menos, pero ni están rotas ni funcionan mal. Y hay que tener en cuenta que estamos hablando de un Drácula debilitado en sus poderes, por lo que están justificados estos momentos en los que tiene que renunciar al enfrentamiento directo. No son muy abundantes y eso, añaden variedad, algo imprescindible en una buena aventura.

Mención especial merece el arte del juego. Castlevania es una franquicia japonesa, pero su ambientación y su contexto están más inmersos en la historia y la iconografía europeas. Si a eso le añades todo el componente religioso, concretamente con imaginería católica, creo que se hace obvio que un estudio europeo y español, tiene mucho más que aportar que uno japonés. Y aquí Mercury Steam se desata con un nivel artístico inconmensurable. Me he tenido que detener múltiples veces a admirar cada estatua, cada textura de las paredes y del suelo, y es que el detallismo es impresionante. 

En fin, un gran juego y un gran representante del hack and slash, como lo fue el primero y que te hace apenarte por el trato que recibió y que llevó a Mercury Steam donde está ahora. La última frase del juego  "¿Quién sabe lo que nos deparará el futuro?" es profética. Ojalá alguien vuelva a confiar un gran proyecto a este estudio que debería estar mucho más reconocido. Es de justicia.

47175707.review:
Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 is the definition of average. For every good thing, there is a bad thing and a lot of average stuff sprinkled inbetween.

The game is set a long time after the first game; Gabriel is now Dracula, Satan threatens to return, so we gotta beat up his Acolytes. The story is both straightforward and needlessly convoluted in places, which sometimes makes it hard to follow. The general thread of chasing Satan and his acolytes is always visible though, so it never devolves into utter confusion.

To bring Satan to his knees, you'll go on an ~20 hour adventure with good, bad and average parts. Best to list them seperately:

[b] Good [/b]

- The game looks nice and runs very well. It's not a graphical masterpiece, but it works and runs fast and fluid with no slowdowns.

- The music is great; it's set in the background in a way that doesn't make it annoying, but it steps forward in just the right moments.

- Great voice acting, cool included collectible artwork and amazing designs. Everything just looks cool, from Dracula himself to the mobs and boss enemies.

[b] Average [/b]

- The active battle system is serviceable, but really nothing special. You have 3 weapons, each with very few distinctive skills. The rest of the skills are essentially the same for all the weapons (they all have an air attack, AOE attack etc.) which can make combat monotonous.

- The collectibles are scattered everywhere and are somewhat frustrating to get to. Due to the world being split into two parts you can only travel between at certain spots, as well as some collectibles only being accessible with dungeon keys you can carry a maximum of 3 of, you'll do a lot of backtracking and pointless walking whenever you need to refill keys or obtain a new ability. They aren't quite optional either since they increase your maximum life or weapon energy.

- While the bosses have great designs, most of the fights are nothing special and too easy even on the hardest difficulty. The annoyance of enemies stems more from the unreliable dodge of Dracula, rather than their strength or difficulty.

[b] Bad [/b]

- The game has a few stealth sections that range from okay to utterly frustrating. The mechanics are half baked, you often get spotted for no reason and sometimes it's not clear how to proceed. Especially as you near the end and are really strong, one questions the need of stealth sections at that point...yet there's still one or two short before the end of the game.

- The game has a number of optional unlockable challenge battles. Those range from fun to very frustrating, and some are borderline impossible to complete with all emblems. Emblems only unlock when you fulfill a specific condition in that battle - like, defeat enemies without breaking their shields. Some of those emblems are extremely frustrating to get and require you to do some very strange "gameplay acrobatics", almost breaking the game in unintended ways. Also, they serve absolutely no purpose - there isn't even an achievement for getting all of them.

- The world is bland. All game, you are either in dark city, or dark castle. The first game had forests, snow landscapes and generally varying enviroments. That's all gone here and it's a sad sin. There are only three areas that stand out, but all of those are very short and don't even take up 10 % of the total game area.

- The open world structure of the game isn't thought out very well. Fast travel is only useable at a few certain points, there is no bigger map; that means you essentially have to memorize all the paths and shortcuts, or else you won't know how to get to a specific landmark or area. Generally, the map feature in this game is pretty useless.


As you can see, this game is very average. Great designs, music and characters meet okay gameplay and some questionable design choices. It's definitely not an awful game, and I wouldn't quite call it bad; but the first one was definitely a step above. Get it on sale, or if you liked the first game and want to play the sequel.

I'd give it an average 5.5/10.
