To start, Lament of Innocence is safe in its spot as the best 3D Castlevania game. LoS2 is really not a Castlevania game, but it is a decent gothic adventure game- it's bigger and more polished than I expected- it can be really a gorgeous game at times with a fantastic art style, and the controls feel good. And I like Robert Carlyle's performance as Gabriel. 

What really lets it down are some bad gameplay choices, particularly the stealth sections- they have no place in this game, and are easily the most tedious, frustrating parts...I absolutely hated the encounter with Agreus for example, and almost considered giving up on the game at that point. Some of the puzzles and platforming are very questionable as well.

Another big issue is the extremely poor map system- it makes trying to figure out how to get somewhere such a pain that I didn't bother going back for many of the upgrades I could have gotten...the 2D Castlevanias always had great, clear maps that made the world feel connected- the map system in this game makes things feel disjointed and confusing, and really discourages exploration. I used to like backtracking in the older games because I knew where everything was by looking at the map- this game forces you to try to remember where something is in a lot of same-y environments, and that is not fun...it's a frustrating waste of my time. The save system is problematic as well...I always had to hope when I quit I wouldn't have to replay very much of what I just did...I just can't understand why so many modern games lack a manual save, or save and quit option.

Not a plus or minus really, but the game is very dark- it takes place entirely at night, in a sunless, completely man made world...there are no organic, natural environments to speak of (with the exception of one very small area), which I find unfortunate. The game is set entirely within Dracula's castle complex, in both modern and ancient times, for good or bad- many of the "modern" areas look like generic backgrounds from a thousands other games, but the when you shift back in time, it is far more interesting- the gothic architecture and art are stunning. I can't say I care much for any of the music in the Lords of Shadow games...I find most of it to be boring and generic, and a poor showing for a series known for such iconic music.

Mercury Steam's Castlevanias are not true Castlevania games in my opinion, and I would have liked them more if they were their own original games without the Castlevania name attached at all. People have expectations when you put Castlevania in the title, and while not bad games (the first LoS game was quite good, but was more God of War than Castlevania), the Lords of Shadow games just don't live up to the name or legacy. I wish Konami would see the error of its ways and bring back IGA and the Symphony of the Night team for a new entry, but sadly it will never happen.

En primer lugar los gráficos si bien no son muy punteros y al, evidentemente, tener que jugar por la noche, no destacan especialmente los escenarios, ninguno, siendo quizás el castillo lo más destacable. Los modelos de los personajes si que se ven claramente mejores que los de la primera entrega, pero lo demás pasa bastante desapercibido.

El diseño de niveles es regulero y es una lástima que se haya cambiado el diseño por capítulos por el intento de "sandbox" por así decirlo, que es esta nueva entrega. El hecho de tener que volver a visitar escenarios para desbloqueables sería un aliciente para el nuevo juego +, pero al no contar con las habilidades necesarias, que se pierden al empezar de nuevo, pierde cualquier incentivo. 

Las habilidades no son nada del otro mundo, y una de las que más se echa en falta es el doble salto, que se consigue hacia el final de la aventura lo que es un desperdicio. La niebla fundamentalmente sirve para revisitar escenarios y algo para el sigilo.

El sigilo es una novedad jugable en esta entrega y es totalmente innecesaria dado que en un hack n slash el sigilo suena a chiste (más siendo el personaje todopoderoso que es en teoría Dracula). El sigilo es muy monótono y aburrido y cada fase con este estilo fracasa, particularmente el sigilo en el castillo es bastante más llevadero que en el mundo "actual".

El juego se divide en dos escenarios, castillo y ciudad, el primero es más clásico y realmente funciona bastante mejor que el segundo, no necesariamente porque pegue más o menos, quizás mejor llevado podría haber sido más entretenido, pero la ciudad realmente es peor que las fases en el castillo.

El combate tiene poco que destacar y aun para el genero el juego es bastante escaso, teniendo tan solo tres armas, una que recupera vida, otra que rompe defensas, y la estándar. Otros juegos introducen demasiadas armas que al final no acabas usando pero en Lords of Shadow 2 pasa al otro extremo dándote lo justo. El juego cuenta además con una mecánica de bloqueo que en la dificultad normal por lo menos puedes pasar completamente de ella sin ningún problema, tampoco es que se recompense demasiado al jugador por bloquear ya sea dicho...

La historia no está mal aunque el giro argumental más o menos te lo esperes y el hecho de llevar a Drácula es un buen incentivo para estar interesado, aunque la impresión final es la de haber desaprovechado la ocasión, tanto la de controlar a Drácula como la de la ambientación moderna. Por otro lado el desenlace del juego es soso siendo muy generesos. Ni cierra la historia ni es la mitad de épico que el primer juego.

Es una pena que toda la trama intermedia entre el primer Lords of Shadow y este se perdiera en Mirror of Fate, pudiendo haberse aprovechado y explotado mucho más en una entrega "principal". Sin duda la primera entrega por sí sola es un mejor producto en cuanto a nivel de argumento y narración. Aunque también se fallaba al no contar con escenas cinemáticas y optar por estética cómic para terminar la historia que por otro lado era fantástica y la pega la tenía en como se mostraba.

Los jefes finales, tanto en el juego principal como en el DLC, vuelven a caer en el pico de dificultad absurdo y son batallas ciertamente malogradas, poco variadas y decepcionantes. Sin embargo el juego no es un desastre respecto a este apartado y hay algún que otro jefe que si que realmente merece la pena aunque no tienen el toque que tenian los jefes del primer juego, tanto en trasfondo como en variedad de mecánicas etc. Una verdadera pena que el jefe final no esté a la altura de lo que tendría que ser el desenlace de la aventura. A pesa de todo el jefe se acaba despachando con un poco de paciencia, no por lo que tarda sino por lo aburrido que es, ataques inbloqueables todo el rato, aprovechas el hueco y atacas (dos veces como mucho) y venga otra vez. Mención especial al destrozo que le hacen a Satán en cuanto al diseño, aunque el primero no era un diseño espectacular, el segundo Satán es ciertamente más feo que el primero y queda extravagante. 

Esta extravagancia se repite en los enemigos normales que abundan por la ciudad que son una especie de mutados raros. Ciertamente el juego cuenta con poca variedad de enemigos pero tampoco es drámatico, simplemente lo hace más mónotono. Su diseño tampoco es llamativo y en la segunda mitad del juego aumenta algo la variedad (en general el último tercio del juego es bastante mejor y más entretenido).

El juego en general carece de dificultad si cuentas con las reliquias y si mueres alguna vez será por un despiste puntual de querer ahorrar reliquias (aunque ni haga falta y sea más por costumbre de otros juegos). El tema de las reliquias y que se puedan además transmutar es un fallo de diseño y debería haberse equilibrado para evitarlo.

La duración es aceptable e incluso un poco menos no hubiera estado mal, recortando las fases de sigilo el juego hubiera sido más redondo. El DLC lleva mejor este aspecto siendo más entretenido y ágil, un acierto lo del teletransporte mediante murciélagos en ciertas posiciones. Tiene puzzles un solo jefe eso sí (dos quizá pero realmente el jefe es el final) y una dosis de plataformas mejor llevadas que en la historia principal, quizás el fallo aquí es el personaje que es más soso que Drácula pero en general el DLC es un buen producto, aunque corto.

El doblaje por otro lado es decente y la voz de Drácula la pone Robert Carlyle que lo hace francamente bien y le da el tono adecuado al personaje.

En líneas generales se podría decir que Lords of Shadow 2 es peor que su predecesor, innovando de manera equivocada y con pocas mejoras, pero todo esto no lo hace un mal juego. En general el juego es entretenido aunque tenga sus momentos más aburridos y el combate sin ser satisfactorio no es injugable, solo en ciertos momentos la cámara no actúa correctamente, pero por lo demás es de suficiente. Y es que el juego no llega al notable por poco pero de manera clara, es peor que el anterior, innova de mala manera y el final encima no da el cierre que se merece. Lamentablemente si te gusta la saga probablemente te decepcione pero como videojuego es un producto de suficiente alto que podría haber llegado al notable poniéndole más esfuerzo.

This installment of the classic Castlevania series developed by the spainish studio MercurySteam can only be described as okay, or decent given the smaller size of the team that worked on it-which is unfortunate, given its nice character design and iconic characters.

The game is split into two parts, with the ability to travel back and forth between the two-Dracula's sprawling castle in the dark gothic period the first LoS was set in and "modern times (90s/2000s)" urban city that was built on the grounds 500 years later. 

As many have pointed out, the art direction in this game is A+, its great stuff and the collectible concept art pieces add to that as well. My critique on that area would maybe be that the modern urban design felt slightly uninspired, the castle itself is gorgeously done-no complaints there. The character and enemy visual designs were also well done. 

Gameplay wise however, the game falls a little flat. Combat had a lot of potential, with a good amount of movesets and combo chaining opportunity-which is one of the reason it is often compared to Devil May Cry. However it fell short of what it could have been-unless playing on easy mode, filling up the power bars to utilize these moveset abilities other than the bloodwhip can be a pain.  Enemies feel repetive and more an impediment than an enjoyment to smash through.

Boss fights in this game can be described as uninspired, which is a shame-as I mentioned, they are well designed visually. Most of these consist of using an ability to get past the boss's mechanic and beating on the boss, then repeating the same-sometimes with a God Of War like QTE type prompt to execute a move. 

Level design aside from visuals, often just has you running from one zone to another and climbing around in mechanics inspired by assassins creed to reach your goal. This is often accompanied by  having to turn on a switch which turns on power to get to the objective-which would be fine, if it wasn't beaten to death as a mechanic on EVERY zone on the city area. 
Aside from the climbing and turning on power-level design suffers from poor telegraphing, with most of the poorly executed "stealth" sections giving little to no indication of how to solve them. one egregious example is one where Dracula must use his mistform ability to pass thru an enemy-a mechanic that is never used or introduced before this part. I was confused for a good while on this part as an elevator door kept opening when I did a certain action which wasn't my goal or part of the area's mechanics toward objective. 

the best part of the game for me was the Toy Maker boss, both in design and his story, it was the only one that really shone out in the game tbh.

Extras-doing a completionist run on this game is a time consumption and generally not worth while for the reward. With most of the collectibles (power pool upgrades and XP boosts-oh as well as unlocks for challenge [arena] mode) being in clear view and tauntingly just out of reach-they only become obtainable once you unlock an ability to reach them. This requires a lot of backtracking, which becomes a pain because that means hitting those switches again and zoneing from one to another, thru the wolf doors that take you between the castle/city traversing through zones again and then having to clear the respawned enemies.

La saga lords of shadow se cierra con un juego que recoge al mismo tiempo los mejores y los peores aspectos encontrados en la misma.

El hecho de que el personaje principal sea un antiheroe tan multidimensional le da un morbo constante que es imposible de ignorar. El final me parece lamentable, el combate final poco epico y no es que deje la historia en un cliffhanger, sino que directamente, salen los personajes y dicen "ale aparcao" y entran los creditos.


Al desarrollarse la historia en el futuro, uno empieza temiendo que desaparezca el castillo, elemento importante en castlevania, pero se lo consiguen montar para que la mitad del juego se desarrolle en el, no dire mas para no desvelar sorpresas. El combate sin embargo es una delicia, añaden unos pocos elementos rpg y en general es mucho mas fluido y controlable, poco que criticar aqui.

41935019.review:
Castlevania:Lords of Shadow 2 is a Hack'n Slash game made by Mercury Steam and published by Konami with help of Kojima Productions in 2014 on PC, Xbox 360 and Playstation 3. It is a sequel to the series reboot Castlevania:Lords of Shadow from 2010.

Story takes place few days after post-credits scene in Lords of Shadow and few centuries after Mirror of Fate, Gabriel Belmont known now as Dracula hides from world in his isolation, resulting in his lack of power. Tired of his immortality he decides to help his former enemy Zobek to stop Satan from returning to human world. To do so first he must regain his powers, then eliminate all the Acolytes hiding in Castlevania City. Through the journey our protagonist also must survive his inner battle to preserve his human emotions. Overally the story is darker than in first game, not really better but definetely not terrible either.
Gameplay has been much improved since Lords of Shadow 1, we still proceed through locations by walking, climbing and acquiring skills to backtrack and get previously unavailable upgrades, BUT now the camera is not locked, which was the biggest issue of the first game. The new issue however are stealth sections that were executed really poorely. Fighting has been divided to 3 styles, default is focused on Shadow Whip and is preety similar to what we saw in original LoS, switching to Void Sword and Chaos Claws changes the fighting completely, both cannot be held forever cause they are limited by amount of magic in Void and Chaos gauges that can be replenished by dealing damage to enemies flawlessly (using Whip only). Sword heals you while damaging opponents, but Claws increase the damage and allow to break shields. Every style might be upgraded by spending earned money in menu, there is also skill mastery level that increase while using those skills. I have got to admit that combat here is real fun (Take that haters).
Through ths game we will encounter 2 types of locations, mostly you will spend time in modern places, that (let us be honest about this) suck, too simple similar places filled with same boring climate. On the other hand we also have visions, where we enter gorgeusly made castle full of unique atmosphere and colorful rooms.
Soundtrack is good, but would be even better if it had some trafitional rock sounds.

Well, yes, the game has many drawbacks but thanks to enjoyable gameplay, good plot and quite nice boss fights it stands as a criminally underrated Slasher definetely deserving more attention. It is not as good as the first Lords of Shadow, not even as good as Symphony of the Night but definetely worth playing, 7,2/10.

While this one gets a lot of bash from apparently everyone, most of it is not truly justified. Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 is a vast improvement from its predecessor, and while it tries a few new things that don't quite work out, the majority of the experience is truly worth at least one playthrough.

[h1] Pros [/h1]
[list]
    [*]-Breathtaking graphics combined with breathtaking art direction make this one of the most beautiful games I've ever played. Every different place you go and enemy you meet is just a pleasure to look at.
    [*]-Combat is improved from the first game, being tighter and bringing more variety both to weapons and moveset. It still leaves some to be desired, especially when compared to the likes of Devil May Cry, but it's a fun combat nonetheless and it gets the job done without major concerns.
    [*]-Plot is very nice. Very dark and personal. It's interesting in the beggining and throughout the game, and the twists and turns are really some masterful plays.
    [*]-Probably the most interesting depiction of Dracula, ever.
    [*]-Voice acting is very nice. Also improved from the first game. Dracula's performance in particular stands out.
    [*]-Chupacabras are no longer the rage inducing insects they once were in the first game.
    [*]-Characters look amazing. Playing with Dracula is that much more fun because he looks awesome.
    [*]-Varied environments, each one hand crafted to perfection. Everything is fun to walk around and explore.
    [*]-Platforming is improved from the first game and it feels very tight and responsive. Visual cues are key for this in this game, and they are used very cleverly when it comes to platforming here.
    [*]-Seamless journey through the environments makes this feel like a really tight and nicely packaged experience. Gone are the days of level selecting. The game is not exactly open-world, but everything is well connected and you are free to come and go as you please.
    [*]-THE best vampire scene in any game ever made. Not only that, but vampires are brought back to what they once were in this game: the terrifying blood-sucking beasts of our nightmares.
    [*]-Option to play without quicktime events.
    [*]-Nicely optimized.
    [*]-Very small download and install size (around ~5gb).
[/list]


[h1] Neutral [/h1]
[list]
    [*]-This game could have some really nice Steam backgrounds and badges, but it doesn't have cards, unfortunately.
    [*]-Music is ok. Nothing memorable, but it gets the job done.
[/list]

[h1] Cons [/h1]
[list]
    [*]-Every button prompt in the game appears as Xbox buttons, even if you have no controller plugged in. This is a real shame bacause, other than that, the port is excellent.
    [*]-Stealth sections. Yes, Dracula needs to resort to stealth a couple of times in this game. As you'd expect, they suck.
    [*]-Armored robot enemies are ridiculous to fight against. They also keep shooting at you with machine guns, making the fight even more dreadful.
    [*]-Sprint mechanic remains from the first game. However, the game doesn't even teach you about sprinting, and every time you sprint you only do it for three steps. There's no bonus to be gained from it whatsoever, like longer jump or anything like that (contrary to the first game where sprinting was a key mechanic). It really feels like they forgot to remove it.
    [*]-Somewhat lackluster final boss fight.
    [*]-Trasversing through environments can be a chore, because a lot of times you are forced to do things such as pulling levers and then waiting for the door to open, or cross a bridge where the character forcefully starts to walk instead of running, this type of thing. It could use a little more polish to make everything run more smoothly. This is especially a problem when you're backtracking, even more so because the game puts a lot of its collectibles in unreachable parts of the world, making you come back later when you have the required ability if you want to collect everything.
[/list]

Castlevania Lords of Shadows 2: a good game with some flaws but plenty enjoyable.          

I played the game first time directly on hard difficulty (cause like the previous Lords of Shadows, easy and normal are just way too easy) and the challenges directly on Prince of Darkness (super hard) difficulty. 

Pros: 
- Controls are smooth; yes, even if the cam is only player controlled it's barely needed to be considered (outside some challenges and one boss fight were you need to aim your target to throw daggers at it).      
- The mastery system for the weapon feels good and effective and offer a good way to incentive in using all weapons instead of focusing on just the basic one; you don't need to grind if you look around for secrets (the casual fights will supply it plenty) and use the hourglass consumable you loot.               
- The artwork is great, especially the castle which is amazing (the city feels much more plain but it's understandable).         
- Boss are fun and enjoyable (all feels different and uniques on their own).             
- The secret hunt is fun and enjoyable overall and the consumable for it ensure you aren't forced to use a guide for them (but obviously you still need all your powers to get all of them which means visiting multiple times or just one single big raid before the final battle... Or right after it since you can explore as long as you want before starting new game+ from the menu)
- Good soundtrack, never got bored of it.             
- The bundle DLC skins are good, a little annoying that they don't use the same location to chose both (one in the additional content like a DLC, the other instead is in the ingame option) and that you have to select it again every time you launch the game.

Cons:           
- The stealth parts (especially the one in advanced point of the story) are damn boring and are easily the worst part in the game period.       
- The story feels quite weak and after the prologue it doesn't feel like using Dracula but simply Gabriel Belmont with vampiric powers (it really lack the villain feeling that being Dracula should provide).                    
- The boss are way too easy to defeat; for someone playing on hard they never felt a challenge or a problem, kinda let down of their boss status (and having an healing consumable lower even more their difficulty... ).              
- 1 consumable is straight useless (the weapon mastery one), the unlimited magic is needed only to close some challenges on Prince of Darkness without going mad.          

Relevation DLC: Good DLC, worth the price. Using Alucard is definitely fun and the powers are well diversified from Dracula, it truly feels like a different character while having the same combat system. [b] Play it AFTER the main game story or you will suffer massive spoilers! [/b]                       

Conclusion: A very good Hack and Slash that provide a decent Castlevania feeling (especially in the castle) in a 3D form and an enjoyable game experience. 
7/10 Fully worth the bundle price.

[b]Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2[/b] mixes parts of previous two games. It tries to be story-oriented game and open-worldish RPG-Metroidvania, but it doesn't mix well. 

The pacing is a mess. Story goes like this: you are awoken after hundreds of years since the last game and have to stop Satan's acolytes before they summoned their lord. The plot implies that you have limited time and have to act fast, but the gameplay dissolves all the tension the story creates. There's a lot of backtracking and climbing which will get annoying very fast. There is a fast-travel system, but there aren't that many points you can travel to and it requires watching painfully slow animations every time you use it. I guess they tried to hide loading screen with this, but somehow I feel more comfortable with regular loading screens than with these pointless cutscenes.

Gameplay is much better than the previous two games, there are more combos and upgrades. As in the previous Castlevania games you can buy combos with experience points you earn from killing your enemies or searching for secrets. This game introduces new aspect to this system - weapon mastery level. When you use your combos in battle you become more skilled and deadly. The combo can only generate fixed amount of these mastery points, so the game forces you to use different combos to upgrade your weapons. Another new addition to combat system is artifacts, those are items you can use in combat to make your enemies slower, to refill your health and magic meters, etc. Magic system also endured some changes, now each magic associated with its weapon, blue magic - sword, red magic - burning gloves. These weapons fill quite different than standard whip and have its own combos. 

Even though the game takes place in modern times, you'll still visit ancient castles and dungeons. The world is beautifully crafted, this time not only artistically, technical side is far superior than that of the predecessors. As a result game plays much smoother than previous one and has more cinematic look. Voice acting is fine, Patrick Stewart and Robert Carlyle return to reprise their roles as Zobek and Dracula respectively. But without narration by Stewart it doesn't feel quite as good as in first one. Soundtrack is ok, its there but you probably won't notice it for the most time.

[b]Pros[/b]: 
- Well-designed combat system
- Epic boss battles
- Engaging story
- Good level-design 
- Great voice acting

[b]Cons[/b]:
- No fun to get around open world
- Awful stealth

It is tough to decide wether to recommend this game. I'd say this one has the best combat system in the whole series, but the other parts of the game just mediocre. There's also a couple of stealth segments, which are just as awful as DLC boss in the first game. Get it, if you can put up with some bad game design choices and enjoy the action-filled story with beautifully looking locations.

39802000.review:
This game is an improvement from its predecessor in many ways: the gameplay is more intuitive, the setpieces are more dynamic, the art direction as a whole seemed more unique and fleshed out. However, many problems still remain, problems that lie far deeper than any gameplay or environment improvements could improve. For one, I'm certain the dialogue is written by high school students, and the untalented ones at that (maybe they were trying to be campy, I dunno). The lead character is badass for about an hour before he turns into an adult with teen angst. In fact, most of the characters come off as fragile, in a way that makes you wonder how the writers who were so obviously attempting badassery fell so far off the mark. Plus, at no point did I actually feel anything for any of the characters: the emotions are so forced it's like you walked into a soap opera mid season. The drama lacked context. As for the story, it often tries to pull off the ol' "JRPGs: plotholes are a feature" trick where you raise your eyebrows but quickly decide not to pursue the inconsistencies because the game's fun enough to ignore them. However, this game does not have the charm nor the wit to go about that and the plotholes metastasize on the narrative. 

Some of the boss fights are pretty cool! Others are pretty lame. 

Elephant in the room? It's a God of War knock-off. No, not every hack-and-slash is a GoW knock-off, but this game and its predecessor are quite obvious about it. And it's a bad knock-off at that! The people who developed this clearly missed much of what made God of War so great. Most of the game is bland but competent, some of the game is actually interesting and enjoyable however, there were definitely times when I rolled my eyes and rethought my decision to keep playing. In the end, I couldn't finish the original game and I can't finish this either. 

These games may have had good intentions, but they'll always be a series of subpar knock-offs to me.

6/10

35506260.review:
Interesting followup to the first game. Lords of Shadows 2 takes place after the events of Mirror of Fate and in two different timelines. It takes place in modern day where a city has been built upon the foundations of Dracula's castle. But it also takes place in the past. Through a strange time-travel sequence that may also be inside Dracula's head. But maybe it isn't in his head?

It's confusing. Don't try to understand it unless you have played Mirror of Fate. In that case you will have a headstart on this story.

If you're looking for a amazing sequel that builds upon the first game into a sublime experience you will find pieces of that effort here. It has plenty of hack n' slash fun and many great features, but do not be fooled so easily: it is not nearly as polished as its predecessor. 

I'll start with the positive since the negative is always easier to write about. The first two aspects which stick out are the music and graphics. Both are excellent, much like Lords of Shadow 1, but strike a different approach. Things are darker this time around and it is showcased both in the artistry and musical score.

The combat also received a small overhaul. Think of it as the difference between the first God of War and the second or the third. Combat is a little more responsive and, in terms of interaction between the NPCs and weapons themselves, a little crisper. 

While the time travel/in your head sequences may be strange at first the sequences follow a certain controlled chaos. The story can be followed but you may have to pause and remind yourself of a few things from time to time. 

The Characters in this game also seem to have taken a backseat in terms of personality. Apparently, sleeping for several centuries can make a person go from an engaging and dynamic personality to a static one. In the first Lords of Shadow I enjoyed taking Gabriel through his trials to defeat the Lords of Shadows. In this game, while the goal is clear, I never found myself being drawn into the story via its characters on the same level.

It also suffers from the classic "our game is too short let's put in some pointless challenges that have nothing to do with anything." This is one of my video game pet peeves. Similar to the Trials in the first game but with less substance. Throughout the game you collect the pieces and unlock Kleidos challenges which you can attempt from a particular area of the castle map. They are difficult after the first few and serve no purpose other than achievements. I don't know why game companies feel players want this kind of fluff which adds only to our achievement list. I know I would choose between the options below
1) 5 hours of gameplay which has no impact on the rest of the game's story, character progression, or collectibles
-OR-
2) 5 hours of gameplay which advances and expands the story


Despite these shortcomings we still have an enjoyable game. I found myself happy more often than frustrated or upset. I recommend playing it through at least once. The story of Gabriel is a fun reboot to the Castlevania franchise. If I had to give it an actual score: 75/100.

LoS 2 continues the story after LoS. If you haven't played Mirror of Fate, however, you're lacking a lot of key knowledge, if you're interested in that. Who the fuck is Alucard? Trevor? Samuel? The story from MoF is conveniently ignored in this game...at least almost.

Gone are the linear levels from the first game, replaced with 2 semi-open worlds, one in the real world and one in Dracula's imaginary castle...I've gotta say the castle trumps the real world in asthetic by miles! Apart from that not that much has actually changed. Dracula is a bit more mobile, the camera can now be rotated and platforming is a bit simpler most of the times. On the other hand, blocking is still a pain in the ass, because it again shares a button with dashing, which means you have to face the right direction before you try and block an attack. But why bother? 95% of the attacks in this game are unblockable anyway -.- And the only advantage of blocking is that you get to counter attack, which does marginally more damage than a regular combo attack...meh. Most of the time not worth it. Problematic is also if you've played any Souls game and are now accustomed to dodge having iframes...nooooope, not in this game. Despite that fact though, you'll be dodging/dashing pretty much constantly. 

Light and Dark magic are replaced with Frost and Chaos, but they pretty much do the same thing. There are a few gimmicks in the game where you have to freeze enemies or environment or break armor or explode stuff with chaos magic. Then you get a few new abilites like a bat swarm, turning into a cloud and a few relics with limited uses. I didn't really use any of the relics most of the time. One lets you heal up, one slows down hit enemies and another gives you full magic for a duration. Those are perhaps the most important. The rest is meh.

I've found myself cursing a lot when enemies seemingly hit me from nowhere or stun locked me. I'm so used to being able to stagger enemies as well. This doesn't really work in this game, so enemies will hit you through your attacks, but on the other hand many enemies have stances that completely block your light attacks.

The best part about the game are no doubt the boss fights. There are a lot of them and each one is quite fun in my opinion.

The worst part are definitely the puzzles, the stealth sections and the cutscenes. The puzzles can't be "auto-solved" anymore. You have to figure them out. There aren't really any tips. One could argue that this isn't a bad thing, however, this is a brawler and if you've played the first one you might get annoyed by this. The stealth sections are imho superflous and just prolong the game unnecessarily. Then we have the cutscenes. I'm not just talking about actual cutscenes, but everything in LoS has an indirect load time attached to it. Change sectors? Animation. Change into a rat? Long animation. Press a switch, ultra long cutscene that flies around the level for half an hour. Srsly, it's obnoxious how many cutscenes there are for no apparent reason. Do you want to watch a character walk 10 meters in 1 minute? LoS 2 got you covered.

It's not a bad game, but it definitely has its flaws. It by no means deserves the terrible Metacritic score it got. Maybe a 7/10.

33930306.review:
Castlevania once again show us that vampires can be truly badass!

Story:
Before going in to the story of the game know that, as this is a sequel, there is going to be some spoilers for Castlevania: Lords of Shadow. 

Gabriel Belmont, after destroying the Lords of Shadow and stopped Satan from returning to earth, now lives an eternal life as the Prince of Darkness, Dracula. A thousand years have passed since his battle with Satan when Draculas old enemy Zobek, Lord of the Necromancers, show up to ask for his help. Apparently Satans Acolaytes are planning on bringing him back, and if so both Dracula and Zobek will be tormented by him forever. But if Dracula can aid Zobek in finding the Acolaytes and slay them before Satan is summoned, Zobek will give him what he wants the most - eternal rest.

Personally, the story has been a bit downgraded from the last game. Lords of Shadow didn't have a great plot, but it had a kind of campy epicness that made the whole game really cool. It feels like the developers tried doing something similar with this entry, but none of the character really stuck with me and I never really felt invested in anything that happened until the very end of the game. The plot also suffers from the "amnesia-syndrome" where the main character don't remember everything - meaning that a lot of the dialogue in the game are very vague and cryptic, trying to build up to a cool twist that sadly falls a bit flat. Also, moving the game to modern time gave room for much less interesting enviroments. The first game had enchanted forests, graveyards, snowy mountains and deadly swamps. This game more or less are all very industrial looking, with some small glimmers of a cool gothic design.

Gameplay:
If you've played through the first Lords of Shadow (wich you probably should if you're interested in a sequel) you more or less know what to expect. The game is a combat-focused hack'n'slash game where you have to combine different attack-combos, special powers and some cool secondary powers (like Blood Daggers) in order to kill of the huge selection of enemies and bosses this game provides. The combat actually have been decently upgraded since the first one. First of all, you can now move the camera freely, giving you more control over your vision and therefore avoid some of the irritation the first game had with its static camera. Also, both guarding and dodging feels a bit more snappy and quick, making for a better control-scheme overall. And hey, if you don't like QTE's, this game actually gives you the option to turn them off!

The plattforming, which was something I really didn't like in the first game has been greatly improved too - taking a note from Sucker Punch's Infamous series, Dracula now snaps to a landing spot rather than it being controlled freely - which gives the impression of you controlling a truly agile figure. This, acording to me, is a great step-up from the last game.

The developers also included stealth into this game, and it is by far the worst part of it. This parts of the game are slow, boring and in many cases not even logical. At some points you are forced into a sneaking section where you have to sneak around a boss-character while activating some switches - only to have to face the boss in the very next room. I really don't get why I have to sneak around them if I'm just going to fight them five minutes later...

Best part of the game:
The game has an incredible fun combat-system, and using Draculas different abilities to battle through hordes of demons is great!

Worst part of the game:
The stealth-sections. They make no sense, aren't fun and are just slowing a combat-focused action game down to a halt. Like the plattforming in the first game, this part should have been cut from the game entirely!

I'm three years late with this review. 

[b]Pros:[/b]
[*] First off, thank God, the sequel's more keyboard-friendly than [i]LoS1[/i]. Remember the forced Stone Idol Titan “twirl-left-stick” QTE in the first game that had dumbfounded pretty much everyone who could not afford a controller? Well, now you can turn that sucker off, granting Gabriel the power to auto-succeed all QTEs at the expense of some experience points. 
[*] The [i]LoS1[/i] skill page has become a skill tree; it's easier to browse and see what skills lead to which. Still, the game funnily “reimburses” you should you go for a NG+. Mildly annoying, but it does show you just how much experience you've accumulated. 
[*] The combat flows more freely if compared to [i]LoS1[/i] and the Somersault move no longer makes you feel like you've cement blocks around your ankles. (Yes, I like Somersault.) Unlike other games I've played (namely Alice: Madness Returns), you get a clear visual/audio indication that your attack did not hit/did no damage. The new Weapon Mastery system gives you an incentive to vary your combos.  
[*] The character design, the bosses, the voice acting, and the OST. Holy hell, A+. Play the game just for these. [spoiler]The Toy Maker and Inner Dracula deserve special mention.[/spoiler]
[*] Unbound camera! Finally some use for your mouse/right stick. 
[*] The atmosphere is amazing, especially if you stop to sightsee. 
[*] The story is engrossing, and it ramps up the stakes in the last ten minutes, too. 
[*] Purely IMO here, but I do think Gabriel's one of the finest examples of good video game writing. His depiction of Dracula is nuanced and endearing. Same goes for Alucard, really. 
[/list]

[b]Cons:[/b]
[*] Forced stealth is meh. It's not that particularly hard, mind; the enemies you're expected to slip past are brain-dead. They don't look up, don't ring the alarm at the sight of bats in a pharmaceutical corporation, and blame mosquitoes when you fling a dagger at them. The only exception to this is [spoiler]Agreus, but his AI is just as exploitable. Psst, ignore the bells, wait till he rushes you and Mist Form away.[/spoiler]
[*] The Xbox prompts stay even if you do not have a controller plugged in. Again, a mild annoyance that very nearly got me killed when the game had asked me to "press B" or "down on the D-Pad". 
[*] The cheap hitscan potshots enemies like to take at you when you're out of range (or just performing an aerial combo for too long). Soldiers chuck daggers, heavies chuck axes, demons spit, vampires, uhhh, scream (?)... you get the picture. Typical padding.
[/list]

Ultimately, in spite of its flaws and troubled development, it's a good game and is worthy its purchase price. I've already beaten it twice. Too bad it was unjustly panned by critics at its release.

***

A fine 3rd person brawler game all around, but I was ultimately a little on the disappointed side when it came to fitting the style and story into the Castlevania universe - even this new one. If you're a fan of classic Castlevania on the NES and SNES, then play Mirror of Fate (very underrated).
The first Lords of Shadow was criticized by some for being more fantasy than Castlevania, but it was more of a prequel to the saga. The real saga is Mirror of Fate. This is more of a post-saga, and it takes place largely in a loney version of the modern (near-future) world. In many ways, the style of enemies you fight are more fitting of the Warhammer franchise, and you're fighting an evil corporation that's being run by figures possesd by the devil's army (despite being Dracula, yourself).

Gameplay is standard and enjoyable (2016/2017 play period). 
It might be worth noting that if you were annoyed by the level-break style of LoS1, they've smoothed it out in this one, using clever lock transitions to handle loading of different areas. So not completely seemless / open-world, but a lot better than distinct leveling that we saw in the first.

So my rankings are as follows:

1. Lords of Shadow - Mirror of Fate
(The heart of the Castlevania saga, brilliantly retold. Side-scroller.)
2. Lords of Shadow 1
(A prequel story to the saga.)
3. Lords of Shadow 2
(A post-saga, modern setting that feels a little muted.)

The story isn't quite as good as the first because I think the character progression of Gabriel is what really made that story great, but it isn't bad here either. The level design overall is nice and the music is decent. My only real complaints are that some of the puzzles seemed unnecessary and the stealth bits were somewhat annoying, although infrequent and easy enough that I didn't care all that much. The Revelations DLC is decent, I'd say it's maybe slightly better than the DLC from the first game. It's about 2-3 hours long and lets you play as a different character with a new weapon and different abilities in a story that takes place just before the start of LoS2 and explains a few events leading up to it. 30063319.review:
Mercury steam sequel of their reboot of the Castlevania series takes the ip back to its root of exploring an entire whole castle, where different sections have unique style, mechanics and monsters. It is probably the closest someone got to make a full 3D experience of Castlevania Symphony of the night. As for the first reboot the game is also at its core a spectacle fighting game.

The story of the game is suspended between two moments in time. In the present, your character, Dracula, wakes up after a very…very long sleep and faces a the evil deeds that are being made in what remains of his castle, now part of a whole city with a high tech facility rule by evil itself. Dracula also has to gain back his lost powers and it will do so traveling back in time to his old castle. Unlocking new areas and abilities will allow Dracula to travel more and more freely to every part of the levels in the typical Metroidvania style. Enemies will respawn every time in the same place giving you always some challenge. It may though get to become repetitive (a common problem with backtracking in this type of game design). What will not become tiresome is how beautiful the environments are! Especially the old castle, simply stunning. The same effort was not exactly put into enemy design, which are a bit more repetitive than in the prequel (no more mounting on orcs or giant spiders!)

The combat system is solid, strikes have impact force despite being almost all whip based and allow for a decent amount of combination, crowd control and power strikes, but not as much as tytles like Devil May Cry or Bayonetta. Mobility during combat is now much improved compared to the prequel, you can dash as much as you want in any direction, which really gives you the sensation of being a superpowered mischevious vampire that moves swiftly and strikes hard! The combat itself did not changed much from the first game. Magic attacks now use a sword and gauntlets instead of different colors of the whip attack, changing a lot the range of actions, but the combo scheme is copied into every weapon set (whip, sword and gauntlet alike).

The interesting combat mechanic of the series, the focus mechanic, comes back. This mechanic builds up a meter for chaining combos and variation of techniques used (as the meter of score for Devil May Cry) and is set back to zero if you are hit. Instead of just being linked to a score rating this focus meter is directly linked to the combat. Once it is filled enemies start giving magic refill, which you can absorb to fill up one of your two magic style (healing/defense style with the sword or heavy attack style with the gauntlet). 

Timing your block properly is probably the most efficient way to build up focus meter and create opening to attack even stronger enemies. The sync block mechanic (such is the name of this timing block thing) will create a sort of light explosion which will stagger enemies and slow time for a bit, great visual effect and good for planning your reposte.
I had the impressions that enemies and boss design had a step back compared to the prequel, but it may be due to the amount of time you will have to backtrack (especially for completionists).

In conclusion, I liked playing this title as much as the prequel, it is probably a more direct 3D successor to Castlevania than the first Lords of Shadows. It has some flaws for sure, but it a solid title if you wish for a good spectacle fighter with a Castlevania flavor.  I really hope a third title comes out taking the good of Lords of Shadows 1 and 2, combining them and smoothing the mistakes. That would really be a great game…but unfortunately it is Konami we are talking about…so don’t hold your breath.

tl;dr - Enjoyable hack-and-slash game in nice gothic environments.


If playing with a [b]Steam Controller[/b], take note - some of the cutscenes are so long that the Steam Controller falls asleep and the game immediately pauses, asking you to connect a controller.  Find a way to get your controller to not sleep, you should be OK.

[b]Graphics[/b] - played nicely at 144fps on a GTX 980 Ti, no hitches, very smooth. 

[b]Storywise[/b], overall, it's as decent as a hack-and-slash can get. There are plenty of evocative names and mythological tie-ups, I felt they were well presented. I don't think it's necessary to play the prequel to this, there is a somewhat incoherent recap of the occurences, but it doesn't matter too much. I am one of the few people who is not a fan of the prequel to this game, but I'm happy with this one.

The presentation of in-game [b]lore[/b] was nicely done.  You have a book with nice drawings, short texts, there are diaries and even your power-ups have descriptions.  

At times I felt some of the [b]boss fights[/b] were a bit short, they just ended too quickly.   The final fight felt short and straightforward too.  I think perhaps the fights weren't meant to be difficult, just a means to move on.  Some of the mob-fights, however, were of satisfying difficulty.  

Some reviewers are not happy about the [b]stealth[/b] parts of the game.  I can relate, it's understandable, thankfully those parts are not too long and you can quickly get over it.  You can also return to those areas later.

The graphics are what I would have to call "the best of last generation" , the appearance of Dracula's castle would have benefited massively from higher resolution textures and more modern processing techniques, even so the design is still a megalithic Gothic masterpiece.

Remember everything: a vampire is said to be ageless and immortal, yet it is an aged, anemic, amnesic Dracula we see at the begin of Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2's story, after the flashbacked prologue reminiscing Golden Paladin Roland de Ronceval and the Brotherhood of Light's fatal assault on the Gothic castle five hundred years ago. Gabriel-Dracula, now a thousand years old, awakes at the exit of the Cathedral into the nocturnal streets of Castlevania City, built upon the remains of his old Castle. He won't be astray much time but soon be meeting the two characters guiding him through the plot: young Trevor Belmont, the never known son, and Zobek, Lord of the Dead and former nemesis, now an influential businessman.

It apparently has been one of the developers' worries to enhance the game where the first Lords of Shadow has most been criticized: so the camera can freely be moved in a 360-degree angle now, the framerate is increased, and the formerly linear setting and storyline made place for an open-world design offering a greater variety in the pacing chosen. Also the gameplay has notably been improved and the sound, vibrant combat mechanics using the default X360 controller is thoroughly satisfying to use (Quick-Time Events can be deactivated in the Game Options menu).

Well-executed are also the necessary climbing and jumping sections that seem largely scripted, in addition to some occasional platforming elements which are usually easy to achieve thanks to a generous savepoint system.
Swarming bats indicate audibly where to proceed to the next ledge or ladder which is useful during as well as after beating the game, in addition to the White Wolf Medallion and the Map rooms for quick-traveling, to continue exploring the medieval Castle and the modern City.
Both the epic bossfights and the numerous collectibles (580 in total) give the game its replay value, in order to try oneself on a higher difficulty level or get one's skills and gauges maxed out.

No doubt, Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 is an ambitious game: what sets in quite like another God of War replica and stumbles at the gloomy entrance of Castlevania City's Sciences district, soon evolves into an extraordinary, creative Gothic action-adventure, with breathtaking visuals, atmospheric music (Óscar Araujo), and an unforgettable plot that relies heavily on the franchise's previous releases.

Story-wise, Castlevania is an epic family drama the likes of Star Wars: akin to Anakin Skywalker, Gabriel Belmont changes sides as he becomes the Prince of Darkness which opposes him to his own son Alucard (Luke), albeit those family bonds seem to be the only human trait left as he shows indulgence towards Victor, leader of the Brotherhood of Light and last of the Belmont bloodline.
The story finds a worthy conclusion in Lords of Shadow 2, but the myth is probably just too good to simply let it die: “Who knows what fate has in store.”

26512754.review:
It pains me to do this, but I can’t recommend this game. It’s an example of how not to do sequels to good games. The first LoS game was a good reboot of the Castlevania setting with an ending that was baiting for a sequel, so I was anticipating this game, hoping for something better or at least more of the same. What I got was mostly the worst parts of LoS1 made even more annoying.

[Spoiler alert for LoS1 and LoS2]

The story and the way it is developing is boring and goes to unbelievable lengths to be stupid. The whole premise “You are Dracula” is being thrown away almost immediately and replaced with a redemption story that defies almost any reason, considering the setting and the narrative. The game starts you with a DmC tier edgy vampire lord and then repeatedly shows him as some pathetic weirdo, who was visions of his son he never actually saw in his young form. The gameplay humiliates the character of Dracula even more with annoying stealth sequences that make you hide from some demonic space marines – these sections of gameplay have zero freedom of approach and challenge – you just have to make progress the way it was intended or you will face ridiculous fail states or invisible walls.

And oh boy, this desire to limit the player can be traced through the entire game when you are stuck with forced tutorials, platforming that makes little sense considering the level geometry (you can’t get to a secret you see hidden behind a 1,5m tall cinder block with wide gaps by its side, because you have to circle around it and use the Mist Form skill after a decent chunk of story progression)

The level design being “open world” doesn’t help at all – it’s just badly designed locations, taped together in an attempt to create a fake metroidvania feeling. It actually brings frustration instead of interesting exploration because there are no ways of traversing the world that are fun. You would think that being Dracula could mean that you can fast travel by turning into bats or something like that, but no – you are stuck with tedious running and platforming with fake loading screens behind switches for doors and elevators.

The things that made this experience actually bearable and occasionally fun were the visuals and the combat system.  The visuals and the designs of sceneries and enemies were pretty cool and the combat system had an interesting leveling gimmick that motivates you to use different moves as often as possible (if you want to level up your weapons faster).

By the way, the Alucard DLC shares the same problems of the base game – it’s more of the base game if you want it.

This game is not the worst game ever, but it’s a disappointment and you can almost always find a better action game to play and waste 15-20 hours on.

26503821.review:
Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 should be the shining example of how not to do a sequel. The first Lords of Shadow game was a successful reimagining of the Belmont clan's eternal war against Dracula, with a solid combat system and gothic story that ended on a cliffhanger that easily teed up a continuation that would just have to stay the course to be enjoyable. Instead, MecurySteam seems to have dug deep to unearth the worst parts of the original, then added a pile of steaming shit on top of it.
 
  I've never played a game that was so hellbent on taking control away from the player as this one. You start out in Gabriel's throne room, fighting back an invading army of armored foes. Every few steps you take, the game pauses to display tutorial text detailing moves you have available. It's a standard introduction to the controls, I thought, that's fine... Then I arrived at a section that required platforming, which was excellent in the prequel. Here, swarms of bats appear on handholds, and you just jump bat point to bat point, with no rhyme or reason to how high/far Gabriel can jump; often where you're jumping is completely off screen or doesn't make logical sense, you just jam jump to follow an arbitrary bat path. The movement in general just feels very stiff, linear, and unreliable. The camera is much too close to the character when “exploring”, and trying to jump a two foot gap could mean death in one instance, but you're deftly performing acrobatic leaps when the game wants you to...
 
  Lords of Shadow 2 is more movie than game. After about the two hour mark of barely controlling the character, watching intolerably long cutscenes, taking two steps forward then triggering another obnoxiously long cutscene, I tried to grin and bear it, holding out hope that the game was setting the scene and would go off the narrow rails later. I was wrong. The reliance on movies to fill out the play time is persistent for the entire game. A few minutes of control, fighting a few small, easy demons... ten minute cutscene. Fight a boss for five minutes... ten minute cutscene. And the story is miserable; part emo, Dracula wants to kill himself, and part cartoon/anime cringe-y, Dragonball Z trash, every story beat somehow manages to be stupider and less cool than the last.
 
  On the off chance you aren't watching a cutscene, you're presented with a poorly designed, fake open world to explore. It's only “open” in the sense that you can theoretically move among the levels at will without loading into them, but good luck with that. The environments are these super tight, twisting, confusing to navigate messes that's don't connect logically, and you're often forced to hit switches and wait for load-hiding mini-cutscenes to play out before you advance. It didn't take long before I completely abandoned any desire to look for optional power ups or secrets and just wanted to rush through the main path as quickly as possible. And even that can be a nightmare...
 
  And then you'll hit the stealth sections. Oh, boy. They are really bad. Putting aside the idiotic narrative leaps where Gabriel can rip the heart out of a skyscraper-sized demon in one scene but will cower and automatically fail if a Strogg spots and shoots him the next, it's just a horrible, tacked on mini-game that you're forced to endure six times too many. Like the rest of the game, these horrible tests of patience expect you to play like a robot, using what powers they want you to use when they want you to use them. Experimentation is discouraged; there were a few instances where I thought I was pretty clever and found shortcuts around the unnecessarily long path they laid out, only to run into invisible walls or nonsensical fail states. You can transform into a swarm of rats if you activate set “dark spots” (because apparently Dracula is shy) which seems neat, but you're forced to watch more canned animation play out every time you do this, and you're often tasked with following a glowing skull bread crumb trail through narrow, linear vents, which is about as much fun as it sounds.
 
  The one thing Lords of Shadow 2 has going for it is the visuals. I guess throwing player agency to the wind has it's perks, because the artists had the time to make a beautiful game. The demon and boss design in particular is excellent and creative. From fighting a Guillermo del Toro looking, tentacle-headed scientist to battling Satan riding a flying Cthulhu worm, the unique monsters and reimagined classic foes are pure, inspired eye candy. This ends the positive things I have to say about the game...
 
  The “Ultimate Edition” includes all of the DLC, including a mode called Revelations that I think lets you play as Alucard in a new set of single player missions. I can't say for sure, because I didn't play it. I honestly couldn't wait for this game to be over so I could delete it off of my hard drive and be done with it. That might not be much of a review, but Lords of Shadow 2 isn't much of a game.

Luego de casi 13 horas de juego, sólo puedo decir que se me han hecho muy largas... y confusas. Ha falta de mucho juego por delante mi opinión puede cambiar, pero de momentos lo resumo de la siguiente manera:

+ El juego entrega información detallada del folklore de la saga, prácticamente en cada aspecto de la misma.

26030484.review:
The original text was published on Kanobu on 25.02.2014

I don’t know if a secret contest is taking place among the slasher game developers for the most over-the-top prologue*; but if there is one, then Lords of Shadow 2 is a shoe-in for the grand prize. First game of the series reboot by MercurySteam has greeted you with a slow gothic fantasy. This time the game gets right into the action. The protagonist is Dracula himself. He uses his own blood as a whip. His castle is under attack by an army of thousands. This army has a giant humanoid robot. The stakes are high, rivalries are thousands-of-years-old, prophecies are dark, and angels are fallen. And then there’s the usual removal of all those nice abilities which used to allow you to perform a complete massacre on poor grunts of the army which was attacking you.

The combat system looks exactly like the one of its predecessor: accentuated counter-attacks and two bars of special energy used to break blocks and heal. Both kinds of magic now have unique weapons, but controls are still the same. What stands out is a free-floating camera as opposed to static angles from the first game. A lot of delightful improvements to what already worked perfectly before aren’t the biggest surprise. The game looks back at the series’ legacy and remembers where the second part of metroidvania term came from. The world is a holistic labyrinth with inaccessible high passages and grates standing in your way. This promise of big and small secrets is the foundation for everything else here. The story progression path goes in big stretches only occasionally offering to come back to the earlier places. You could replay levels in the first game to access locked upgrades once you’ve acquired the required ability, but you also had to go through the repetition of story scenes and routes weren’t particularly interesting.

The second installment simply blends the secrets in the world as a part of a bigger picture. The scenery is grotesque most of the time and is occasionally filled with details for you to look at for some time. Half of the locations are in the future, of course, so it adds up to a final result of a truly bizarre over-stylized collage.

The wild outlook in accompanied by an equally wild script. It defies logic in favor of having more and more bizarre characters and spectacular action scenes. If there’s a fight on a moving train it’ll end with a crash, explosions and acrobatics. You can’t just kill the giant boss — you have to rip out its heart. It is completely normal for the protagonist to ride a giant gas bottle because he needed a new entrance in the building. The headcount of unlucky enemies of Dracula is in a thousands range. Relentless postmodern carnival wouldn’t give you a break, so at some point you just can’t be surprised by anything. Raisa Volkova, the daughter of Satan? Sounds completely normal!

Lords of Shadow 2 wants to go further than its predecessor so desperately and tries so much new stuff, that sometimes it ends with stuff that is just too cringeworthy. Clumsy stealth sections simply don’t hold up to the pace of the game and are irritating rather than entertaining.

Still, you get transformations into blood mist and rat pack out of this torture. Two more instruments for world-exploring toolset. You can see in it the reminiscence of what Symphony of the Night did to Rondo of Blood. The story of the series also goes in circles on the moebius band of time-travelling nonsense. The game may pass a self-parody for the long franchise with a few dozens of titles in it. And that may be a good thing sometimes.

25745893.review:
Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 is a good game.  In fact, I'd call it very good if it weren't for a few glaring flaws.  Critically, this game floundered since the media focused on what the game did wrong rather than what it did right.  This game has many extremely memorable moments.  The battle with medusa and the battle with the toy maker immediately come to mind.  However, for a short amount of time,  the game throws some bad stealth mechanics at you.  There isn't much to say about them, the stealth is barebones and feels very out of place in the story, outside of a single instance where it seemed logical.  Luckily, their presence is more like a puzzle in the game than an actual mechanic.  You won't spend much time stealthing around.

Now, on to what this game got right:

Combat is A+.  It's up there with the best action games imo: God of War, Devil May Cry, etc.  It's more comparable to DmC: Devil May Cry all the way down to the weapon swapping mechanic.  It feels smooth, responsive, and impactful.  

The graphics are fantastic.  The art team did a wonderful job in this game and the engine devs did a great job focusing on the most important aspects of the engine for this game.  The modern city looks great and manages to feel victorian while also looking modern, and Dracula's castle is absolutely gorgeous.  The game also runs like a dream (originally played on a gtx 780 with plenty of power to spare).

The story is...well it's nothing to brag about.  The premise is interesting, and the beginning isn't too bad, but some cringy dialogue and a painfullly bad ending ruin it.

In the end, I recommend this game.  The good outweighs the bad by a long shot.  Critically speaking, it's a heavily underrated game.  It's hard to accurately express what makes the good parts feel so much better than the bad.

If you are interested in this game, download the demo.  It's a good representation of what you'll do in this game 80%-90% of the time (minus the exploration).

25648289.review:
I think I need to add this to the "games that most people hated which I actually enjoyed" list. Admittedly, I'm biased because I really dig Castlevania, enjoyed the first Lords of Shadow and Mirror of Fate, and am a sucker for the idea of playing as Dracula himself. But even at its most frustrating moments, Lords of Shadow 2 isn't nearly as bad as Edge Magazine (which gave it a 4/10) or any of the other mainstream reviews would have you believe. 

Bloodsucking awesome stuff:
+ I feel like combat's speedier and more responsive than it was in the first Lords of Shadow, and there's less reliance on quicktime events. This might have to do with the fact that I'm just more experienced with the combat system after playing through the first game and Mirror of Fate, but I had a lot of fun beating up some of the bosses, which leads me to the next point...
+ The boss battles (with the exception of the finale) are grand as hell! You've got some classic mainstays in there, like Death and Medusa, whose inclusion instantly make this game seem "more Castlevania" than its prequel.
+ On that note, the first Lords of Shadow got criticism from many people who felt it was Castlevania in name only (though in a surprising twist, I've noticed that the first game is now retroactively considered great in the wake of the poor reception the second got). This isn't the case here - from the getgo, when you start out as Dracula in your castle sipping a glass of blood, Symphony of the Night references start popping up everywhere. These plus the haunted atmosphere and the inclusion of Alucard just make the game *FEEL* more like a proper entry in the series. 
+ Lords of Shadow 2 is beautifully presented, and like its predecessor, has some of my favorite menus ever in a video game. (I'm just a sucker for any menu that resembles an old torn book and has little hand-drawn animations showing your available attacks.) The music feels like it's from the long-lost Castlevania movie that got stuck in development hell, and the environments are amazing...at least for the flashback sections of the game. 

Not so bloodsuckingly awesome
+ The game has two worlds, Zelda-style - a flashback castle that sort of exists in Dracula's mind (or in another dimension, it's never really explained) and a modern setting. And while the castle is gorgeous, the modern levels are laboratories, deserted hospitals and dirty streets that resemble Gotham City in the Arkham games at their best but are just forgettable at their worst. 
+ With the strange duo world thing comes the plot, which I actually enjoyed for the majority of the game, even though there's one big twist near the end that is really the most comic book thing ever, and I don't mean that in a good way. But the ending is very weak. Let's just say that the final boss battle doesn't exactly hit the heights of previous fights, let alone the epic clash of Gabriel Belmont versus Satan from the first game, and even though there's a big redemption story that builds up for Dracula over the course of 30-some hours, the whole thing concludes like a wet fart in the night. Also...Victor Belmont, what a waste.
+ Unlike Lords of Shadow 1, this sequel's a Metroidvania. This is good in theory, but on the negative side, enemies are still damage sinks, which interrupts the joy of exploration, and the shackles of the level-based structure of the first game are still there. Many times you can only traverse areas in a VERY SPECIFIC WAY that the game wants you to take - ie, even though Drac gets a double jump, he can't jump over this crappy little ledge to get the collectible on the other side even though you can CLEARLY see he should be able to reach it. No, you have to take the long route around and use your mist form to pass through a gate (and the mist form can only be used in a few key places too) because the game's been programmed that way. Mirror of Fate had this issue as well, but it wasn't as noticeable because that game was 2.5D. In a 3D environment, it's very obvious.
+ Tying into this element of restrictiveness, the stealth sections that got slammed by every reviewer ARE quite annoying. If you dunno what these are - there are a few enemies, like some huge armor-plated guards and Pan's brother, who can kill Drac in two shots, even though in every cutscene the Prince of Darkness easily demolishes much bigger foes. The only reason Drac is vulnerable to these guys is because the designers needed an excuse to make the players complete so-so puzzles where you need to change to rat form or cling to walls to sneak by them. It's kind of a ham-fisted way to switch up gameplay, but luckily it's only about 5% of the game. 

Lords of Shadow 2 got massacred upon release, but I'm glad to see it's at least getting positive reviews on Steam two years later. I still liked it enough to go out of my way to find every collectible, which is rare for me. It's biggest flaw is that it has the restrictive design of a PS2 game, but was released in 2014, a year which also saw innovative titles like Shadow of Mordor which introduced fresh gameplay mechanics. (OK, I agree that Mordor was overrated - but it did offer a solid open world, and the Nemesis system WAS great.) Reviewers were expecting more when this came out, frankly, and rated the game as such. As it stands, it's still not a horrible way for the Castlevania franchise to end, and worth a look for more open-minded fans who aren't opposed to Castlevania games not made by Koji Igarashi. 

If you're interested, I wrote some longer thoughts on this game and the negative reception it got here: http://pixelgrotto.tumblr.com/post/150812695901/musings-goodnight-sweet-prince-eurogamer

25153720.review:
Castlevania LoS 2 es el cierre de la trilogía que el estudio madrileño creó sobre la famosa saga. Un juego largo y completo, con una historia interesante que explica en profundidad y cierra todas las tramas que se originaron con el primer Lords of Shadow.

En este juego las novedades respecto a los anteriores son bastante numerosas. Comenzando por la inclusión de una cámara libre, un sistema de combate más variado, con más opciones y mejor desarrollado, un sistema de juego algo más abierto que permite explorar los escenarios en cualquier momento, pudiendo hacer backtracking cuando conseguimos nuevas habilidades y un mayor sentido de la espectacularidad en momentos de acción.

El punto más destacable de esta aventura son los combates, que esta vez son más numerosos, convirtiéndose en el principal aliciente. Ofrece combates contra jefes de muy diferentes clases y con estrategias a seguir dispares, además de luchas contra numerosas clases de enemigos menores también muy satisfactorias. El gran arsenal de Drácula, junto con un buen puñado de poderes mágicos nuevos, reliquias y habilidades que iremos consiguiendo poco a poco hace que los combates nunca sean repetitivos, pudiendo intercalar todas estas posibilidades de la forma más eficaz según las clases de enemigos a las que nos enfrentemos cada vez, siendo su IA bastante diferente entre ellos. Así, el sistema de lucha se muestra complejo y profundo, pero sencillo de dominar con algo de práctica, y muy satisfactorio en la mayoría de combates en los que tomaremos parte. Además varios combates suponen un reto importante.

El otro gran pilar del juego siguen siendo las plataformas, un punto que sigue flojeando bastante debido a la linealidad con las que están diseñadas las zonas de agarre en los niveles, sin permitirnos apenas libertad en la forma de atravesar los escenarios. Aún así se intenta dar complejidad con trampas de varias clases, retos de tiempo y uso de habilidades especiales para hacer el plataformeo algo más variado, pero se queda a medio fuelle, ya que el control en el salto por ejemplo, no es todo lo preciso que podría y debería ser. Por lo tanto el plataformeo termina resultando monótono, fácil y simple, aún mejorando el plataformeo del 1º Lords of Shadow.

También nos encontramos con puzzles, la mayoría en forma de zonas de sigilo donde normalmente solo hay una posible forma correcta de hacer las cosas, siguiendo unos determinados pasos. Para ello Drácula puede transformarse en un grupo de ratas para atravesar pequeños canales y pasadizos, con sus propias trampas, también hacer uso de una bandada de murciélagos para distraer a los enemigos, tranformarse en niebla momentánemente para pasar desapercibido y sortear verjas, o incluso poseer a los enemigos desde atrás para pasar a zonas de acceso restringido desde dentro de sus cuerpos. A pesar de las numerosas posibilidades, todas estas zonas son similares de resolver y no ofrecen una gran diversión porque están muy encorsetadas y solo se resuelven de una manera, aunque se agradece la inclusión de variabilidad en la jugabilidad.

El progreso de Drácula es bastante profundo y podremos mejorar multitud de habilidades de combate con sus tres armas principales, además de aumentar parámetros como la cantidad de poder mágico y vitalidad. Estos parámetros se mejoran mediante la búsqueda de unos artilugios donde Drácula hará un pequeño sacrificio de su sangre, y en muchos casos habrá que observar y explorar con minuciosidad los grandes escenarios para llegar hasta ellos. También hay otros tipos de coleccionables, como diarios de soldados caídos, documentos de la ciudad, ciertos clavos que nos permitirán enfrentarnos a retos especiales de combate, puntos de habilidades,etc. En este sentido el juego premia la exploración, y los escenarios invitan a ser recorridos en más de una ocasión para localizar lo máximo posible. Incluso podremos obtener unas reliquias que nos ayudarán a señalar en el mapa la localización de algunos de estos secretos.
En general el diseño de niveles del juego tiene una gran calidad. Hay bastante variedad en las maneras en las que recorreremos los escenarios, incluso colgados de plataformas movibles por ejemplo. Sobresale el grado de detalle de las estructuras, con un diseño gótico tan exagerado y barroco. En muchas zonas es fácil quedarse mirando estos escenarios dada su belleza y alto nivel de detalle tanto en la ciudad moderna como en la otra realidad antigua del castillo. Los juegos de luces, el fuego, partículas, brillos y diseño de personajes y enemigos también está a un gran nivel.
El juego cumple muy bien en variedad de escenarios, y mezclando zonas en la ciudad moderna, como laboratorios y apartamentos, con el majestuoso castillo de Drácula en sus mejores tiempos. Ambos tipos de escenarios están muy bien recreados, ofrecen bonitas vistas y diferentes tipos de plataformas, uso de poderes y saltos para cada zona.

La historia es otro de los puntos fuertes de esta aventura, narrada con tranquilidad y con intensidad esporádica, manteniendo siempre la atención de la trama, que aunque no tiene giros drásticos del guión como en el 1º juego, cumple con creces en este aspecto y sí que presenciaremos varias sorpresas menores. Se profundiza en todos los personajes, dándoles una fuerte personalidad en la mayoría de casos. Hay bastantes cinemáticas, pero no resultan aburridas ni rompen el ritmo del juego, que está bastante bien llevado.
La BSO es excelente, combina perfectamente en cada momento del juego y en general son piezas con mucha calidad y complejas que transmiten bien la emoción de cada situación, así como el buen doblaje de personajes principales y secundarios.

Así, este Castlevania es un muy notable juego de aventuras cargado de acción y exploración con una historia muy elaborada y llena de detalles que finalizan la epopeya del clan Belmont contada a lo largo de cientos de años. Un juego bastante superior a sus predecesores. Completarlo al 100% puede llevar hasta 25 horas, por lo que ofrece buenas horas de diversión. Sólo un plataformeo encorsetado lastrado de su 1º parte con poco control sobre el salto, un diseño de niveles que ofrece pocas formas diferentes de movernos por ellos, unas zonas de sigilo también demasiado encorsetadas y con pocas posibilidades y una falta de mayor número de novedades y minijuegos lastran lo que podría haber sido un juego de aventuras sobresaliente con un aspecto y ambientación excelente.
Muy recomendable tambien el DLC de Revelations, donde manejaremos a Alucard en cierto intervalo crítico de tiempo en la historia del juego principal. Un DLC corto, pero que reune lo mejor del juego principal, además de ofrecer habilidades completamente nuevas, como el control de un lobo espectral o la reconstrucción de viejas estructuras dañadas, además del manejo de armas diferentes a las que usa Drácula. También encontramos en este DLC dos de los mejores puzzles de todo el juego, con secciones muy inspiradas tanto en jugabilidad como en su diseño artístico. Incluso se mejora la satisfacción que producen las zonas de plataformeo haciéndolas más complejas y complicadas.  8'4
