Castlevania LoS2 Is what I would define as bad oatmeal. Strong elements of several kinds without a smoot transition is what makes the experience feel forced, or what may force you to have harsh feelings about the game. (Like I did)

Merging strong storytelling with exploration using cutscenes is a big no in the experience category. When you find a new area or get past or to a boss or story area, you get a cutscene that either  shows you everything you want to find on your own, or tells you a story that moves you from the area before you can finish exploring. Other games manage this type of merge by using character narration or slowing the walk speed. 

Strong combat elements with excessive backtracking: Having to down half a dozen enemies who are tiered to what part of the main story you are on just because you are looking for something is what I hate most about the game. The lack of loot and a equipment system makes me lose the edge for excessive combat, but in addition to that, almost every enemy has a ranged attack that has huge hitboxes that they are all too happy to use deciding you would like to skip the battle. Most battles near the endgame or after you gained a new traversal ability are begun with a groan because you've been shot off a ledge to the point where you do want to fight just so you can enjoy the game. The mastery system ends way too early to entice excessive battling and credits are easy to get provided you dpend them properly upgrading skills you'll most likely use. 

The open world element is trashed by an isolated map system and the same looking load elevators and hatches. Find things in this game is met with repeatedly going the wrong way and passing points where you cannot backtrack through the area after you jumped down. The areas are intertwined somewhat and only one or two pllaces have this problem, but that tied with the block the area rests in being behind one of like 5 blue elevator doors makes the experience irritating and repetitive.

But after you swallow those strong flavors and seperate them by improvising, you can stop to appreaciate the art and fluidity of the combat and the thought they put into hiding the upgrades. And then when all that is getting good... The game is over. It's metroid all over again. Get the screw attack, Find stuff, kill the last guy. I just hope there is a secret boss or something. 

The alucard dlc is honestly why I bought the game. For some reason, everything dracula backwards is in seems to get more polish than the game itself... for some reason, that's still true. Alucard has proper last gen hair animation, a shiny coat, skin that is also pale but not sickening to look at, skills that are practical, a sword and movelist that probably drove the fans crazy, and one of the coolest ideas for a puzzle element ever. It doesn't break pace ever, and it makes you feel like you're a strong character. Instead of being dracula where you never even got to beat one of the guards that caused you so much trouble without taking over their body and dropping their gun. 

It's one of those games that gets better when you play it. The start is slow, and the search is tedius, but after you play through it, you realize it is really a fantastic idea made into a just okay game. Where in my opinion, Lament of innocence probably takes the cake for a castlevania game, and alucard still takes the cake for the coolest vampire. Dracula should have stayed dead... Could have been a way better game.

It's a great game.  Alot more dark than the first game, but for what it is, it's very well presented.  There's more to do, and bigger areas to explore.  The story is a lock-step continuation of the first game, and you'll see some familiar faces and some inuendo for your imagination to figure out.  I find the dark style a little unwelcome, but that's just me.  It doesn't have to be bright and sunny, but it could have more supernatural monsters, or ... you know, just something.

The fighting in this is much improved.  Some of your moves are similar to the first game, but they do more of what they are supposed to, and less scripted.  If you do a Guilotine for example, some enemies will dodge, some will block, and some will take the full brunt, instead of a guaranteed hit every time.  So those familiar moves feel so much more realistic.  Even small enemies require some strategy.

One almost deal breaker was the onscreen prompts.  I started out using a keyboard-mouse, and it displays xbox prompts -ONLY.  It took me forever to associate B with "f" and Y with Mouse2.  You can get used to it though.

If you liked the first game, you'll find this one better in alot more ways than not.  Qualitywise, hugely better.  Graphics, way better, Fights, hugely better.  Mood, eh... but I think the story compensates for that alot.  It looks like the DLC "Revelations" is going to have alot of what I'm looking for.  Great game all around.

24069560.review: Lords of Shadow 2 is ostensibly the last game in the Lords of Shadow trilogy created by MercurySteam, and possibly the final game in the Castlevania series, due to Konami moving on to more "profitable" ventures. On paper, this game has all the ingredients needed to send the series out with a bang; amazing graphics, expanded combat and upgrade system, larger and more explorable world, great score, and stellar voice cast. However, when taken together, it doesn't quite reach the heights of the first Lords of Shadow game. One of the biggest problems is the story, which is all over the place as the player jumps between the past and present, represented by the enormous castle where Dracula resides, and the modern-day, gothic city. While MercurySteam's attention to detail and graphical prowess shine in both sections of the game, the city just wasn't as compelling as the castle, and every time I had to go back to the city to complete an objective, I sighed. This point extends to the gameplay in the city as well, which boasts uninspired and frustrating enemies, and stealth sections. In truth, the enemies in the city weren't actually that bad; I just felt that the castle's enemies were much better designed, and fit the "Castlevania" theme. Despite these issues, the core gameplay and combat is solid, and for the most part, better than the first game. The player is also free to roam around both areas looking for upgrades and collectibles; gone is the chapter-by-chapter format. Even with the story jumping around, it is fairly interesting, and the cast does a good job of keeping the player involved. However, the biggest problem emerged during the last third of the game, where it seemed like interesting characters and plot developments were either dropped or rushed to conclusion, culminating in a disappointing final sequence and boss that paled in comparison to the epic scale and confrontations of the first game. Stretching out some story moments or expanding on all the concepts that the narrative introduced would have made the story feel much more put together and complete. And ultimately, it is this feeling of "what could have been" that drags this game down to being simply good, and not great. There are some cool moments, and I did enjoy the experience enough to recommend this game, but it could have been so much more. And that's just a shame.

23904791.review:
[h1]Un juego notable, pero con potencial para haber conseguido mucho más.[/h1]

Los que hemos tenido la suerte de disfrutar de buenas trilogías, tetralogías, etc. estamos acostumbrados a ver una primera entrega con mucho potencial que destaca por su calidad y que da lugar a secuelas que, con mostrar más de lo mismo pero mejor y añadiendo alguna novedad jugable, se consiguen juegos realmente buenos hasta el punto de ser obras maestras en algunos casos.

Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 se queda a medio camino de ser una secuela a la altura de la primera entrega, pues mejora muchos aspectos de ésta, pero flojea en otros y sobretodo en algunas de las novedades jugables, que no le sientan nada bien a un hack n slash. Pero no hay que confundirse, no estamos ante un juego simplemente bueno, sino un juego notable pero que a los que hemos jugado la trilogía nos duele que no se cierre con broche de oro.

[b]Lo que se ha mejorado:[/b]

El combate, que ya era bueno, ahora no se limita a tener un arma principal y magias para curarse o hacer más daño, sino que cada poder o magia es un arma distinta sumando un total de 3 armas distintas, obligándonos a usar un arma para romper escudos, otra para congelar a enemigos que son muy rápidos, etc. Además, cada arma tiene muchas técnicas que desbloquear y dominar para así subir el nivel del arma al máximo.

Se ha mejorado también la forma de contar la historia. Se nota el esfuerzo que se ha puesto en las cinemáticas, que resultan más interesantes. Las voces están más trabajadas, etc. La presentación es sublime.

Ahora el juego no se divide en capítulos a los que se acceden a través de un menú, sino que la historia transcurre en una ciudad/castillo con diferentes zonas interconectadas que se pueden explorar libremente, sin llegar a nivel de “mundo abierto”. Hay unas “salas de mapas” que ofrecen la opción de teletransporte.

Los desafíos de Kleidos, un modo arena con retos que superar bastante atractivo, tanto para completar el 100% del juego como para practicar. Creo que estos modos de juego tipo arena/oleadas de enemigos deberían estar en todos los juegos de accion. Explotan bastante la jugabilidad. Mejor este modo que tener que repetir capítulo por capítulo bajo unas determinadas condiciones, como ocurría en la primera entrega. No hubiera estado de más un modo contrarreloj como en Mirror of Fate.

[b]Donde se ha dado un paso atrás:[/b]

Las secciones de plataformas pierden fuerza en esta entrega. Ahora en las zonas de escalada el personaje es mucho más ágil y prácticamente con mover el stick de dirección y aporrear el botón de salto para llegar a los salientes más alejados acabaremos con dichas secciones rápidamente. El primer juego no es que fuese difícil en este aspecto, pero en Lords of Shadow 2 han simplificado demasiado estas secciones.

El sigilo está metido con calzador. Al principio del juego intentan justificarlo con que el personaje está débil y tiene que evitar enemigos, pero una vez la historia avanza podemos encontrarnos con situaciones tan forzadas como escondernos de un enemigo para que inmediatamente después de terminar la zona de sigilo enfrentarnos a él. Hay que añadir que estas secciones son fáciles, pero paran tanto la acción que por la ansiedad de acabarlas cuanto antes pueden llegar a matarnos una y otra vez y llegar a ser realmente frustrantes.

Convertirse en rata puede resultar una mecánica interesante a la hora de acceder a zonas secretas con coleccionables, desbloquear puertas, etc., pero no se ha explotado en este aspecto. Aunque es de agradecer que esta mecánica sirva para algo más que las zonas de sigilo, tampoco aporta mucho y se podría haber evitado, sin ser lo peor del mundo.

[b]Merece la pena si has jugado a los anteriores[/b]

En definitiva, Castlevania, Lords of Shadow 2 es un juego totalmente recomendable a los que hayan jugado a alguna de las entregas anteriores y quieran saber cómo acaba todo. No es una obra maestra pero no es lo suficientemente malo como para dejarlo pasar de largo sino todo lo contrario, es un juego notable, con fallos que lo penalizan pero que no son lo suficientemente graves para eclipsar todos los demás aspectos positivos del juego.

Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 is an action adventure game developed by the company MercurySteam and published by the company Konami Digital Entertainment. It represents the sequel to Castlevania: Lords of Shadow (2010).

[i] Pros & cons: [/i]

o Variety of enemies is rather small and champions are too weak. Compelling storytelling in the beginning, but it loses momentum towards the end.

[i] Summary: [/i]

I got this for 10 bucks on the Humble Bundle store after having a lot of interest in it beforehand. Having played the original Castlevania, SOTN, Aria of Sorrow, and a portion of LOSMOF HD, I can say this game stands up to the general dark vibes. I was a bit hesitant of a 3D Castlevania game, but it worked quite well. Once I got used to the keyboard controls and whatnot, the game was not difficult at all, with the exception of a few very frustrating puzzles and a couple bosses.

It plays a lot like the older Devil May Cry games, including the 4th game in the series, even some of the camera zooms on doors and other things were very reminiscent of those games, which I loved. 

The game promotes using different attack patterns, by using a "mastery" system for each skill you buy with Souls. This system gives you points in whichever skill you are using, and when maxed out, can be used to upgrade the weapon itself. I found myself using more varied combos and different attack patterns, instead of just cheesing the bosses with Guillotine. 

I digged how Dracula / Gabriel is portrayed, and the other characters are well done as well. 

Though, be advised that the controls are not shown as keyboard keys, and will instead be like, "push A" and so on, corresponding to an Xbox 360 controller. This got extremely frustrating in the beginning before I knew what the buttons translated to on the PC, but once I got used to it, everything worked well. 

Is this game worth the $40 dollars? I am not sure really, it depends how much you want a game like this. I personally feel that the game is very good, and was well developed, even if by a different company than the original games

An open world connected by shortcuts, more weapons and spells to use, and the addition of new relics and items to toss about. Unfortunately, the story and lore about about as mishmosh and nonsensical as the first games if you give them even a second thought, so if you're looking for a compelling addition to the Castlevania chronicles, like the first game, you're going to be sorely mistaken.

For being "the epic conclusion" to the Lords of Shadow saga, very little is actually concluded.

Luckily, the combat is smoother, faster, more fluid, as are all the platforming aspects. While the trappings and aesthetics are lacking, underneath beats the heart of a solid, fun action game. Like the first game, I feel like if it had been called anything buta Castlevania game, the story would get a pass. The game itself though, is fun enough to be a recommendation for anyone who enjoys action games.

Aunque allá afuera hay mucha gente criticando Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2, yo creo que es una digna continuación de su predecesor y el juego intermedio entre ambos (Castlevania - Mirror of Fate). En esta ocasión, se nos dice qué ocurrió después de que Gabriel, en la cinemática final del primer juego, fuera buscado por Zobek y de repente apareciese en una ciudad absolutamente moderna; nos encontramos en el año 2057 y Zobek está enterado de que Satán va a ser traído nuevamente al mundo (específicamente a la ciudad de Castlevania), tras los enormes esfuerzos de tres acólitos que tienen mucha influencia en la sociedad. No me queda claro aún si el final del castillo que se vio en Mirror of Fate es el mismo que se vio al inicio de LoS 2, y poco o nada nos entera sobre la descendencia de Simon Belmont. Lords of Shadow 2, como cualquier juego y secuela, tiene puntos en donde flaquea y donde es fuerte, me entristece decir que uno de los puntos donde flaquea un poco es el final, que es medio «meh», pero la historia general, la jugabilidad, los mapas, las gráficas, el sonido... es todo un banquete.

🌞 Logros en Steam.
🌞 Todo el juego está en español salvo los diálogos (que están en inglés), pero esos tienen subtítulos en español.
🌞 Tienes la posibilidad de jugar con teclado o control tipo consola. El juego te recomienda que uses el control.
🌞 Maravillosas gráficas y una banda sonora absolutamente magnífica.
🌞 Pese al escenario moderno, la ambientación es bastante obscura y sangrienta. Cuando estés a punto de matar a un enemigo podrás tomarlo y verás una cortísima escena que demuestra la brutalidad de Drácula.
🌞 Tiene muchas cualidades del LoS, como un álbum de ilustraciones (bellísimo, por cierto), una interfaz para que compres y veas tus técnicas (ahora hay muchas más).
🌞 Cuenta con una expansión (DLC comprable) que es «Revelations». No la he comprado aún, pero entiendo que es algo cortita.
🌞 Hay muchos rompecabezas y secretos por aquí y por allá (artes que debes buscar, memoriales con historias, cristales de magia del vacío, del caos y de vida, clavos de Kleidos para los desafíos).
🌞 Los desafíos ahora ya no son en cada nivel como en el LoS, sino que hay un área en particular cuyos niveles de dificultad (que son cuatro) deben ser desbloqueados con cuatro clavos de Kleidos cada uno. Algunos te darán ganas de pedir misericordia, otros son muy fáciles.
🌞 Las peleas con los jefes son geniales. Disfruté con casi todas ellas, pero sobre todo con las de el Juguetero y la de Carmilla... ¡ah, y también la de los espíritus de la tormenta!
🌞 La historia es muy atractiva, tendrás que luchar en el año 2057 y regresar al pasado para completar la historia y recoger objetos.
🌞 Las habilidades pueden subir de nivel y cada tanto puedes transferir la maestría al arma correspondiente (hasta un máximo de nivel tres) para hacer que dicha arma sea más fuerte.
🌞 Salvado automático.
🌞 Al haber sido LoS un universo alterno, LoS 2 viene a ser la continuación de dicho universo, por lo que los fanáticos más acérrimos de la saga deben andar con cuidado.
🌞 Hay otros DLCs para comprar.
🌞 Cuando termines el juego, podrás iniciar una Partida+ para que lo intentes en otro nivel de dificultad.

☠ No hay cromos en Steam.
☠ Pese a poder jugar con el teclado, hay momentos en los que es muy difícil llevar a cabo ciertas cosas. Por ejemplo, si bien en el LoS jugamos con Eventos Rápidos (Quick Time Events), era fácil si elegíamos el teclado porque el juego nos indicaba qué letra de este apretar; en LoS 2 no importa si elegiste el teclado, el juego te indicará que presiones un botón del control tipo consola, lo que puede causar mucha confusión y hacerte perder estos eventos, impidiéndote progresar. Por este motivo es que recomiendo ir a las opciones del menú y desactivar los QTE. Esto provoca que el juego sea MUCHÍSIMO más fácil, pero también te evitará muchos malos ratos.
☠ La cámara... Dios mío, no puedo dejar de mencionar esto. Si bien se mueve la mayor parte del tiempo apropiadamente, en los desafíos de Kleidos solía ser muy molesta la manera en la que se movía la cámara.
☠ El DLC de «Revelations» que cuenta parte de la historia de Alucard (Trevor) tiene un precio un poquito alto, lo que añadido al precio del juego base hace que sea un relativo lujo tener todo el juego.
☠ Los DLCs extras son más estéticos que otra cosa (disfraces para Gabriel). Hay uno que es una runa que permite transformar las reliquias en aquella que tú prefieras.
☠ Existe un glitch que puede aparecer de la nada y consiste en que se crean paredes invisibles que no te dejan cruzar puertas o subir a pisos superiores. No es común, me pasó solo una vez en todo lo que jugué, pero es molesto y se resuelve regresando al punto de control más reciente.
☠ No cuenta con una opción de salvado, solo con el salvado automático.
☠ Nuevamente no aprovecharon la posibilidad de crear un modo «boss rush» o «contrarreloj». Acá se pudo explotar muchísimo más considerando las grandiosas batallas con jefes que tiene.
☠ Los enemigos son algo repetitivos, no hay mucha variedad en ese aspecto.
☠ Los guardias del Apocalipsis. Son enemigos muy molestos y nunca tienes la oportunidad de vengarte de ellos.
☠ El desafío de Kleidos de Roland de Ronceval. No es que perjudique al juego pero... me lleva, cómo hincha las verijas ese desafío.
☠ El final del juego deja mucho que desear.

En breves palabras, recomiendo mucho Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2, tiene una jugabilidad muy amigable, una banda sonora envidiable y unas gráficas indiscutiblemente hermosa. Es un juego que, pese a sus flaquezas, se nota que ha sido hecho con cariño. Yo lo compré en oferta y no salió para nada caro, quizá deban esperar un poco para encontrarlo a buen precio, por lo que recomendaría que lo pongan en su lista de deseados y estén pendientes de él.

I'm going to start by saying that my overall experience with this game is more positive than negative. While there are a few issues that detract from the overall experience, they are not serious enough for me to not recommend the game. Some key points follow.

[list]
[*]The combat system is an evolution of the one in the first game, with significant refinements that make for a very smooth experience. For example, you can dodge and parry attacks even in the air. While the skill trees for each of the weapons may seem labyrinthine at first, if you put some thought into how they're structured and how each of the moves are executed, you'll start to realize how elegantly designed Dracula's moveset is. Gone are the difficult-to-execute combos in the first [i]Lords of Shadow[/i]; you now have a broad range of attacks that are easily performed with plenty of versatility for nearly any combat situation.
[*]Setting and environmental design is generally excellent. Both in the castle and in the city, there's a great sense of scale, and the level of detail put into the environment is absolutely incredible. Overall, it's designed in the open-world "Metroidvania" tradition, with plenty of exploration and discovery. Many level design cues have been taken from the [i]Assassin's Creed[/i] series, which isn't a bad thing since I've always liked their level design; likewise, when not in combat, Dracula himself handles a lot like Connor from [i]Assassin's Creed III[/i]. However, it is not completely flawless; ...
[*]...in particular, some of the stealth sections need improvement. While the ones involving Golgoth Guards aren't exactly bad, Agreus's maze and [spoiler]Carmilla's[/spoiler] blood curse puzzle are questionably designed, leaving the player very little room for error which can lead to frustration.
[*]The story is good, but not great. Dracula as a character has some very nice background but scenario design can be a bit better and the ending is a bit too open-ended.
[/list]

Again, neither of the last two points are enough to take away my recommendation. It's sad that these (relatively minor) flaws in an otherwise well-executed game led to such negative critical reception from several expert reviewers. Playing as the Prince of Darkness himself has been an unforgettable experience for me and I ultimately enjoyed the game. [b]Recommended.[/b]

22263727.review:
Castlevania Lords of Shadow 2
A wasted opportunity

Mercury Steam had the chance to close his Castlevania trilogy in a high note, with a golden lock, but instead, all it accomplishes is a terrible failure. I have not reviewed a game in a while but I really need to let out some steam. Lords of Shadow was a great game, a good incarnation of the Castlevania series and the first one to actually manage to pull a good game in 3D. With it's combat mechanics, it's boss fights and a story that I find quite interesting. The first Belmont turns out to be the one transforming into Dracula and the greater evil is Satan. Bravo!

Mirror of Fate was a good game, just that. It had a good story, the first time that the Belmont (Vampire Hunters) went on for Dracula's head and how Alucard came to be. Pretty original all around. But it can't compare of course with the first game. And then it came the trilogy closure. Lords of Shadow two. The first game to actually put you in the role of Dracula and in the present. At glance, it's an idea worth exploring, a finale worth telling; to know what happens to Gabriel Belmont now as Dracula and to see if Satan returns. Will Dracula find redemption? At least I know the game won't. The combat mechanics are the same as Lords of Shadow, but now instead of light and shadow magic you have a Void Sword (light) and Chaos Claws (Shadow). Not one change in the mechanics aside from that. If it ain't broke, why fix it?

But oh! Mercury Steam tried to step up the game with the world and the map. What a big mistake. The map, instead of being presented as the first game, in which you were advancing from place to place and you could revisit them whenever you wanted and relive the boss fights; now it's just a conglomerate mess. It deviates itself into a sort of open world with a map room every now and then in some locations that help you fast travel from place to place, but it is hard to keep track of where have you been and where you need to go to get all the upgrades. The map is divided in two: the city and the castle. What you may say? We are in the present day right? Yes! We are, but on that later.

The city is just dull. All grey, wherever you turn. Generic places, streets, alleys; only for a few landmarks where you fight bosses or big group of enemies. The presentation of the place is lame, it does not encourage the player to explore. The castle has some epic scenarios and places that vary from each other, one time you are on an underground city and another you are exploring a hall; and that's a good thing but unfortunately that is all. The enemies are generic as hell. The demon spawns are so generic and there are so few types of them that you feel like you are battling the same enemies all the game. It is another story for the castle, but nevertheless, there are not so many different types of enemies.

And here come the bosses. I don't know where to start. Let's see...
There are many bosses on this game and their design is great, but just two of them managed to wake my emotion battling them. The rest of them felt kind of cheap. Also, there aren't any or at least few mechanics whatsoever to kill them. You literally (aside some exceptions) can blast your way through them with brute force. What thing that was a big letdown was the final battle. I was expecting an epic clash and what I received was a boss battle that felt forced and a killing scene that couldn't be more lame, LAME with capital letters, do you hear me mercury steam?

Now, onto the point where you are Dracula, the prince of darkness, the dragon, the... Wait... Do I need to hide from this guys because I can't fight them? Do I need to turn myself into rats because of the fear to be killed by them? Am I not the Dragon? A force of darkness to be reckoned with? The one who vanquished Satan? 
Let that sink in. There are some parts of the game that put you up against some body guards of Satan and you can't fight them, you need to sneak past them transforming into rats or mist; I get it, Dracula can use those skills and I know that he is weakened by his long sleep but there is no part in the game that we face them directly in combat; but oh the final boss? Yeah sure bring it on! I am certain that after that fight, Dracula still needs to sneak from those bodyguards. So in a few words: you never really feel like the dragon.

And now, for the final part of this review and my conclusion: the story, if that thing can be called that. The story is just a convoluted mess. Mercury Steam clearly had no idea on how to develop the story and how to end it. The premise is a fantastic one: you are now Dracula and you are about to confront the lord of hell, Satan himself with acolytes around the city paving his way; also, there is something within his mind, dreams (I really don't know what was it) that draws you back to the castle, and when you are there you discover that a corrupted blood, a dark entity is trying to keep Dracula there for all eternity. The story, as I said before, is developed in the present day at Castlevania City and in the Castle. You travel from one another by portals around the world or when a vision comes to play or Trevor appears and guides you to the castle. 

So this was the ending of the trilogy, of Mercury Steam take on the franchise and what did they do with it? They blow it off. The story is weak, doesn't give a closure and nothing great happens. Dracula sets to stop Satan but ends in a very weak tone for this part and it is never explained why there was dark blood in the castle possessing the minions of Dracula, also it is never explained why you travel back to the castle.


In conclusion: this game is mediocre. All of it. The combat is the same as the first entry but you as a player don't need to develop it to conquer the game, there is no need for it. The map, the map is a mess. The bosses don't have any essence to them (in a story way) and have no mechanics whatsoever, just two or three of them. The premise of the story was amazing! It could have been taking through a glorious path and end on an epic note, but instead you get a story that feels dull and no closure at all.

Don't play this game if you haven't. Just stay with Lords of Shadow 1 and Mirror of Fate. This is a waste of your time.

Shortly: (trying no to tell any spoilers and and I didn't play the DLC: Revelations)
Basically, the game is a sequel for the original Castlevania: Lords of Shadow and the Castlevania: Mirror of Fate games, and it continues the story of Dracula (Gabriel Belmont) thousand years after the events of those 2 games.

The game is staged on a modern era, where Satan is once again trying to destroy the world of men with the help of his Acolytes.

Unlike in the original LoS game, this time the game is a openworld game, however you can only travel to new areas AFTER you've aquired a certain powerup to access them. And like in all openworld games, this one also has fast-travel system, but its pretty primitive.

There are 2 different worlds that you can travel, the modern era where the Satan's forcers brings havoc and the Dracula's Castle where the Dracula's own blood is trying to trap you.

Graphics are decent, sounds and voice actings are doreable. The battle system is slightly better than it was in the original LoS, but at the same time it feels a little bit watered down from what it was.

The overall story is a cliche, because you can easily predict that what's about to happen. However, it is interesting enough to see it through. The ending itself however was a disappointment for me, because there's no conclusion, but that's just my opinion.


Pros:
+ Battle and upgrade systems
+ Boss encounters (though the last boss was disappointment)
+ Lots of different enemies
+ Lots of collectables for those interested
+ Over 20 hours of gameplay if you collect every collectable like I did

Cons:
- Disappointing last boss
- Awful Fast-travel system (though you only need it when you're searching for collectables)
- Lots of annoying enemies at the end
- Bad ending (there's no conclusion in my opinion but then again I didn't play the revelations DLC)
- The Shop's location is bad, because getting some of the collectables requires a certain item that can only be bought from the shop, so you need to visit it a lot
- Kleido's Challenges offer no reward except a few Steam achievements
- Few un-skippable cutscenes and events such as the slow paced transition between the modern era - Dracula's Castle


Do I recommend ?:
If you're interested to see what happens to the Dracula after the events of Lords of Shadow and Mirror of Fate, then this might interest you. But if you haven't played those 2 games before, don't care about the story and are only interested for the action, then don't bother.

Verdict: 6 / 10 - Slightly good game

It's games like this that really make me wish Steam has 3 recommendation buttons: thumbs up / thumbs down / apathetic shrug. Because LOS 2 is far from the great game the first one was, but also isn't totally crap - I'd say it's about 60/40 on the quality divide.

If you played LOS 1 you'll recall it finished with a gob smacking reveal - that had me extremely curious as to how the developers would follow up on this audacious twist. As it turns out - not particularly well. It's a beat em up platformer just like the first, but in this case the camera is moveable - which makes a big, and unwelcome, difference as it is slightly too far out to see the action, and also gets obscured by the ridiculous amount of special effects that happen with EVERY attack.

The game begins back in ye olde days with Dracula's castle being attacked by a giant robot that looks like a building. At first I was like WTF  is that?? because it looks utterly stupid - until I remembered the Titans from LOS 1: those majestic towering elemental creatures that were so impressive. Well, this is one of those - except it's been put through the moronometer, and come out with totally dumb design. Technically impressive for sure, but so NOT Castlevania!

If you hated the liberties the first game took with the series design - you'll be frothing at the mouth over this one....and I'd probably best not mention it gets even worse when the game jumps back to the present day, because those bits will  likely cause your brain to explode in disgust. They annoyed me, and I wasn't bothered by LOS 1's changes. 

In the modern day bits you begin by traipsing through a pharmaceutical warehouse, beating up crates and plastic barrels - but not the enemies because you are too weedy after starving yourself of blood for hundreds of years. Yet there's a cutscene where Dracula gleefully murders a family of three - kid included - to regain some of his strength, and to show you how EVIL he has become...err, okay ...not really selling it so far (mainly due to Robert Carlylse's utterly shit performance), but whatevs!

Anyway, because you've become a total wimp  the first enemies you face have an enforced stealth aspect, which is pretty basic - and by the way, said enemies are big dudes in demonic armour with a gun bigger than you are.......Wot tha fudge?

Eventually you get through these dull encounters, and get sucked back into ye olde times - which thankfully are (a) much more enjoyable, and (b) less crap stylistically, though the first boss you face in this world isn't the greatest to look at. Duff them up, explore a bit more, and then...it's back to the crappy warehouse, traipse thru that some more, and it's back to ye olde world. The games a YOYO!!! Ye olde world =good, modern day=big bag'o'shito

Back in yon days of lore there's a bit with these creepy snake headed girls that's very....creepy, as they skitter about, and contort themselves in a fashion that really won't be doing their spine any favours. They're genuinely disturbing, yet at the same time it's such a pity the whole game seems incapable of maintaining the menace they exude. 

The boss battle that precedes this bit has an awfully written cutscene, that's very japanese (even though the devs are spanish...) With an overtly sexual demonic villainess who laughs like a demented walrus, and then says you make her wet....yeeeessss, ok then. The bizarrest thing about all this - the first game had Hideo Kojima involved and wasn't this bad, this time around he was nowhere near this game and it's even more Hideo Kojimaesque than Hideo Kojima. 

And, well, that's as far as I've got so far : that's an awful lot of crappy aspects for the first 3 or 4 hours of a game. There's still some enjoyment to be had with it, but it's a shadow of LOS's greatness and a horrendous treatment of Castlevania.
On the plus side - Patrick Stewart is much less awful this time around, so there's that. So, here goes - time to push the 'meh' recommend button, oh wait - there isn't one.

21896677.review:
Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 is lying to you, there are not Lords of Shadow in this game. But luckily there is a castle, so I guess it's not all bad. 
Okay, half a castle.

You play as Dracula...What, really? Yeah, you play as that guy you've been beating up since the 80's. Now, when I played Lords of Shadow I explained that I am not familiar with Castlevania outside of a little bit of Symphony of the Night. Now that I've played more than an hour of the original games I have a better understanding of the series. And now I come to you saying that Castlevania: Lords of Shadow as a series feels more like a fairly competent fan fiction than it's own universe.

After an annoying tutorial sequence, you wake up in the DISTANT FUTURE OF 1999, at least I think it's 1999. Dracula awakens form his long slumber looking much like I do after a Saturday night, minus the incredibly handsome. After getting beaten up by a large T-rex looking monster, you are saved by a man in armor  who's wielding a suspiciously Japanese looking sword, lets just call him Scrungus Humungous for now. 

So Scrungus takes you back to his master Zobek, who is Patrick Stewart but also a jerk. He tells you that Satan is using his Acolytes to revive him so he can dominate the world. Zobek tells you that if you can pull Satan out of hiding and defeat him, he will give Dracula the eternal rest he longed for. 

So yes, this game is about Dracula fist fighting Satan. 

I should probably explain the game now.

Much like the first game, LOS is a action beat-em-up much like God of War. You have three weapons, a whip, a sword, and your dukes, but your dukes are on fire, how rad is that? Both the sword and your fire fists are on a meter of sorts while your whip is good to go at any moment, not unlike a whip in that weird teachers basement. 

Your enemies come in different shapes and sizes, with a nice touch that they all have lore and back story to them. But other than a few special moves they all attack the same outside of the very few bosses you run into. Standard attacks can be both blocked and countered, leaving the enemy open for a critical attack. But every now and then, or more than often, all the time, the enemy will use a heavy attack which you will have to dodge. Outside of a few items and changing weapons on the fly, that's about as complicated as combat gets. 

So I'm going to say some bad stuff now.

Like I said before, I finally got familiar with Castlevania as a whole, and now a lot of elements just leave a bad taste in my mouth. Outside of Dracula originally being Gabriel Belmont (Spoilers by the way, if you've never watched any of the trailers), the Belmont lineage kind of gets turned into that soup the weird lady hands out down town. Dracula and Alucard (That's Dracula backwards) are both Belmonts and the rest of the lineage kind of takes a back seat.  Actual spoilers by the way.
[spoiler]You actually DO meet another Belmont named Victor, but he dies roughly 10 minutes after you meet him, so whatever. [/spoiler]

This is honestly kind of stupid, in the original series, Dracula was a man named Mathias Cronqvist, so not only did they change who Dracula actually IS but they also flat out replaced him with their own new character for the series: Gabriel. 

What was the point of this? I'm not in the fanbase but did anyone actually ask for Dracula as a playable character? It doesn't add anything because your best healing is the same healing you used in the last game because Dracula biting fools doesn't really cut it. If they really wanted you to play as a Vampire why didn't they just have you play as Alucard as you did in Symphony or that other part of Mirror of Fate? Alucard already plays better than his father does in the DLC and has a more interesting set of skills. 

Did they think that people really liked Gabriel so much as a character that they wouldn't want to move on to another Belmont? Perhaps continue the narrative in another way that doesn't include reusing an original character you made specifically for your reboot? It doesn't really even feel all that Castlevania like, really, outside of a few name drops and shout outs from previous games. 

And for a game with as much padding as Lords of Shadow 2, it sure as hell is rushed at the end. And by that I mean it just kind of ends, it's all over and then Dracula goes to take a nap. I'm not kidding, that's how it ends. Roll credits. I've watched bum fights with better closure than that. 

Should you play Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2: The Reckoning: Fury Road? 

This is actually hard. Because the game has a really strong start but then kind of fades away at the half way point. A lot of plot points are just kind of shoved aside or hand waved before the game comes to an end and it drags on just long enough for the combat to become frustrating and boring. Just like my sex life. 

But on the other hand, it's nowhere near as offensive as other reboots like, lets say, DmC, or my sex life. I just feel like it could have maybe cut out a lot of the fat and busy work and focused on it's strongest point. 

Just like my sex life. 


LOS2 is getting pass, but just barely, I would get it while it's on sale at five bucks or less. It's not great, but it's nowhere near as offensive as a lot of other reviewers made it out ot be. If you absolutely NEED a vampire game right at this moment, though? You can get the Legacy of Kain series for much cheaper.

Fortressmania 2: Kings of Shade gets 3 badly voiced sections from Symphony of the night out of 6. 

Dracula backwards is Alucard.

21166790.review:
Well if you're here then probably you have already looked up some "professional" reviews about this game. And most of them call it inferior to the series or just simply say it's mediocre. This game made me to stop listening to these reviewers. I didn't really want to buy it, but I fell in love so hard with the story they presented in LoS1 and MoF I needed to know the conclusion and I felt like I wouldn't be satisfied if I just simply watched it on YouTube. So here I am amazed by this fantastic game...

[h1]+Combat[/h1]
If you are coming from LoS1 (if not then please play it before this one) you already know the basics. They basically tightened it up, made it much more responsive and fluid then it was. There are new moves and combos, too. And this time we get a much more "user-friendly" skill page then in LoS1.

[h1]+Story and narrative[/h1]
These were the second biggest positives I encountered in this game (the 1st one is ofc the combat). Of course there are plot twists, and most of them hit hard (you know it's good when your jaw drops). There are many interesting characters; there will be some who you'll hate and many who you'll love. It made me care about a side-character in ~20 mins and when it turned out he may die I felt really bad. But the ultimate peak for me was the Toymaker. It is that kind of rare time in gaming when a good story and a well-imagined narrative meets. I won't spoil it for you, you have to experience it by yourself. And most importantly it got rid of that bad narrative element that they used in the 1st game, which made up every little thing so dramatic that it felt like it just changed the whole world, but in reality it had no impact on anything.

[h1]+Camera[/h1]
Thankfully they got rid of the fixed camera presented in the first game. Don't get me wrong, fixed camera can work pretty well (like the old Resident Evils), but a high-speed action came certainly doesn't need it. Surprisingly it's also dynamic. So like when you're just walking, it comes quite close to you (kind of like RE4). But during combat it goes much further so you can see better.

[h1]+Platforming[/h1]
Just like the combat, they kept it and made it better. Thanks to the accurate controls it's much more fluid and if you failed a lot of times during platforming in LoS1 (like me) than fear no more, it's much better. A little bat swarm will always indicate where you can jump to and during climbing you can (optionally) highlight where you can climb to.

[h1]+Soundtrack[/h1]
I know it's subjective, but it's still amazing. It's not that kind of music that you will download and listen to regularly. It just fits so well the game, that it greatly boosts its already good atmosphere. It's epic and beautiful at the same time. And when it needs to be, then it's emotional.

[h1]+Bosses[/h1]
They are pretty diverse and just enough challanging.

[h1]+Design[/h1]
The graphics are good, but the design is the thing that's important. When you're in the castle dimension it's simply breathtaking. Every little detail in every little painting and statue and thing in the castle...Everything feels just in place, that I risk that even in 8-bit it would still look beautiful. Now about the modern dimension...For a city design it looks good, but I couldn't wait to get back into the castle from the modern world.

And the list could go on and on (good portray of Dracula, references, etc.), but let's talk about some not that good aspects of the game.

[h1]+/-Stealth segments[/h1]
Now this is the most criticized part...I don't hate them but neither love them. It's all about if you mind being taken away from the fast-paced gameplay and use your brain and patience a little bit. But the biggest issue with these is the fact that mostly there's only one way to do them! But people hate it like it's all over the place but you have to be stealthy like 5 times in this game...But I loved the parts when I could be a rat, it still really gave me the feels of being smarter and more powerful then my enemies.

[h1]-No detailed map[/h1]
You get 2 kinds of map in this game: one that shows the districts and one that shows your surrindings.

[h1]-Rare bugs[/h1]
I encountered two kind of biggie bugs during my playthrough and I looked up if anyone else has encountered them and I didn't find anyone, so they must be really rare.


[u]In conclusion[/u]: As a fan of Hack 'n' slash games and the first two LoS games I have to say that this is a must have. The game is very well optimized, so no worries about that. It has it's bad moments, but they're still mediocre at worst. 
I love this even more than the 1st one actually. The story and drama feels kind of weak if you don't really care about it, but once you start to think about what just happened you'll be amazed. Don't listen to the critics (probably Konami just didn't pay for good reviews), this game deserves much more than that (8/10 minimum).

P.S.: I feel like it's needless to say about this kind of games, but a controller is strongly recommended (I played with a Steam Controller and it was very comfortable and precise).

I played both Lords of Shadow back to back. I definitely liked this game, and do wish there was a third ready to queue up.

Overall it was a great game, with amazing visuals, great story, and an amazing soundtrack. However, it was an interesting mix of strengths and weaknesses, some being very different than the 1st game. I would say that its 1st strength is how powerfully it started, I was drawn into the story immediately and even felt goosebumps as the 1st cut scene gracefully sets the stage of what Gabriel has become, complete in its gothic splendor of visuals, music, and of being loathed by the locals and probably even by himself. It’s the type of vampire that I wish could replace the entire Twilight series. If you’ve read the Anne Rice novels, I noticed many details that were alike.

The 1st hour was a blast, then come an hour of wondering if this game was going to turn horrible, followed with an awkward climb back to awesome, and luckily it stayed there til’ the end of the game.

The bad: There were many things that weren’t explained in the 2nd hour which made the story seem artificial, luckily everything started making sense as you put the pieces together yourself, that’s if you didn’t bail in the meantime and read every piece of lore you found. Often there wasn’t enough of a visual clue to know what to do next, I found myself running through the same halls over and over again, trying to find that one thing I missed and now I can’t move on. Finally, the final boss is Satan, and you never really fought him, and then he was “dead”. Game over, time for DLC-expansion. Just so awkward.

The end result is we have lots of 10/10 experiences mixed with subpar experiences, leaving you wanting more if you made it far enough to understand its style, but also hoping they’re learning from their mistakes and that they figure they’re shit out. I would probably relate my enjoyment to watching the beginning seasons of Dr. Who, of which they luckily got their shit figured out which is apparent in later seasons.

20588315.review:
I was not disappointed! Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 was an excellent sequel and just as good action adventure game.
So, this game tells what happened to Gabriel Belmont after the events of Castlevania: Lords of Shadow. Needles to say, [b]there are spoilers ahead[/b] and if you haven't played the first one, I have to ask why first and then I have to warn you that you should probably stop reading if you care for the story of the game. If you only care about the gameplay, keep on reading.
Also, what I would like to mention is that I will be comparing this game a lot to the first one since they are very similar and I already wrote a review on the eLords of Shadow, so if you don't like that, you should prolly read another review.

What I like about the sequel is that it keeps to its roots. Lords of Shadow 2 feels and plays very familiar, almost the same as the first game, but its just refreshing and innovative enough not to be a copy-paste of the original while still having that same good feeling of the first one. The main difference this time, story vise is that, instead of a holy warrior from the Brotherhood of Light, you are actually the Prince of Darkness, a powerful immortal vampiric being who, bitter and hateful because of how god "rewarded" him for his services and heroic acts, finds comfort and joy in terrorizing the mankind. Oh, and he goes by the name of Dracula :P

As for the gameplay, it still maintains that fast combat of the previous game, with a bit of tactics and different approaches to different enemy types but its a little bit changed and the fact that I can't really pick a favorite says a lot about them both. What I can say is that, the main difference now is, instead of having one set of moves with the Combat Cross(now called Shadow Whip) and two magic types to infuse it with, you now wield two additional weapons. A Void Sword to replace your Light Magic which heals you when you hit enemies with it, just like the Light Magic infused Combat Cross did, and heavy hitting Chaos Gauntlets that deal massive damage and break enemy armor upon impact, which replaces your Shadow Magic. These two slight changes make the combat a bit different but still try to keep it familiar. Other than that you can expect almost complete lack of stagger when attacking enemies. This can take a bit of getting used to especially if you play the game right after you finish the first one but still, it's not a big deal and after just and hour or so, you should get completely used to it. However, in terms of challenge, I have to admit that, the first game was much better since Lords of Shadow 2 feel very easy even when played for the first time on the highest(highest possible for the first playthrough) difficulty. There are challenges, yes, but they are more of a "figure out how to do it and its easy" rather than "I know how to do it but I simply can't do it due to its difficulty". I guess what I'm trying to say is that the challenges are more of a combat puzzles rather than combat skill mastery tests. Hope that makes sense to whoever is reading.

Another thing worth mentioning is that, instead of a level based progression system, we now have a big, connected map with zoning transitions, (kinda like old DMC games but with much more freedom). Now, I won't say its open world because that term is used way too often nowadays and gamers consider every non linear game with a hub like world design to be an open world game. This is not the case. While you are indeed free to roam the streets of the city/halls of the castle, within playable boarders, as you see fit, and backtrack whenever you feel like it, it is still a very linear game with linear progression system, but in case of this game, it's not a bad thing. Addition of a dynamic camera is also great and lets you take cool screenshots, look around this beautifully crafted world and just appreciate the artful and detailed environment that this game has to offer. As I said in the review of the original Lords of Shadow, playing it simply for its beautiful scenery is worth it!

All in all, this was a great game. I really took my time with it and tried to enjoy it as much as possible and kinda felt sad when I realized that its over. Gameplay time can be extended by doing challenges and trying to collect all the collectible items like upgrade gems, concept art and game lore scrolls and also by playing the Revelations DLC(which is fairly short TBH but a very good and quite different experience). So it should be clear by pretty clear that I will, 100% recommend this game to every action/adventure game lover, everyone who enjoyed the original Lords of Shadow as well as everyone who appreciates stunning visuals, detailed and beautiful game world.

Castlevania: Lords of Shadows 2 es un hack and slash como el primero, pero desarrollado en un mundo más o menos abierto que le otorga cierto componente de exploración y plataformas, a diferencia de su antecesor que se dividía en misiones cerradas. Mejora el combate de forma sustancial y, a grandes rasgos, es mucho más divertido que el primero.

Es estéticamente bastante bonito, aunque ningún portento gráfico. Eso sí, funciona en máquinas muy antiguas sin problemas. La música es de gran calidad y el doblaje también es loable, salvo el personaje de Alucard que, en mi opinión, es más soso que un huevo sin sal.

Si el juego es bueno, entonces, ¿por qué ha sido tan machacado por la crítica? Bueno, es discutible y, en el fondo, no llego a entenderlo muy bien. Es cierto que Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 no es ninguna maravilla pero, dentro de su género, supera claramente a otros como DmC, el cual le saca la friolera de 27 puntos en metacritic (nada merecidos, por cierto). Es cierto que añade fases olvidables, especialmente las conocidas vulgarmente como de "sigilo", que, sin ser especialmente malas, sencillamente sobran y el juego estaría mejor sin ellas. Más allá de eso, no tiene ningún fallo destacable por lo que el 58 que tiene en metacritic es, a todas luces, un ejemplo de cómo la prensa especializada a veces se ceba contra un juego en concreto o contra un estudio. En este caso, pienso que es contra el estudio completo porque Mirror of Fate también fue aplastado, a pesar de ser un juego competente.

Volviendo al juego en sí que, como leéis, sí merece la pena (aunque no sea una maravilla), cabe destacar que la historia está a la altura de la del resto de los juegos de la saga. Es decir, que es bastante floja. Pero bueno, si juegas a videojuegos para disfrutar de grandes historias desde luego deberías hacértelo mirar (por supuesto, haberlas las hay pero no es el foco de interés principal de un videojuego, obviamente).

En definitiva, un Hack &  slash (de mundo abierto), lineal eso sí, muy divertido pero con algunas partes que sobran. Mejora, y mucho, el sistema de combate del original y, en general, todo él se desarrolla como un juego mucho más orgánico y pulido. Una pequeña gema en bruto del género, sin llegar a la altura de los referentes, como Bayonetta, pero superando holgadamente a los falsos profetas como DmC.

The game was alright overall, but it's a poor man's Arkham game. The story of the main game was interesting and the art style is fantastic, but the gameplay and combat system actually got quite annoying near the end, when trying to get all the collectables.

Part of the problem is the level design which is a non-obvious corridor, where areas are separated by a multitude of sluice-gates, elevators, decontamination rooms, etc. It's constant delaying and unnecessary gratuituous animations which get boring rather quick. It takes a very long time to navigate between areas and respawning mobs often prevent you from leaving before you dealt with them, even though you have nothing else to gain from killing them. Once I got the final secret collectible, it took me something like 20 minutes to get to the area where you trigger the final boss encoounter.

Unlike the Arkham games where collecting additional content is enjoyable and adds to the experience, the design of the levels actually takes enjoyment away. I would recommend doing a story driven run and avoiding backtracking for collectables and challenges.

The music is OK on it's own, but doesn't fill inspired as much as the art style and often doesn't really fit the environemt or add much to the game.

The PC port is pretty bad. You pretty much need a controller, as all the button prompts are laid out for a 360 pad. It's much worse than the first game which you could play with KB/Mouse perfectly fine. The game runs well and stable, but it's absolutely impossible to tab out. You need to trigger an automatic save, which often happens between areas, but isn't reliable, and quit the game.

Lastly, something that bugged me personally. You frequently either fight or partner up with humnoid characters. They have about 3 phrases each on average and will keep shouting them non-stop. Gets seriously annoying.

5/10
[b]tl, dr version:[/b] A cash in on the franchise one more time.
Awful story that has ruined the heart of Castlevania as a game franchise. Decent graphics and responsive gameplay, but heavily mired by a flawed combat system. Still perhaps worth getting if on sale for the mindless smash enemies combat. Great voice acting from the main actors, but less should have been put in to the voice acting and instead spent on developing a real story that respects the franchise mythology. Big thumbs up, the scourge of modern games, QTE's, can be disabled permanently.

[b]Long Version:[/b]
[u]Story[/u]
Awful to put it simply, it's a train wreck. Castevania is at its heart a conquer the castle and kill Dracula game, this "re-origin" story series has just wrecked that with taking away everything that is Castlevania in exchange for trying to dramatise the backstory of Dracula to make him a tragic hero; with an overwhelming judeo-christian mythology shoehorned in to dominate the mythological aspects whereas previously the series was only very loosely tied to any particular mythology. The whole story was just 'Ugh, it's the devil is the bad guy story, how original...push that religion on us even more'.We are meant to believe the city is built on the ruins of Castlevania (dont even get me started on that nuke effect taht was shown large enough it would have destroyed several ENTIRE EUROPEAN COUNTRIES), and the devils kids would use that spot to try bringing about their dad's return...ofcourse. Use the site your ancient enemy is at his most powerful as your base of operations.....yep, perfect sense. 

Major plot holes exist *spoiler* e.g. Zobek could have read Drac's mind to discover his deception unless he lost his memories, but Zobek couldnt realise that his lieutenant had been replaced by Alucard by, oh I dont know...reading his thoughts....yeah, sure. I call bullshit. 

The deal with Castlevania itself is never really clarified, is the castle real and split off from the modern era dimension, or just a figment of Drac's fragmented mind....Major problems arise with the story regardless of which it is.
The story is jsut a cavalcade of bad ideas. 

[u]Gameplay[/u]
Tight controls that function decently for getting around and in combat. Probably the aspect of the game that is most positive. The grappling aspects are a disappointment, see that you can only use fixed grapple points to get around, instead of simply making anything that is like a ledge able to be hung from, and the game is loaded with invisible walls which is hugely disappointing for exploration. The game is heavily walled in and you will find that you are limited to very selective above street level areas, and street level, if you want to go explore over the rooftops of the city like some real badass vampire god, forget it, go buy a copy of Batman arkham city, a game which did city exploration properly.

[u]Combat[/u]
The combat is broken down into mobs using 3 types of attacks: range, melee blockable, and melee/range unblockable.
You have 3 weapons, a whip, sword adn claws. All with varying utility, the whip is a mid range weapon that is usable for building up 'focus' which when you hit 100% then attacking enemies will cause them to drop little gems that can be absorbed for magic power for your sword or claws, this only works with the whip though so you will spend a lot of time using it. Void sword burns magic and leeches life on hit, while the claws also burn magic but deal high damage and destroying shields and armour. The shields and armour shit was a terrible implementation, mobs can stand there blocking forever if you dont destroy the shield or armour, forcing you to use the real core combat mechanic, "timed counters" where you hit L2 at the right time in their swing to block an attack and stun them for a second and smash away, this builds huge focus so you can get your claws powered up to break the shields, alternateively you can somersault over attacking monsters and smack them in the back, whatever works. Unfortunately unless you are good at it, you are fucked, having spent significant time playing dark souls it was piss easy to time compared to parries in DS, but often if you are using the void sword or claws the actual enemy attacks get obscured by the flashy animations of the glowing weapons that you dont see them, this is a shit implementation really forcing play where you dont really engage upclose with magic weapons you mainly use a couple of specific moves then go back to the whip.

There is though a mechanic of "unblockable attacks", which is a huge flaw in the combat and you are forced to dodge, these attacks are indicated, but seems like lazy design, especially when you come to the bosses who their attacks are pretty much all unblockables or range attacks other than usually 1 blockable melee attack, this menas you can spend boss fights frustrated and magic starved as the range attacks keep you away, and the unblockables are chained so often the fight is 30 seconds of dodging and waiting to get one block and some melee attacks, absorb some magic and hit them a couple times for reasonable damage as the whip does fuck all. In this way the game lends itself to securing really only a couple of the actual skills for the sword and claws to 'gg no re' your way through the game, namely: Whirlwind for the Void Sword, and Flame Claws for the Chaos Claws. Both expensive to use but when you see them in action it's pretty much a no brainer to use them. You may simply discover the other method which is boss cheese and basically forces you to pop relics such as ensnared demon then go crazy with the inifnite magic while timer counts down (spam those flame claw attacks, for real, ~300 damage per hit on everything), then when it runs out pop the dragon emblem and finish the boss off, takes about 30secs per boss fight, even on PoD difficulty and is almost zero effort (you may have to use the void sword to freeze bosses to spam them hard with the claws).

Skipping combat and bypassing trash is often impossible, as pretty much every enemy has some sort of range attack intended to knock you off a hang point if you try to grapple away. Some monsters (the wraith type guys at the end msotly) have ridiculous bullshit attacks that you cannot do anythign to avoid and hit extremelyhard, as noted, the wraiths, tey have a lightning attack that will hit you from 50 metres away, is practically instant hit and dodging it not really possible as by the time you see it, it is hitting you, and there is no way to defend against it other than popping the sword or claws shield magic. As these creatures fight in packs of 4-6 generally, you can imagine, Drac at max HP has about 300 hp, and lightning hit's for 40 each time....6 of them will kill you in about 3 secs, faster than you can close the distance to get to them sometimes....

Also, finally, the camera is terrible, even with "combat assisted", it is awful and seems like it tries to blind spot enemies, and the trash monster scripts seem they are intent on getting behind the camera when they can to hit you in the back. This because truly frstrating when their seems to be no 'free camera' even when assist is off and the camera constantly tries to centre in ways that make no sense and you often spend as much time trying to correct the camera so you can see wtf is happening as actually paying attention.

[u]DLC[/u]
Revelations has good puzzles, but disappointingly cruel end boss fight due to endless unblockable attacks and mechanics that dont work with the camera (teleporting behind and unblockable charge).

[u]Conclusion[/u]
Is the game worth buying? Not at full price, it seems like an effort to just milk some more money out of the Castlevania fans who are holding on to hope that each release will be the next Symphony of the Night. Something which the LoD series just hasnt been anything near, ultimately this game is completely forgettable.

18024279.review:
This game is kind of a mixed bag with me, so I'll just list the pros and cons.

[h1] Pros[/h1]

[b]+Gameplay[/b]
The gameplay is quite a bit improved from the first game; camera is no longer locked, climbing is easier, items are actually useful this time, and there's items dedicated to helping you uncover secrets. I'm also quite fond of the openness, allowing you to go back at virtually any time to explore, collect items, etc.

[b]+Graphics[/b]
Visually, the game is beautiful, and there's plenty of areas in the game that are simply stunning. Found myself taking in the view more than once.

[b]+Combat[/b]
The mastery system rewards using different skills to enhance your weapons' power. Each of Dracula's weapons have their own specific use, similar to the first game, but are more than just enchanting your whip with magic this time around, giving you entirely different movesets for each weapon. Also you get to drink your enemies' blood.

[b]+Music[/b]
The music of the first game was good, but it lacked any sort of memorability. The music in Lords of Shadow 2 is much better, although you'll hear a lot of the same tracks over and over. Somewhat of a hit and miss here, but a majority of the music is good enough that this is more of a pro than a con.

[b]+Pacing[/b]
There was a lot of nothing in between the major events of the first game; the pacing was just kinda crap, in all honesty. There always seems to be something going on in LoS 2, it's easier to feel like you're actually doing something rather than roaming through some ruins without much of a goal, which was a major problem throughout the first third of the first game.

[b]+Gabriel is More Interesting[/b]
I was completely incapable of feeling any sort of sympathy for Gabriel in the first game. He was a cardboard cutout of a character devoid of most emotion. In this one, however, he's a little more interesting simply because he is fairly PO'ed. Also he's the dark lord, he has a reputation to live up to. Thankfully, he does.

[b]+Environment[/b]
As previously mentioned in the Graphics, the game is beautiful. The environment is also essential for this as well; for the areas that they created, the world is detailed and interesting. Areas are distinguishable from other places, and the concept of building a city on the ruined foundations of Dracula's castle is, honestly, quite interesting. It creates a distinctive gothic-type city that still seems reminiscent of Dracula's castle pre-ruin when you have opportunities to overlook the city.

[b]+Lore[/b]
While the story blows (more on that later), it does have some intriguing lore to find, some of which indicating that the people of Castlevania City are fully aware that monsters and magic are a thing. It's definitely a turn from the original Castlevania games and other games such as Vampire: The Masquerade- Bloodlines where hiding the supernatural from the world was of the utmost importance. In Lords of Shadow 2, I find it intriguing that they accept, and are even fascinated by, the fact that there used to be werewolves, vampires, and even the siege against Dracula are merely documented as history and treated as such. Their history is as natural to them as our own is to us. This is certainly something I'd love to see expanded on in future games- maybe not Lords of Shadow, but other franchises where the supernatural is merely embraced as a part of history rather than hidden from the world for safety. 


[h1] Cons[/h1]

[b]-It's Not Castlevania[/b]
You can add the title, give the characters the names, and everything else, but it still doesn't make it a Castlevania game. Let alone it's horridly out of place with half of the game taking place in a modern day city. To be perfectly honest, it feels more like Darksiders than Castlevania due to the themes throughout the game. The heart and spirit of the series is completely absent from Lords of Shadow, hence I only ever refer to it as Lords of Shadow.

[b]-Story[/b]
I find it ironic that they rebooted Castlevania with an intended focus on story, and then ended up dropping the ball. The first game had an okay, albeit not-very-original story with Satan having Necron Syndrome and popping up literally out of nowhere at the end. Mirror of Fate was an atrocity of a game and explained jack squat. Similar problems are in LoS 2- Gabriel often finds himself back in what appears to be either the past of his memories of his castle. Honestly have no idea because it's [i]never explained at all[/i]. His memories/past/whatever-the-fudge-is-going-on also has zero relevance to what's going on, aside from getting back his powers because reasons. There's also some Resident Evil bullcrap going on where the citizens are mutated by some demonic virus; this is so out of place it hurts. Everything else is fairly easy to follow, and there's some interesting things that do happen throughout the game, but it's nothing to write home about. Story is honestly not a good reason to play this game, and if it's what you're looking for, turn the other way.

[b]Gabriel forgot how to Open Doors[/b]
Found a door? Guess what? You're going to have to pull a switch to open it. He's only a superhuman Prince of Darkness, godforbid he opens a metal door on his own. There's a lot of this crap that just slows the game down needlessly, especially since it takes [i]forever[/i] for said doors to open. This game was made in 2014, this is rather inexcusable.

[b]-Enemies can be Annoying[/b]
There's a guard/perfect guard mechanic in the game, which is quite useful. Unfortunately, roughly 50% of the time, the enemies perform an unblockable attack, which renders guarding a lot less useful than you'd like it to be. Also there's plenty of times where I simply wanted to get somewhere and didn't want to fight. Going places often involve climbing. Guess what? [i]Every freaking enemy in the game can use some kind of projectile to knock you down,[/i] often forcing you to fight enemies when you don't want to. This is often infuriating when you merely want to explore for upgrades and other hidden items.

[b]-Stealth Segments[/b]
Okay, I get that he's weak and whatnot at the beginning, but this just seems so unnecessary. Especially since the stealth segment with Agreus is absolutely infuriating.

[b]-Bugs[/b]
Every now and then, characters may "say something" without sound- basically the sound file for the line they're supposed to say doesn't play (no subtitles either, which is even more aggravating). I've had other instances where the objective was the last objective I just did, and wasn't up to date. Worst of all, I've had it crash on me for no reason once.


[h1] Final Verdict[/h1]
While the story is laughable, the stealth is pointless, and bugs are afoot, the game is actually quite fun. I do not recommend it at full price; wait for a Steam sale to get it because $40 is a bit much for some of the frustrations of the game. Gameplay-wise, it's pretty good, despite the annoying gameplay oversights. Worth getting if you're interested in, or at least play the demo first to know if you'd like it.

17287050.review:
While not quite what I'd wanted after the first game in the series (and Mirror of Fate,) this is a good place for a semi-closing chapter.  Without any spoilers, a lot has happened since Gabriel Belmont originally set out to kill the Lords of Shadow and Do Good Things.  And this is a worthy addition to that story.  But what we see here is literally centuries after everything that happens in the other two games, and that gap feels kinda weird.  I suppose it's all explained via flashbacks and things, but even still.

Lords of Shadow 2 improves on anything the first game did that needed improving, while not messing with 95% of the things about that game that worked great already.  And it THANKFULLY brings back one continuous world that you can explore as you see fit.  Physically walking back to an area with a new power to get a thing you saw but couldn't reach makes sense; selecting an earlier chapter from a menu in the first game, and running into characters and even bosses that are already DEAD... not so much.

That said, the tone of the two games is much different.  This one doesn't ride on Hope so much.  Some might like the darker story, but personally I thought that it was a little somber and depressing at times.  It was all well told, and Robert Carlyle and Patrick Stewart knocked their roles out of the park, but I think that the darker universe just kinda took a toll on things.  We'll be visiting different environments, but gone are the sunny paths, baked desert-scapes, and clear skied mountain fortresses of the first game.  Here you get plenty of variety, with stormy locales, night cityscapes, fiery caverns, frozen mountainsides... but you'll never be doing anything during the day.  That's understandable, as Story Reasons require you to get everything done in one night.  And hell, Castlevania games usually all happen indoors, in one night, IN Dracula's Castle, so I can't fault it too much for grim, darkness.

Powers work better in this game than the first.  Alternate weapons/magic/sub-weapons, all that stuff is great.  In the first game, I found myself doing everything with the whip, and never bothering to use my daggers, fairies, or dark crystal.  I used Holy Water to deal with BS waves that got boring, but when I used sub weapons or items here, it was all strategic and useful.  Especially in the Kleidos Challenges.

Kleidos Challenges are unlockable (and thankfully optional) challenges that put you in a circular area with various enemies.  And there are three objectives, different to each challenge.  You might get, say, don't break any shields, don't use the Void Sword, and don't recover health by any means during the fight.  There's always the same 4th objective: do all three in the same run.  I did more than half of these before I got annoyed, and then just stopped.  For the super-hardcore, this is your kind of thing.

Collectables are EVERYWHERE!  Kinda literally.  I've found 3 or 4 things in the SAME ROOM, sometimes I needed different powers for each... and sometimes when you find the first collectable, it's actually only half-way down a secret path, and going just a little farther will find you a hand-hold to climb or sneak or do something to get to another.  I liked that, using one power-up as a distraction so you'll think you've got it and miss out on the next one.

Speaking of those collectible powerups, the come from two major things: Pain Boxes and Piles of Sacrifice.  The Pain Box is a box with a mouth that cuts or stabs your wrist when you stick your hand in, but then you get a Health, Void, or Chaos shard to raise your HP or Void or Chaos magics!  The Pile of Sacrifice is a little statue of a dude with a big curved sword over his shoulder, and you slice your wrist on it, bleed a LOT into the bowl beneath it, and then the bowl gives you either a capacity upgrade for 5 of your 6 relics or a Kleidos Nail, to get them Kleidos Challenges unlocked.  Don't worry if hunting for all this sounds annoying: you can pick up or shop for Dodo Eggs, and using one will mark the nearest collectible on your map.  It was fun for me hunting these down, though I did Dodo around... 15 of the game's nearly 200, just because I was at the end and wanted to get everything before I hit the last area.

Some people say that the bosses here aren't as good as the first game.  True, for the most part, but at the same time not true.  They're very different.  The first game's bosses were huge and awesome, but had some HIGHLY scripted ways to beat them, and most ended in a series of Quick Timing Events.  Here it's more a real fight, relying on your gameplay skills.  QTEs have been dialed back A LOT from the first game.  Lords of Shadow 1 must have something like 800% as many as this one does.

So I'll conclude here saying that this is a solid game with a cool story, and voice acting from two guys who do very good work.  Definitely, without question worth a buy on sale, and honestly even worth a buy at normal price if you're into Castlevania stuff.  But as a caveat, you might want to get the first game and Mirror of Fate HD first, as this is one epic overarching story, and though they do a pretty good recap at the beginning here, you want to be attached to the characters and the world first.  It makes this much more powerful.

Here's hoping they make the intended third and final game, and round everything out as incredibly as I hope.
