It usually happens I find myself torn between a diamond in the rough and problematic technical or some other aspect of the game, but with Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 it's somewhat different. Time to see if I can put into somewhat coherent paragraph or two as to why that's the case.

Let's start off by saying I was one of the people who enjoyed the original Lords of Shadow for what it was – not necessarily a creatively original masterpiece, but a game of astounding production values, competent writing and tight narrative punctuated by stellar voice work and lastly, and perhaps most importantly, it was a very meaty game which lead to some even saying it was too long for its own good. Fast forward to sequel and you can see it basically falters in each of these categories.

Interestingly enough game seems to swing between two polar opposites with its visuals because on one hand you have this classic Castlevania look comprised of foreboding yet mystical gothic castle to romp through, as well as its assorted menagerie of beasties to but heads with and solve painfully few puzzles compared to the first game, but on the other you have to contend with extremely bland modern-day warehouses and science laboratories ad nauseam alongside some fairly uninspired enemies ranging from more classical demons and Satanists to, what really should've been more interesting that ended up, futuristic soldiers and cybernetic abominations roaming the streets. But honestly, it's this weird disjointed narrative that undoes the game the most in my mind because you can clearly tell there was meant to be more there instead of just going from A to B and meandering in-between retreading locations with nothing but brief radio contacts from time to time. And lastly – game is simply short compared to the first one and that probably ties into my previous point. Rumors abound regarding game's troubled development were apparently well founded. 

That's not to say game is bad because, as you will have most likely noticed despite my continued rambling on regarding its negatives, this is marked as a positive review overall. It's still Lords of Shadow and if you liked the original you'll probably like this considering you can overlook its weak story. Gameplay feels familiar and skippable QTEs are god-sent, both of which are points in game's favor for me, not to mention combat and item system was expanded and enemy variety despite their designs actually means you'll end up facing quite a bit of different behaviors. Story establishes the mood very early on as one of Dracula's somber and more resigned journey, one profoundly personal despite all other events that unfold over the course of the game. Had it been properly fleshed out and Robert Carlyle's more subdued performance given time to develop, occasional hamfisted melodrama notwithstanding, it would've been a much, much better final product. I also heard some nay saying about mandatory stealth sections in the game to which I say it's about time to drop hand-holding. Barring for one section involving leaves and crazed Satyr these were a welcome diversion for me and fitting considering MC's condition story-wise.

One last caveat I feel should be posted is that playing the original game and Mirror of Fate is recommended before tackling the sequel.

17012922.review:
8.5/10
Overview: Third Person Action Adventure 

The Good

+ The setting is a mixture of a modern city in ruins and Draculas old castle. Both settings provide a nice contrast with each other and are fun to explore

+ The first major difference from the original is the ability to control the camera as opposed to having a fixed camera in the first game. 

+ The second major change is all the levels are interconnected with each other. This provides for a much more immersive and seamless experience with gameplay. 

+ Combat is more refined than the original and just as fun. You have light magic that does less damage but heals you whenever you damage an enemy and chaos magic that does significantly more damage but is slower and has less range. Effectively dodging and switching between your magic meters is fun and engaging. If you played the first game, the combat should offer little surprise to you. One key difference is by using attacks over and over again you can increase your mastery of a certain weapons making them stronger. 

+ Boss battles have always been a highlight for this series and this game is no exception. Bosses are unique, well designed and will require you to use all your techniques in battle to defeat them. 

+ the game has plenty of collectables scattered throughout the world

+ The game features 16 optional challenges to further extend your game time. Each challenge has a series of objectives that has to be completed in order to complete the challenge. 

+ option to disable quicktime events 


The Average

The story is not awful but it didn't really do much either. It doesn't help that most of the dialogue spoken by the villains is bad. 

This game has some REALLY annoying enemies that will test your patience


The Bad

For some odd reason the developers decided to include stealth sections in the game. I like stealth games and I like it when developers try to mix up the gameplay but this was just a bad effort. The stealth sections feel very out of place and are not always clear in what you have to do making for some really frustrating trial and error. It also feels very odd that you play a badass destroying most enemies in your path only to reach a section in the level where you have to avoid enemies. 


Conclusion

This game fixed two of my biggest gripes from the first game. The fact that the levels are interconnected and the ability to actually control the camera make for a much better gameplay experience despite the awful stealth sections. I was a bit baffled that reviewers panned this game pretty badly as I think this game improves the first game in many ways. If you enjoyed the first game then there is no reason why you shouldn't love this game as well, unless of course the modern day setting doesn't appeal to you.

16920298.review:
To be perfectly honest, if you want more Lords of Shadow, you're better off replaying the first game.

I feel this one really missed the mark, and after reading about the internal struggles of the development team and their near-constant battle with their director, I can say I'm not really surprised.

Lords of Shadow 2 is, in every way, inferior to its predecessor. Graphically, it fails to impress. Mechanically, it feels sloppy. The combat is frustrating and choppy and, while LoS1 had its fair share of controller-throwing platforming segments, LoS2 doesn't even justify its own such moments with an equal helping of fun, satisfying ones. I have only put a couple hours into the game so far, and already I'm mad at it. I cannot comment on the overall story yet, but the beginning feels rushed and strange, and I have to feel bad for Patrick Stewart being forced to deliver such a petty script as Zobek. The writing is childish and uninspired, and the semi-animated lore sequence explaining the Belmont lineage is utterly boring.

But you know, I could forgive all of that if the game didn't so completely miss its own point. At no time during play did I ever FEEL like Dracula, who is supposed to be an absolute powerhouse, combining strength, speed, and magical abilities to devastate ranks upon ranks of foes. The most basic of enemies can take a monumental beating from any of your weapons, and can even attack straight through your combos to strike you. One minor strike from an enemy, however, will interrupt your combo and send you flying, which makes your stature feel pitiful, even if you aren't taking significant damage from those attacks. These problems are only magnified and exacerbated when, after the tutorial sequence, the story fast-forwards some centuries and resets all of Gabriel's powers, requiring you to slowly unlock them, one by one.

Other games have successfully portrayed their protagonists as extremely powerful beings without robbing the game of its core challenge. A great case in point is Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine. Lords of Shadow 2, however, takes the legendary Dracula and nerfs him into the ground, and then poops all over him with bad gameplay mechanics.

I'll say it again: if you want more LoS, play the first game again, because you'll enjoy it a whole lot more.

15402855.review:
This is a very, VERY good game!  Take note that this is a review from a gamer that ACTUALLY read all the memorials, did not skip a scene, took the time to look at statutes, arts and building structural designs, and all the back stories in every description. I also take this game as it is, instead of relating it back to any other Castlevania, such as Symphony of The Night or the first LoS.  

10/10 would recommend this game, and here's why: 

Pros

1) The story is amazing.  As I dig deeper into the story, I feel I can relate to some of the characters, know why they did what they did, and that is important! Some may argue that the ending is dull, I personally think that it is fitting.  Reading the memorials help me understand how the modern era portrays the world and history.  

2) Voice acting is phenomenal.  They not only fit the characters, they brought out the emotions of their characters and made the story more colorful. 

3) The soundtrack is amazing as well. 

4) The city and castle designs are amazing.  While it is set in a modern world close to ours, it also retain some original castle structures that makes sense to remain there.  The castle is, well, Dracula's castle, and it is beautiful.  The texture of the stone/wooden floors, ceilings, and walls are so detailed that they are worth admiring, one could feel that this is not a simple copy-and-paste world.  I actually took time to look at statutes from different angles, just to admire them.  The world is interconnected, different routes to a place is possible.  

5) Game's free-camera-control is great, and the combat is fluid. 

6) I love it when in Dracula's rat form.  While some will argue it's necessity (Dracula too powerful to be a rat), it gives me a different view of the city.  What amazes me is that despite everything being bigger, the texture of the world is still amazing (floor tiles, walls and cables)!  So what he turns into a rat? He's a fucking Dracula! 

7) The most controversial part of the game: Argreus.  I like the stealth part in his maze.  Again, many people would argue that since Dracula is so powerful why the sneaking and the one-shot-kill? Ever heard of Pan's Labyrinth? Well, Argreus IS Pan's brother, so it makes sense that a maze like that would be his world, and the one-shot-kill is justified.  That is why we have to make it past the maze to a higher ground where it is not a maze to fight him.  Savvy? 

Cons

1) The stealth system is flawed.  While bat swarm works on certain enemies (only on the red armored marine if I recall correctly), most of the time when you use it sneaking up on an enemy, it just draws attention to every enemy in the vicinity to focus on you (once you use it, they know where you are).  

2) Despite having so many different skills, as the game progresses, skills will become less useful.  Some enemies are so aggressive that you just don't have time to use different attacks without being knocked down first.  I ended up using basic attacks in most of the situation.  

Overall, this is a great game.  You will be missing out if you rely your decision to buy this game on unprofessional critic's opinions about this game.  Hell, reviewing a game ain't even close to my profession, but after seeing some negative reviews of this game, and after personally playing it, I feel compelled to write something to justify the unjust.  After all, it's really about whether you had fun or not about a game, right?

15168173.review:
Lords of Shadow 2 is a very good, but not quite a great game. It has some flaws, but it has fun gameplay and a rich atmosphere. It's mostly a character action game with some Metroidvania style exploration elements.

Firstly, the good stuff. Most of the time playing this game you will be either in combat with enemies, or exploring the world. Combat is very fun and engaging, albeit not the deepest of the genre. It can't rival the likes of Platinum's work, but still creates a fun system that keeps you wanting more. It has a nice rhythm to it as it requires you to always keep an eye on enemies and properly timing blocking to keep your combo up, which is crucial for the "Focus" system. This system is also what gives you the power needed to use two of the three main weapons. These two weapons also have special effects, such as freezing enemies or burning away their armour, but break your Focus. It creates this flow to combat that feels very fluid and back-and-forth, meaning you can't get lazy and just endlessly wail on enemies without opposition, especially on higher difficulties. The different weapons also feel distinct from each other outside of their special effects. They each have different range, speed, and power, and there are plenty of combos in each weapon that all have a use in different combat situations, which are unlocked in an RPG style experience system.

The aesthetic of the game is also great. Everything has a dark and intricate look to it, with stunning Gothic architecture and really interesting world and boss design. The soundtrack is also fantastic, with a sweeping orchestral sound that fits the melodramatic and dark feel of the game. This makes simply being in the game world and moving around it a lot of fun. It does a good job of helping you soak in the atmosphere, both in and out of combat. The kinaesthetics too, are fantastic. The weapons all have a very satisfying feel to them. A sense of power and impact, but also vibrancy. They leave trails colour that arc around in the air as you swing your weapons, or explosions when they hit enemies. Some of the more powerful moves are especially impressive in how they surround you in a storm of whirling lights that destroys everything in the area.

The structure of the game world is pretty interesting as well, and quite unique for the genre. Unlike the first game in the Lords of Shadow series, this game is set in two moderately sized Metroidvania-like overworlds. It is somewhat inspired by the traditional Castlevania style of level design, but isn't really the main focus of the gameplay here. Yet it still manages to achieve this feeling of place to the game world. You can explore around seamlessly without any loading screens, and many areas are connected, and sometimes loop around on each other. This also aids the sense of atmosphere to the game, and gives the game much better pacing than the first as well. Here you're not thrown back to the main menu to sit through a long loading screen every fifteen minutes. But despite its interconnected nature, main story progress through the game world is mostly pretty linear. Apart from a few specific points, you won't be revisiting older places unless you go out of your way to find upgrades and collectables. It's not as dense and maze-like as some older Castlevania games, but for what it brings to the type of game it is, it's a great addition.

There are also some areas of the game which are clearly lacking, though they are not anywhere near significant enough to ruin the experience.

Firstly, there are the much lamented stealth sections. These are pretty bad, but not game-breakingly so. They feel half-baked and somewhat forced in to the game, by taking away your ability to fight while entering a stealth section. The mechanics of the stealth sections are also shallow, and it’s not exactly clear when you are detected or not. When you are, although it's not an instant failure, it might as well be, given that you will be attacked by enemies that can kill you in two hits or so, even with all the health upgrades. But even so, these sections are relatively rare. They make up only what is probably 5% or less of the actual main story. On top of that they are all incredibly short and easy. All they require you to do most of the time is sneak to the other side of a small room. Usually that involves nothing more than distracting one enemy, or possessing another. Additionally, once a stealth section has been cleared, you will never have to do it again if you return to the same area. 

Another problem is the story. It's a confused mess of underutilised characters and poorly explained plot devices. This game was set up as a big finale to the Lords of Shadow story, and unfortunately it mostly fails at that. There are a lot of characters in the game which don't get as much time as they need to really make the impact they otherwise could. They often appear only as bosses, given a short introduction and forgotten immediately after. While the boss fights themselves are fun, from a story perspective they feel like they are being given the short straw. There are also some elements of the story that are fairly crucial to the plot which aren't explained well at all. For example the Mirror of Fate, from the game of the same name, also plays a prominent role in this game, but its significance isn't explained here, and its role seems unrelated to the game it was introduced in. But despite this, there are a few good moments. A conversation or two that hint at some interesting themes, although they are never explored as they could be, still bring out some good character moments. There's a sense that this game is trying to do a character study of Dracula, exploring his inner struggle between opening up to accepting his family or succumbing to the power of the evil vampiric curse. But it deals with these themes clumsily, and doesn't give them enough time and attention. The best part of the story was mostly the tone and feeling of it, which in both the previous games and this one, are mostly achieved through the aesthetics.

So overall, Lords of Shadow 2 is a pretty good game. Far from perfect, but certainly undeserving of the overly harsh critical mauling it got on release. If you were a fan of the previous Lords of Shadow game(s), then this should be right up your alley as well. It's far from the best game in the world, but much like its predecessors, it is a flawed gem.

As a side note, I recommend that if you have played the first game, but not Mirror of Fate, you should also play that before this one. The stories are quite closely connected, and as previously mentioned, this game expects you to be familiar with it. Although it’s not as good as LoS2, MoF is short and can be beaten in a day if you focus on only the main story.

14822667.review:
What a botched sequel this truly is. I loved Lords of Shadow. It had some issues, but was incredibly enjoyable, from the variety of settings to the classic monsters Gabriel did battle with. 

I'd read that this one was very slow to get going, but that once it did, it was solid. That disappointed me in and of itself, but it also made me wait for a sale to buy it. Finally a good one came along, and I bought the game, looking forward to get back into the world and see what had become of Gabriel since we'd last met. 

Because I'd read the reviews already, I was willing to sludge through the awful stealth sections where you have to turn into a rat to accomplish a variety of goals. And yes, they were terrible. But what was also very annoying was a constant sense of "where do I go" and "what am I supposed to do now?" A lot of time was spent backtracking or wandering all over the map looking for the next goal. There were areas that I couldn't get to simply because I wasn't SUPPOSED to get to them yet, even though I could see things I wanted just beyond simple things like rocks that Dracula should've easily been able to leap over and obtain. 

Not this Dracula. So that took me right out of the immersion. But OK, I can overlook it if the game itself is good. 

It's just the opposite of the first LoS to me. That one was excellent with a few flaws. This one is generally bad with a few bright spots, none of which make up for the game as a whole. 

The voice acting, aside from Dracula, is absolutely terrible, especially the "extras" you fight who constantly shout out the same lines over and over. The monsters in this one are poorly designed as well, and even the humans look bizarre. Garbriel's head often seems way too small for his giant body, for instance. 

Some of the fights were OK, but the vast majority just came down to relentless button mashing mixed with evasion. You can learn all the "cool moves" you want, but you really don't need them. Just mash that X and Y, and you'll get through most of the fights. Boss battles are typical of the problem with so many of these types of games today: big, giant, lumbering beasts or creatures that you have to climb or hit a glowing portion on, blah, blah, blah. Nothing exciting, nothing very interesting. 

The only thing that kept me going in this was really wanting to see a resolution to Dracula's story. Quite frankly, I wanted to see him become Gabriel again. But about 3/4 of the way in, I realized that, despite what some of the reviews said, this game was not getting much better. I was revisiting the same places over and over again, and who wants to walk Dracula around science labs in a game like this? Drab, boring science labs is where you spend much of the game, not the gothic settings of the first. 

SPOILER:
Anyway, I was getting so frustrated wtih the game that I decided to spoil the ending for myself. I wanted to see if it was worth playing through to the end for a solid payoff. Well ... for me, it's not. Not even close. There was no resolution whatsoever. Silly me. How could I not get that they were just going to leave everything open-ended for yet another one of these things. The plot has become idiotic, downright stupid. I felt dumber for having played as much as I did. 

But at least I got it on sale. A true shame what they did to this franchise after such a great predecessor. Do not recommend this game at all.

14804695.review:
A few notes about this review: I'm yet to play the prequel to this game as of the time this review was written, and as such, will not be comparing this title to Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 1.

Gameplay:

The game is very reminiscent of open-world  hack and slash classics such as Devil May Cry and Bayonetta. The mechanics are well varied and properly executed, and at its' very beginning, launches the player into action. 

The boss fights are bloody, epic, and memorable. Little was spared in terms of length and difficulty when encountering various bosses, who are well varied and endowed. Prepare to die a few times in your quest to make progress.

Note that duie to the nature of the story (see section below) , repetitive gameplay is necessitated for one to unlock Dracula's potential abilities as the story progresses. This is executed in a repetitive manner, and as such, incurs a considerable challenge at the early stages of the game. However, as an indirect consequence, later sections are very rewarding as your new abilities are fully utilized in making progress. Prepare for a challenge. 

The stealth system and mechanics used are not ideal and are out of balance. A being such as dracula shouldn't be reduced to a powerless imp in the stealth sections, which can be confusing and often convoluted. 

Graphics:

Excellent, judging bu its' requirements and visuals. They are well balanced and properly executed. Details are clear and vivid, and so are the vast, open world environments. Character forms are well refined and so are their spectral abilities. 

Story line: 

All in all, dependin gon your background, its' taste may differ to you. I've read previous reviews from people who played the games' prequel and most were not pleased.
in my opinion, I found the fusion of both the present and the past (through the use of the Wolf Medallion) a bit unique in that you can switch to either timeline and progress at your own rate. In a manner, this further enhances the open world experience. As a drawback, this can make the game very repetitive since the environments are consrained to one transitional area, a chemical company. This also incurs a drawback to the overall quality of Dracula's retelling as a legendary vampire who must be trapped to a moden themed factory for extended periods of gameplay time as a requirement to progressing in the game. This repetitive nature may not bode well for all players. 

Overall rating:

The production quality is superb, and so is the gameplay. Comes highly recommended.
My personal rating is 7.5/10.

I really enjoyed this game. I played 1st one as well so I was interested in how the story ends especially because of amazing outro. The story of previous game was amazing with a lot of plot twists. However, in case of this game, it was shorter and narrower. Anyway, I still enjoyed it and I really loved the ending. If I would play it as a standalone game I would be still satisfied, but I also understand those who are disappointed especially when they are comparing it to the first game.

When it comes to gameplay - play this game with controller!!! (I played with X-box controller and I can only recommend it). There was like only one mini game when I switched to mouse for a faster and smoother aiming. Otherwise this game is really difficult to play with keyboard, especially because hints are given in X-box controller binding (for example "Press [insert green circle with A letter] to continue").

Combat system was amazing compared to the previous game. Camera was also improved. Those two things let you really enjoy all the fights, especially those with bosses. On the other hand, difficulty was decreased (at least this is my impression) compared to the previous game. And not only during fights. I also found climbing passages much easier. Yes, they were smoother, more intuitive and much less painful than in previous game, but on the other hand, I felt like I am just moving stick in one of the 4 directions and Gabriel is auto-piloting himself through those catch points on the wall. If those passages are replaced with cinematics of Gabriel climbing some wall, I would not see any difference and that is a bit disappointing for me.

When it comes to stealth passages, I see a lot of people did not like them. Honestly, I expected those passages will be very often and very boring after reading some reviews, but I found them quite interesting and there were actually only few in the game.

Another thing I would like to mention are puzzles. I really liked puzzles in the first game and this was probably the biggest disappointment for me, because there were only few puzzles and difficulty of all of them was like difficulty of puzzles in pre-school kid magazines.

And last thing I would like to talk about are graphics. They are really amazing. Especially castle is truly master piece. However, it is looking quite the same all the time. During playing the first game, player is going through various environments. Each one looks different. Each one got different colour scheme. Each one got unique textures. Environments in first game are truly amazing and I still remember a lot of amazing sceneries from there. But with this game everything is dark and quite the same. Only colourful place I can remember was one garden passage within the castle (I will not say more details to not spoil it). Details are still really amazing, but everything is so dark and similar, that you will stop sense them.

I guess this is mainly because the game is open-world like and not level system like in previous game so environment have to be "one solid connected piece". In the first game all what was needed was simple introduction "and in this level Gabriel went to some other place far away from previous one" and environment could change drastically. In this game it has to fit all together, because there is no space for long distance travelling.

Well, to sum it up - I was satisfied with this game. If I would not play the first one I would probably enjoy it much more. The truth is, that the first game set really high standards and they were overcome only in a very few cases. For the most of them, they were below those from the first game. Still, I would give this game something about 70-80%.

I had a much better time with this than I expected. The early reviews for the game made it sound like it was terrible, but it really wasn't that bad. However, that's not to say it isn't without its flaws. 

The highlight of the game is probably its combat. You get three different weapons this time around instead of just magical powerups for the whip like in the original LOS: A light magic sword, dark magic gauntlets, and the whip returns as the default weapon. Each has their own style and role in combat; the sword can heal you when you do damage, the gauntlets do more damage than the other two overall and can also break enemy blocking, and the whip has good crowd control skills and has more range overall. Each weapon also has a fleshed out skill/move set tree that you can unlock with experience points. Gabriel controls more or less the same as he did in LOS with a couple tweaks, like a free moving camera.

For the overall main plot the game is shorter than the original Lords of Shadow, but it has much more in the way of secret items and challenge modes. The game is also much less linear than the original, with a semi-open world map that you can freely roam when not in a specific mission. The voice work is high quality, with much of the cast of the original returning (Patrick Stewart FTW) along with some new cast members who give a great performance as well. The game itself also looks great with very detailed and unique locals, characters, and monsters.

The biggest let down of the game is probably the forced stealth sections. They slow down what is normally a relatively fast paced game to a crawl, and don't work out well with how the game controls. They also don't really make sense in the context of the game, you are supposed to be this powerful being and yet these power armored lackeys can utterly destroy you if they see you. Thankfully there aren't many of these sections, and the rest of the game definitely makes up for it.

Overall I'd say the game is pretty good and is definitely worthwhile if you've played the other Lords of Shadow games.

Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 is an awesome game and the classic example of what's wrong with Metacritic. A 58 out of 100 seems awfully low for a game that plays so well, that I'm baffled by the hatred it gets from critics. Or, perhaps, the way Metacritic aggregates review scores is the problem? A single negative review can make that score right there plummet and provide extreme misinformation on an otherwise great game!

Lords of Shadow 2 does a few things quite well. First, it removes the stupid locked camera. Second, it has easy to learn combos that the game outright encourages you to use via the "mastery" system. Third, it has far more gothic scenery and themes that pay a deep homage to Castlevania in general. Fourth, the graphics are absolutely beautiful yet they run at 60 frames per second. Fifth, the bosses are incredible. Sixth, there's a ton of secrets and for the most part you are encouraged to explore at your leisure between objectives. Those are the six key aspects I can think of, besides the music, voiceacting, and controls being stellar as well. The story can be confusing, but it's the most tragic tale of Dracula I've ever seen in my life, and that is awesome in itself! Have you ever found yourself rooting for Dracula in all of the Castlevania games? Well, you WILL in this game!

The most criticized aspect of this game is that it "doesnt know what it wants to be", on critic reviews. I'm sorry, but there is such a thing as "gameplay variety". Consistency is nice, but this game isn't trying to be 100% like God of War, and offers decent stealth segments which aren't awful. Some of these segments are even a little clever, but they could be better. In fact, the game IS consistent for the most part, offering lots of platforming, action, exploration, secrets, and grand vistas. So why is that the worst part of the game? Is it really too linear? Does it really change too often too fast with the gameplay? Is it not trying hard enough to be Metroidvania style? These questions don't matter. The classic Castlevania games were by far more linear than this game, except the often criticized Simon's Quest entry. 13635528.review:
According to Steam I've sunk 16.8 hours into this game from beginning to end, and two of that was on the last boss, because jeez, what a pain!

If you were a fan of Lords Of Shadow 1 then the next entry should definitely satisfy your jonesing for another foray as Gabriel Belmont.  

The story is decent, it's not an amazing articulate and in depth thriller, but it is serviceable for the game that it is, and honestly, as far as Castlevania games go, it is probably the best story.  (People really seem to love the 'plots' of Castlevania games without understanding that the story is generally pretty weak.)

Gameplay-wise, big improvement over LoS1.  The camera isn't locked, the environments are open for fighting and the "background" doesn't obstruct the combat the way it did in LoS1.

The platforming is guided, there aren't a lot of fall down and die challenges, if you can make a leap, you'll make a leap, and there's a lot less guesswork than there was in the first one since the camera now sits behind Gabriel not a mile away from him while you judge a gap.

The pace does get disrupted in several moments with these bizarre stealth pieces that, as you approach the end of the game, will have you wondering how it is you still aren't powerful enough to sneak around enemies you should be able to kill.  If you've been playing about 45 minutes of combat, then expect to spend the next 45 dealing with sneaking.  There are a couple of scenes that will definitely test the frustration durability of your controller as well.

The game allows backtracking, but it isn't as crucial as it was in LoS1.  I remember in LoS1 NEEDING to go back and get some more upgrades because combat was such a pain.  In this I tended to find enough health upgrades, power upgrades etc. along the way if I kept my eyes open for side passes, that I did not backtrack at all.

I didn't backtrack because it is a giant pain in the ass.  The environments are HUGE, there is a quick travel system but it goes to like 4 waypoints in massive areas in the city or in the castle, so it doesn't exactly put you right where you want to be.  I thought about it said "nope" and never backtracked, aside from hitting up a shop.

You may also get locked into certain fights and you can't back out of them to go back and farm health potions, so you're screwed.  Let's just say I spent so long fighting the last boss starting with a shred of health and zero void sword power that I had to learn how to fight and counter him effectively.  I'm probably pretty much unbeatable now thanks to my own lack of preparation going in to the end game.

Despite some of the flaws, fun game.

So...

Get this if:

You love the atmosphere / plot of the Castlevania games and aren't so linear in your thinking that "ZOMGZ ITS NOT CASTLEVANIA IF ITS NOT 2D!"  Or if you were ever a fan of the Legacy of Kain games, because there hasn't been a better "bad-ass-vampire platformer" since the last ones of those were made.

Avoid it if: 

You need complicated platforming, not the hand holding kind, or if you're the kind of person who will put a game down if the pace of it gets disrupted.  Because this game definitely upsets its own pace several times during a playthrough, and then it just sits on your computer never getting played.

When in doubt:

Steam sale!

13371031.review:
Allow me to add to the chorus that says "The Metacritic Score is a lie."

This was a good game. Though it differs from the first. It is by that measure that I think its best compared.

+Graphical Presentation+
The first game had your character crossing an elaborate, Lord of the Rings like world with plenty of variety and set pieces. It was absolutely beautiful.

None of that beauty comes close to be realized here. Instead, what you get is an atmosphere...

...THAT ACTUALLY FEELS LIKE CASTLEVANIA!

There are many reviewers who will cry at the fact that the last game was prettier, but here, you are in a dark, moody castle with full control of your camera and dammit I just couldn't help but love how it actually felt like you were involved in a dark tale of vampires and demons, unlike the first. So between this and the first, its an apples to oranges comparision. In the end, the graphical presentation gives you that SoTN feel that the first game was missing (the sexy mountaintops of LoS1 be darned).

+Story (Spoiler Free)+
The first game was about losing faith. The second game is about redemption. Obviously. What else is new? What's important here is characterization and voice acting delivery. To which it does an absolutely fantastic job of delivering. Though, in my view, its story is not as heavy as the first, given that every single chapter in LoS1 had Captain Picarde himself explaining what the heck is going on in detail. We really could've used that narration to explain some of the strange stuff having in this castle-city. Like what the heck is a castle doing here in the first place? That was a head-trip, but hey, its Dracula; his castle be constantly respawning I guess.

So here's what I recommend you do before jumping in here: 1) Play the first game first (or read its cliff-notes). 2) Play Mirror of Fate (or read its cliff-notes) . They frequently make references to the first game and the hand-held tie-in so if you skip these steps then expect a confusing plot. 

Given that I didn't skip these steps, I found LoS2 to make for a pretty good story. Certainly has more heart than most games these days. It's like a DMC that you can take seriously.

+Gameplay+
Here is the one place where I can say without a doubt that it delivers better than the first game. You see, LoS2 is easier than the first, for all the RIGHT reasons.

The first had some Nintendo-hard bulls*** issues holding it back that have been fixed. For one, you have more options given the three weapons to choose from. The lame Light and Dark Magic system is replaced by an Ice Weapon and Fire Weapon.  In the first game, you only switched to Light to heal on occasion and that was it, as you were constantly struggling to fill up the focus meter to fuel your heals. Dark magic was never used. It was nothing more than an unimportant DPS buff. 

Here, the replacements to the old magic honestly feels different enough for you to want to mix it up, what with the fire ability being able to break enemy shields and blocking (in addition to doing more DPS), and the ice sword having some mean crowd control abilities (in addition to healing you). Filling up the focus meter is much faster and easier so you can continue to fuel these things without fear, and with the camera in your control, you just won't feel as frustrated as before.

The side items and powers are must more useful as well, and a power you get later on adds a whole new dimension to to your defensive options. Overall, I'd say LoS1 comes no where CLOSE to being a steller action game in the gameplay department. It was servicable and that was it. Here, we actually have a system that's as fun as God of War.  YOU FEEL LIKE YOU'RE GOD-DAMNED DRACULA, AND NO ONE CAN F*** WITH YOU! You ARE the final boss of over 30 games, and nothing can stop you, only slow you down.

Hell yeah. 

About the only thing relatively weak are the stealth sections, which make sense only at the start of the game...how is it that you're a threat to Satan, but these red guys can blow your ass away doing 9999 damage per shot? I need Captain Picarde to explain. Fortunately, such sections are mercifully short and easy.

There are also fewer puzzles than the first game. But who cares?

+Overall+
Overall I give this game a 7.9/10. Its not the greatest thing since Bayonetta but taken as a whole, the Lord of Shadows series offers the best story in the action game genre today...taken as a whole.  View Lord of Shadows 1 and 2 as one really long epic and you're pretty much doing it right. When the dust clears, you'll likely give this game a worthy playthrough on New Game + and have fun with it as well.

13284983.review:
I loved the hell out of the first Lords of Shadow, and I enjoyed this game as well. However, it's not without its share of problems.

First and foremost, there's the setting. I didn't mind the fact that a significant portion of the game was set in the near future, but the open nature of the environments (both the castle and the city) seemed to sap the creative element from their design. Yes, it's cool that all of it links together, but that feeling of exploring strange new landscapes with all their weird quirks has been completely sacrificed. I get that it works with the plot, but I feel like the game would have benefited from having a level structure like the first.

Speaking of plot, there's the second problem. The story in LoS2 doesn't stack up to the first game at all, opting to go with a campier plot more reminscent of other Castlevania games than the original Lords of Shadow. While this isn't inherently a bad thing (I love Castlevania as a series, cheese and all), there's a massive plot hole introduced at the beginning of the game that is never resolved. Dracula was defeated at the end of Mirror of Fate, but apparently rose up again at some point between that game and this one. This is entirely glossed over in the main narrative and only offhandedly mentioned in Alucard's lore entry. I might be expecting too much out of the story of a Castlevania game, but it bothers me nonetheless given the detail and work put into the first game.

Then there's the stealth sections. Oh god, the stealth sections. For the most part it's not too bad; there is one enemy type that requires you to go around instead of confronting directly. These sections are mostly just mild hiccups in the pacing (which also isn't quite as good as the first game), but the final one is absolutely one of the worst segments I've had the displeasure of playing through. Not only is this segment immensly frustrating, but you battle the thing you were sneaking around immediately afterwards; no new weapon, no new powers, no upgrades whatsoever. You just fight it straight away, essentially rendering all the work you just did completely pointless.

Fortunately, it's not all bad. The combat is a ton of fun, giving you three different weapons with distinct features and fighting styles. It also looks fantastic; though I disparaged the nature of the new environments earlier, I can't deny the level of detail put into the city and Dracula's castle. The creatures and characters all look great too, from the detailed facial animations of the humanoids to Satan's grotesque abominations. Voice acting is solid; the actors did a good job delivering the lukewarm script in a believable way.

All in all, Lords of Shadow 2 is a solid action game with a few flaws. Go into it expecting more of a Devil May Cry experience than a Lords of Shadow 1 experience and I think you'll be able to derive more enjoyment from it that way.
